text: In threatening doctors with sanctions if they prescribe marijuana for patients, the Clinton Administration says it is buttressing its fight against drug use by young people and countering the effects of two recently approved ballot initiatives in California and Arizona that declare marijuana legal if used for medical purposes.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: But the Government's threat has angered a number of doctors, who criticize it as a new intrusion by Washington into their right to decide what is best for their patients.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: ''They can't go after the voters in California and Arizona, so they go after the medical profession,'' said Dr. David C. Lewis, director of the Center for Alcohol and Addiction Studies at Brown University. ''Now the Federal Government is entering the practice of medicine, placing itself in the physician's office between the doctor and patient.''
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: Dr. Richard J. Cohen, a cancer specialist in San Francisco, agreed that the Administration's announcement yesterday amounted to such an intrusion. Over the last 28 years, Dr. Cohen said, he has recommended marijuana to alleviate the suffering of hundreds of his patients. Now, he said, he finds himself in the ''Kafkaesque'' position where he cannot do so without jeopardizing his practice.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: ''The benefit of the California referendum was to open the door for research to be done'' about marijuana, Dr. Cohen said. ''The Federal mandate closes that door of opportunity.'' Another California doctor, Donald Abrams, has contended that the Federal Government blocked his efforts to undertake research on the effect of marijuana.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: Barry R. McCaffrey, the retired four-star Army general who heads the White House Office of National Drug Control Policy, seemed to leave room for such projects when he said in a telephone interview that ''without question the door is open to examine any drug,'' including marijuana, that would benefit American medicine.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: But he immediately stressed that such research must be scientifically valid and pass a peer review of other medical researchers, some of whom express doubts about the therapeutic value of marijuana. The American Medical Association and the California Medical Association are among the professional groups opposed to marijuana for medical purposes.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: ''That's going to be our focus: on science, not ideology,'' General McCaffrey said in the interview. He said marijuana had no demonstrated medical benefit that was not offered by other drugs. ''Tremendous pain management remedies are available,'' he said.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: Dr. Kildare Clarke, an emergency doctor with a private practice in White Plains, said he had two patients who had benefited from marijuana. One suffered from a seizure disorder, he said, and the other had optic neuritis, a degenerative eye disease that has apparently stabilized since he used marijuana.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: ''We're in the business to care for the patient,'' Dr. Clarke said, ''and whatever works should be utilized for the best interest of the patient.''
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: Back in his native Jamaica, he said, marijuana was widely used to treat different ailments. ''Those people do not have resources to go and see doctors,'' he said.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: But many other doctors remain wary of the implications of the use of marijuana in medicine.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: ''Who could possibly be against sick and dying people getting relief?'' said Dr. Sally Satel, an addiction psychiatrist in Washington. ''But the way it's set forth, you can't disentangle it from the legalization effort.'' Marijuana, Dr. Satel said, should be ''explicitly limited to grossly debilitated people who have failed all other interventions, those near death and those who need it for an acute problem.''
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: The Federal law that bars doctors from prescribing marijuana is the Controlled Substances Act, passed in 1970. The law regulates drugs by dividing them into five categories, according to their potential for abuse. Marijuana coexists with heroin under Schedule I, the most stringent category, for drugs with a high potential for abuse and no currently accepted medical use.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: Cocaine and methamphetamines, which are widely regarded as more dangerous than marijuana, are listed under Schedule II because they have some accepted medical use in treatment. Cocaine, for example, may be used as a topical anesthetic in eye surgery.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: Other drugs are classified under the three other schedules by their decreasing potential for abuse. Tylenol with codeine and some barbiturates are on Schedule III, Valium and other tranquilizers on Schedule IV, and over-the-counter cough medicines on Schedule V.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: Doctors, who are required to register with the Drug Enforcement Administration to prescribe drugs, are permitted to use substances from Schedules II through V, but not from Schedule I.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: The Government has approved dronabinol, a capsule form of anti-nausea medicine that incorporates marijuana's active ingredient, tetrahydrocannabinol, but without its psychoactive high. Some patients who have tried it complain that the capsule, marketed under the brand name Marinol, acts more slowly than marijuana and is much more expensive.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: The Administration yesterday cited some of the sanctions it could impose on doctors who prescribe marijuana as another medicine. The Drug Enforcement Administration could revoke its registration of them, and the Department of Health and Human Services could withhold the money it pays for patients who are treated under Medicare and Medicaid.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: Where state or local law-enforcement officials are unwilling or unable to confiscate marijuana, Federal drug agents would fill the breach. But Attorney General Janet Reno yesterday played down any notion that doctors would be singled out for prosecution.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: The American Civil Liberties Union, meanwhile, joined in criticizing what it called the Government's hypocrisy about medical marijuana. The group's education director, Loren Siegal, contended in a statement that the Government ''has consistently impeded research into medical marijuana'' while maintaining that its effectiveness should be subjected to scientific scrutiny.
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: ''If that were true,'' Mr. Siegal said, ''a body of scientific research would exist.''
title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures

text: Voter initiatives in California and Arizona approving the use of marijuana for medical purposes are spreading alarm among many families and confronting law enforcement officials with a tough dilemma. Although the voters in those two states have clearly spoken, it is impossible for either measure to be carried out without someone violating Federal law. The Clinton Administration thus has little choice but to insist that Federal drug statutes be enforced. That response is not enough, however. Federal authorities need to address concerns that a legitimate treatment for seriously ill patients is being blocked because of broader fears of marijuana abuse.
title: Marijuana for the Sick

text: The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration maintains there is no medical evidence that smoking marijuana has ever helped anyone. But it is difficult to dismiss the testimony from many seriously ill patients and their doctors that marijuana can ease pain, reduce the nausea associated with cancer chemotherapy, stimulate the appetites of AIDS patients who are wasting away, and lower the pressure within the eyes of glaucoma victims. The Food and Drug Administration has approved a synthetic version of THC, a main ingredient of marijuana, that can help in such cases, but many patients complain that it is a poor substitute and is much more expensive.
title: Marijuana for the Sick

text: What is needed now is a more thorough effort to test the claims from reputable sources that marijuana may be a compassionate means of relieving suffering. Many critics charge that drug enforcement authorities have instead cut back on research out of fear that it would become impossible to limit marijuana use to those who need it medically. The fears are understandable, especially given the rising use of marijuana among teen-agers today. But it ought to be possible to regulate marijuana as a prescription drug if it is found to be of legitimate benefit for sick people.
title: Marijuana for the Sick

text: State initiatives are a clumsy way to set policy. The California proposition, for example, is so vaguely written that it could lead to wholesale distribution of marijuana well beyond the medical scope intended by those who voted for it. It says nothing about withholding marijuana from young people or from those operating dangerous equipment. It also suggests that a simple oral recommendation from any doctor would suffice. That loose provision, designed to get around Federal laws that bar doctors from prescribing an illegal substance, makes abuse of the new law inevitable. The Arizona law, by contrast, requires that marijuana be prescribed in writing by two doctors. But that measure is also written too broadly. It says that many other drugs, not simply marijuana, may be prescribed if permission from two doctors is obtained.
title: Marijuana for the Sick

text: Supporters of the California measure did their cause no good by immediately lighting up marijuana cigarettes after it passed last month and proclaiming that a legitimate medicinal use would include smoking a joint to relieve stress. Dennis Peron, originator of the California initiative, said afterward, ''I believe all marijuana use is medical -- except for kids.'' These actions made it obvious that the goal of at least some supporters is to get marijuana legalized outright, a proposition that opinion polls indicate most Americans reject.
title: Marijuana for the Sick

text: Parents have legitimate concerns about the increase in marijuana use among teen-agers. Many who used marijuana a generation ago are struggling over what to tell their children, but they need to realize that today's marijuana is more potent than the version they smoked and that research has shown the drug to be far more dangerous to young people than was known in the 1960's and 1970's. It can be particularly harmful to the growth and development of teen-agers.
title: Marijuana for the Sick

text: California's Attorney General, Daniel Lungren, has ordered state law enforcement officials to interpret the law's language narrowly and require proof from those arrested that marijuana is being used medically. The Clinton Administration is expected to announce today an aggressive campaign to combat the state initiatives, including criminal prosecution of doctors who prescribe marijuana. That hard line makes sense for now. But if the Government refuses to investigate carefully the claims about medical use of marijuana, it will only spur voters in other states to take the issue into their own hands.
title: Marijuana for the Sick

text: Two young women, lifelong friends who vanished early Friday after leaving a nightclub in Jamaica, Queens, were found yesterday morning locked inside a storefront about half a mile away. One had been badly beaten and the other had apparently been bludgeoned to death.

text: The discovery was made by the members of a social club who recognized the women's pictures from the television news Saturday evening and went to look for them in the store next door, Mama's Mini Mart at 109-10 Guy R. Brewer Boulevard, where they remembered having seen the women on Friday morning.

text: Through the window of the locked store, they saw Marsha Davis, 21, slumped over a video game and covered with blood, and broke in to rescue her. When the police came, they found the body of Rushiandra Cooper, 23, a senior at Brooklyn College, behind a counter, Doram Tamari, a police spokesman, said.

text: When the evening news came on television at 11 P.M., the members of the Southside Social Club watched the segment about the disappearance, and the conversation quickly turned to the women's plight.

text: It had begun as a typical Saturday night at the club, an unmarked storefront on Guy R. Then they began discussing the missing women.

text: Shortly before midnight, a man from the neighborhood walked into the club and told the members that he seemed to remember seeing the women hanging around with a man who works at Mama's Mini Mart, a small arcade of shops next door to the social club, on Friday morning.

text: A few eyebrows were raised. The store had been closed since Friday afternoon. ''I've never seen that store closed, ever, so that was something that was suspicious to me,'' said James Thompson, 19, who had been hanging out at the club on Saturday evening. The men decided to investigate.

title: Woman Found Slain in Store in Queens

text: Then they saw a sneaker, moving slightly. It was Ms. Davis's. She was slumped over a video game, wearing a jacket that they recognized as belonging to one of the men who works at the store. They recognized her from her picture on television.

title: Woman Found Slain in Store in Queens

text: Outside the social club, Mr. Jackson shrugged off any suggestion that he and his friends had acted heroically. He said that he simply regretted not getting there soon enough to save Ms. Cooper. text: Murder by strangers has declined more than twice as much as murder by acquaintances over four years in New York City, part of a pronounced shift in both the nature and scope of homicide in the city.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: The city is almost certain to end the year with fewer than 1,000 murders, the lowest level since 1968, newly released police records show.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: The figures offer a measure of relief from one particularly jarring brand of urban terror: random violence. The percentage of victims killed by strangers dropped to 19 percent this year, from 37 percent in 1993. There were fewer murders in public places, fewer murders stemming from spontaneous disputes and robberies, fewer drug-related murders and fewer murders committed by teen-agers. Four out of every five murder victims knew their killers.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: While the overall number of murder victims has fallen, the drop in the number killed by strangers is particularly striking. That figure is down by 74 percent over four years, while the number of those killed by acquaintances is down by 36 percent.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: ''The city is now safer in that, one, you are less likely to be murdered, and two, you are less likely to be attacked by a stranger,'' Police Commissioner Howard Safir said. ''It's the kind of thing that people always talk about, that if you go to New York somebody's going to come out of an alley and shoot you.''
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: And since success has many fathers, criminologists, sociologists, law-enforcement officials and politicians continue to debate where the credit belongs. Their theories about the declining number of murders, particularly random murders, range from the waning of the crack epidemic, the improving economy and the doubling of the prison population to new policing strategies, tougher gun control laws and the dismantling of major drug gangs.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: While the homicide rate is falling across the nation, particularly in the biggest and most violent cities, New York's decline exceeds that of the country as a whole. With only three days left in the year, the tally of murder victims was 972, less than half what it was in 1990, when the city set a record for homicides with 2,245.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: ''When New York goes from 2,000 murders to 1,000, that's substantial,'' said Dr. Andrew Karmen, a professor of sociology at John Jay College of Criminal Justice who studies the city's murder rate. ''There is something very real happening. It is not a blip or a passing phenomenon.''
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: The steepest decline in murders has been among black New Yorkers. According to data from the State Department of Health that Dr. Karmen analyzed, black New Yorkers were killed at the rate of about 31 per 100,000 in 1995, the latest statistics available, down from 53 per 100,000 in 1993. ''It's still far above the national norm, and it's still much too high, but historically speaking it is the best it has been in 25 years,'' Dr. Karmen said.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: The murder rate for Hispanic New Yorkers dropped to 18 per 100,000 in 1995 from 34 per 100,000 in 1993, while the murder rate for white New Yorkers remained constant, at around 7 per 100,000.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: A critical factor, law-enforcement officials said, is that there seem to be fewer guns on the streets. Arrests for gun possession dropped by 20 percent this year, to 4,200, and there were 21 percent fewer shootings and 22 percent fewer shooting victims, according to police statistics. The proportion of murders committed with guns dropped to 67 percent this year from 75 percent in 1993.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: Commissioner Safir credits the Police Department's crackdown on quality-of-life offenses -- like drinking beer in public, fare-beating in the subways and public urination -- with discouraging many people from carrying their guns.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: ''It is my belief that people who carry weapons in the city are less likely to carry them because there is a higher risk of being arrested for weapons possession by a police officer based on our quality-of-life enforcement, our roadblocks or drug initiatives,'' he said. ''From the intelligence we get, people are stashing their weapons rather than carrying them.''
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: Tougher gun control laws around the nation have made it harder for smugglers to buy guns in states with more permissive laws and then resell them illegally on the streets of New York. The Brady law, for example, requires a five-day waiting period to buy a handgun. And Virginia, once a main supplier of illegal guns in New York, has enacted a law limiting buyers to one gun a month.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: But gun traffickers have moved on, the authorities said, particularly to the Carolinas and Florida.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: The Police Department has teamed up with the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms to break up gunrunning rings that have brought hundreds of guns into the city. In a recent case, bureau agents traced more than 150 guns that turned up in New York to a Federally licensed gun shop in Orlando, Fla.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: An investigation led to three arrests, and all pleaded guilty and are awaiting sentencing. Now the agency is trying to discourage small-time gunrunners who bring guns back to the city in dribs and drabs. ''We continue to target the organized firearms trafficking rings, but we are also focusing on casual firearms traffickers,'' said Henry J. Ballas, the special agent in charge of the bureau's New York office.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: Commissioner Safir said the country needed even more stringent gun control laws. ''I believe what we need is a national one-gun-a-month law,'' he said. ''I'm too much of a realist to believe we could get guns banned, but at least something that approaches sanity -- but is still not sane -- like a one-gun-a-month law would be incredibly helpful.''
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: The murder rate fell the most in neighborhoods that were the city's most violent. For years, the city's deadliest precinct was the 75th in East New York, Brooklyn, where 110 people were murdered in 1993. This year, the toll was 35. Murders dropped by more than half in the 44th Precinct, in the Highbridge and East Tremont sections of the Bronx, to 17 this year from 43 last year.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: The dismantling of several violent drug gangs appears to have stemmed the tide of murders in some neighborhoods. In northern Queens, for example, three gangs that officials said operated as murder and collection squads for the Cali drug cartel of Colombia were broken up after investigations by the police and the Drug Enforcement Administration.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: The police said they believed the gangs were responsible for up to 30 murders in Jackson Heights, Corona, Elmhurst and Long Island City in 1995. This year, the number of murders in northern Queens dropped to 60 from 113 the year before.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: A similar trend can be seen in Manhattan Valley, where more than 100 members of rival drug gangs have been arrested in sweeps conducted by the Manhattan District Attorney's Homicide Investigation Unit and the Police Department. Murders in the 24th Precinct, which includes Manhattan Valley, have fallen to 7 this year from 21 in 1993.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: Commissioner Safir said he expected crime to fall further because of two drug-fighting initiatives in northern Manhattan and northern Brooklyn. Both neighborhoods, major drug sites, have seen added officers patrolling the streets, more undercover officers buying drugs and guns and collecting intelligence on gangs and greater cooperation among city, state and Federal law-enforcement agencies, Mr. Safir said.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: With arrests way up for low-level ''quality of life'' crimes, more people are being brought through the criminal justice system, fingerprinted and questioned about what they may know about more serious crimes. Some suspects tell the police the location of illegal weapons.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: Others give information about bigger crimes. Last week, the police arrested a 19-year-old on a charge of selling marijuana, and the police said he confessed to being the lookout for the Dec. 21 robbery of a Queens check-cashing store that resulted in the murders of Charles A. Davis, an off-duty police officer moonlighting as a security guard, and Ira Epstein, the store's owner.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: ''We routinely ask, 'What do you know, what can you tell us?' '' said one police official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ''Ninety-nine out of a hundred times we get nothing, but once in while something breaks. The drop is not the result of any one thing, it's the payoff for a lot of little things like this.''
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: But murders are not down everywhere. In the East Village, they climbed to 13 this year from 3 in 1995.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: And for the friends and relatives of the 972 people who were killed, the figures offer cold comfort.
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

text: ''The crime rate went down, but it didn't go down enough; I lost my sister,'' said Ethel Davis, 31, whose sister, Evelyn, was killed on Dec. 7 as she saved two friends at a social club in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, from robbers who tried to shoot them execution style. ''That was the only sister I had. I'm glad they caught the guys, but it's not going to bring her back. I don't feel safe around here. She died right around the corner from the house.''
title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: The defense lawyer for Alex Kelly pushed a lot of people's outrage buttons when, after the jury deadlock in Mr. Kelly's Connecticut trial on rape charges in November, he blasted Mr. Kelly's accuser as a ''very unvictim victim'' and berated her family for going to court ''totally coiffed and dressed to kill.''
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Mr. Puccio has been the object of unusual fury since the mistrial in the case of Mr. Kelly, the Darien man who fled two rape charges when he was a teen-ager and lived the life of a ski bum for eight years. Lawyers and women's groups have said Mr. Puccio exploited 19th-century stereotypes of rape victims. He has heard himself publicly called a liar and a ''smooth-talking defense lawyer'' who ''spewed his vitriol.''
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: But Mr. Puccio, it seems obvious, couldn't be more comfortable in the center of controversy. In a series of unapologetic conversations, he said he was unmoved by the criticism and he promised an even more blistering defense in the retrial of Mr. Kelly scheduled for the spring. ''This is going to be a direct attack on her credibility,'' he said with something of a chortle.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: The quintessential combative New York lawyer, who first won fame as a prosecutor of corrupt politicians in the Abscam scandal and then became a celebrity defense lawyer, has parlayed his courtroom skills into a comfortable life that includes a Park Avenue office, influential friends and wealthy clients. And he clearly relishes being talked about as one tough lawyer for the people who pay him well. He has been known to describe his efforts on their behalf as psychological warfare.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: In the recent conversations, Mr. Puccio appeared defiant about his role as the advocate for an unpopular client, even saying that he felt a bond with Mr. Kelly's parents as they fight for their son because his own teen-age son died in a car accident two years ago while they were together during a driving lesson.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Heedless of his critics, Mr. Puccio repeated his criticisms of what he called the offensive ''fashion statement every day.'' And he said he was beginning an aggressive effort to introduce testimony barred by the judge in the first trial that suggested the young woman might have used cocaine and marijuana. The trial judge concluded that that evidence was based on unscientific tests of a 10-year old bloodstain and the prosecutors accused Mr. Puccio of baseless character assassination.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Some critics have been perplexed by his assault on Mr. Kelly's accuser because it could alienate potential jurors. But people who know him say they understand it: Mr. Puccio smells victory. And to win a high-stakes case, he has shown in the past, he will do what it takes: intimidation of witnesses, humiliation of adversaries or efforts to manage news coverage. The saber-rattling at Mr. Kelly's accuser and her family is a classic Puccio strategy, said one lawyer who has known Mr. Puccio for 20 years but asked not to be named. ''He is sending a message: that if they come back to testify, he is going to take them apart,'' said the lawyer.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Friends say Mr. Puccio is motivated in his cases by an unusually ferocious desire to win. ''In a courtroom, he is incredibly calculating and coldblooded, and I say this not in a derogatory way,'' said Edward R. Korman, a United States District judge in Brooklyn and a longtime friend.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: A Will to Win, A Taste for the Best
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Thomas Phillip Puccio, 52, first tasted the fame that comes with high-profile victories as a Federal prosecutor in Brooklyn nearly 25 years ago. A scrappy lawyer who was born and raised in Brooklyn, he was known in those days as intensely conscious of the fact that his degree came from Fordham and not from Harvard or Yale like those of many of his adversaries.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: But he bested several adversaries with more prestigious diplomas and won a series of convictions of corrupt Congressmen who were videotaped stuffing money into their pockets in the Abscam scandal.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Then, as a defense lawyer, he hit the publicity stratosphere when he won the acquittal of Claus von Bulow, the socialite who was accused of trying to murder his wife. Friends say the von Bulow victory in 1985 showed him the enormous rewards that can come to famous lawyers.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: After working at a series of law firms, he hung up his own shingle in 1992. In doing so, he gave up a partnership at the prestigious firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, known for its handling of Rockefeller interests and where, according to legal newspapers, the average partner earns at least $500,000 a year.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Mr. Puccio said he left Milbank in part because ''frankly there comes a point in time when you want to increase your earning capability.'' For years, one friend said, Mr. Puccio kept in his office a book that listed the supposed best of everything, from fine wines to cooking utensils to antiques.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Mr. Puccio acknowledges that he has what he says is a healthy dose of selfish appetite. ''You hire Tom Puccio and Tom Puccio wants to win for you and Tom Puccio wants to win for himself,'' he said, sitting behind the big desk in his Park Avenue office.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Lawyers who have worked with him say that Mr. Puccio can be so intense in his drive to win that he appears to lose sight of everything else. ''If we're on the phone and he asks me a legal question and he doesn't like the answer, I get a full court press that has me sweating in a minute,'' said Herbert F. Fisher, a Manhattan lawyer and former partner. ''If you are in the way of a result, there are no prisoners taken. It's like watching a kid hold his breath, but it's a very smart kid.''
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Since he left the United States Attorney's office in Brooklyn in 1982 after 13 years as a prosecutor, Mr. Puccio has traveled easily in the New York world of well-connected people. He counts among his friends journalists, Fortune 500 executives and many of the city's blue-chip lawyers. Most of his cases are big-business squabbles, securities cases or white-collar crimes.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Reynaldo P. Glover, the general counsel of T.L.C. Beatrice Holdings, an international company with revenues of $2.1 billion, said he uses Mr. Puccio for legal work partly because of the way he moves around the New York financial community.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: ''This guy's just phenomenal in his knowledge of the way things work and who can make things happen,'' Mr. Glover said.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Admirers and adversaries say that part of making things happen often includes a shrewd sense of how to get his message across. Mr. Puccio is often seen with reporters at his trials, imparting amusing interpretations of events that inevitably indicate what a good job he is doing or what stiff odds he faces.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: In a 1995 autobiography, ''In the Name of the Law,'' which Mr. Puccio wrote with a New York journalist, Dan Collins, there is a hint that Mr. Puccio's interpretations are sometimes carefully tailored. ''One of the absolute rules of defense work,'' he wrote, ''is that you must always tell reporters things are going great -- even if 14 nuns have just taken the stand to identify your client as the man who pulled the trigger.''
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: At Ease With Criticism, But Not With Failure
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Such hardball tactics have left Mr. Puccio with a trail of detractors. In the von Bulow case, for example, Mr. Puccio took over after Mr. von Bulow had been convicted and had won a new trial. Mr. Puccio had the prosecutor in the first trial, Stephen R. Famiglietti, summoned to court in the second trial because Mr. Puccio said he had found evidence of prosecutorial misconduct.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: The judge disagreed, but only after allowing Mr. Puccio a cross-examination of the ex-prosecutor that he describes in his book as ''a rough going over.'' Mr. Famiglietti said in a recent interview that he is still bitter because he believes Mr. Puccio used him for public relations purposes. ''All he was trying to do,'' Mr. Famiglietti said, ''was to embarrass or humiliate me to plant in the minds of the jurors and the trial judge that we had done something improper.''
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: The animosity against Mr. Puccio, several friends said, caused a virtual celebration in 1986 when he sustained the biggest loss of his career. He represented Stanley R. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, who was convicted in the city's Parking Violations Bureau scandal. The prosecutor in the case was Rudolph W. Giuliani. then the United States Attorney in Manhattan.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: ''A lot of guys were so happy when Tom went down with that case.'' said Sidney Zion, the New York writer who has been a friend for years. ''I remember up in the Yale Club, guys were buying drinks for each other.''
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Mr. Puccio acknowledged that he was despondent after the Friedman loss. ''A verdict like that,'' he said, ''is very difficult for a lawyer like me to deal with.'' Three people who know both men said Mr. Puccio remains so uncomfortable about that failure that he has rarely seen Mr. Friedman, who now manages a hotel on Staten Island, since the case ended. Mr. Puccio said that he has not seen Mr. Friedman much ''just because that's the way life is.''
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Other lawyers say, however, that if Mr. Puccio was humbled by his defeat he did not show it with any softening of his scorched-earth style. His attacks on the young woman who said she was raped by Alex Kelly, some of them said, reminded them of the aggressive style of psychological combat that was Mr. Puccio's trademark as a Federal prosecutor years ago.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: For his part, Mr. Puccio is unrepentant to the point of asserting that critics who say he overstepped the bounds of propriety with his attack on the young woman misunderstand the role of a defense lawyer. ''My job,'' he said, ''is to defend people and to defend them well. Every possible legal angle that can be exploited to their advantage I will use.''
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Friends say they often find it difficult to tell how Mr. Puccio feels about setbacks like the loss in the Friedman case to Mr. Giuliani, a friend whose wedding he had attended. Some people who have known Mr. Puccio for years say he can be as enigmatic personally as he is professionally when he is plotting one of his courtroom strategies.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: An Enigma In Both Lives
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Over the last several years, Mr. Puccio's personal life has been filled with disruption and tragedy. Four days after he completed a bitter divorce in 1992 from his first wife, Carol L. Ziegler, the associate dean of Brooklyn Law School, Mr. Puccio remarried.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: His wife, Kathy, a former model who was the Noxzema Shave Creme Girl in commercials with Joe Namath in the 1970's, attended every day of the Alex Kelly trial. Although she had no official role in the defense team, she sat with the Kelly family and occasionally criticized reporters for coverage that she said was slanted toward the prosecution.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: She explained that she and Mr. Puccio have spent much of their time together since they met. She once accompanied him to a network television interview where she did his makeup. But Mrs. Puccio, who describes herself as a born-again Christian, said she went to the trial also because she was offended by the vindictiveness many people expressed about Mr. Kelly.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: ''My response,'' she said, ''is: Let he who is without sin cast the first stone.''
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: The Puccios live in Weston, Conn. It was near there in February 1995 that Mr. Puccio was teaching his only child, Matthew, to drive. The car went over an embankment into 15 feet of icy water in a yacht basin. Matthew died. Mr. Puccio, who was not wearing his seat belt, escaped.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: It was, Mr. Puccio said, devastating. Some of his closest friends said there were a few days when they were not sure if he would regain his equilibrium.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Kathy Puccio said that in time he returned to work with what seemed to be an even greater focus than before and it seemed to help him deal with the tragedy. ''I remember him saying, 'There are two ways to handle this and I'm not going to let it defeat me,' '' Mrs. Puccio said.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Mr. Puccio was already handling Mr. Kelly's rape case at the time of the accident. As he pressed on with the case, some of his friends said, he seemed even more intense than before about winning.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: Mr. Puccio said work helped him live through something it is not possible to get over. He said he would probably have represented Alex Kelly the same way even if he had not suffered his own loss. But, he said, there was a special bond with Mr. Kelly's parents that may be spurring him on to try to win.
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: ''I can relate,'' Mr. Puccio said, ''to them trying to save their son.''
title: Thomas Puccio Rattles It and Uses It in Representing Defendants

text: After James McIntyre, a starter on the New Mexico State football team, was charged with raping two students last summer, the head coach suspended him. But the athletic department decided to honor his scholarship pending trial. He was allowed to stay on campus, although he had previously been convicted of disorderly conduct after a skirmish with the campus police, and had been the subject of several sexual-harassment complaints.
title: Colleges Protect Athletes, Not Students

text: The case was hardly unusual. In 1995 alone, 220 student athletes were in court on charges from illegal gambling to manslaughter. Over the last two years, 112 college athletes have been charged with sexual assault or with abusing spouses and girlfriends; most victims were other students. A 1994 study of 10 Division I schools with powerhouse football and basketball teams found that while athletes composed just 3 percent of the male student population, they were responsible for 19 percent of the colleges' sexual assaults and 35 percent of acts of domestic violence.
title: Colleges Protect Athletes, Not Students

text: Yet these athletes almost never lose their scholarships until they are convicted. Not only do they remain a threat to other students, but because campuses are small places, victims must choose whether to leave school or to stay and likely run into their accused assailants.
title: Colleges Protect Athletes, Not Students

text: The National Collegiate Athletic Association should step in and insure that victims no longer face this dilemma and that all students are safe from out-of-control athletes. The N.C.A.A. should require colleges to revoke the scholarship of any athlete formally charged with a violent crime. Some will say this is judging people guilty until proven innocent. So what? Scholarships are a privilege, not a right. If the legal system finds probable cause to charge a person, it should be sufficient reason to get him off campus.
title: Colleges Protect Athletes, Not Students

text: True, some colleges have taken a tougher stance. Bobby Knight, Indiana University's basketball coach, kicked a point guard off the team last season after the player was arrested for allegedly assaulting his girlfriend. After rape charges were dropped against five Brigham Young University football players in 1995, the university nonetheless dismissed them for violating the school's conduct code.
title: Colleges Protect Athletes, Not Students

text: But such action is the exception. In 1995 and 1996, the University of Nebraska won consecutive football championships with a starting lineup that included players charged with sexual assault, theft, assault and unlawfully firing a gun at an occupied vehicle. One reserve player had been indicted for attempted murder.
title: Colleges Protect Athletes, Not Students

text: At Virginia Tech, which will play Nebraska in this year's Orange Bowl, 18 football players have been arrested in the past year. Last week, two players were arrested for rape; one had been accused of another rape earlier this year, and the other had been arrested for assault.
title: Colleges Protect Athletes, Not Students

text: The University of Cincinnati basketball team, which began this season ranked first in the nation, has repeatedly given scholarships to blue-chip athletes with prior criminal problems. Art Long, on probation for selling marijuana when recruited, was convicted of assaulting a girlfriend while at Cincinnati. This season, a starting guard was arrested on charges of aggravated burglary.
title: Colleges Protect Athletes, Not Students

text: Colleges often justify their recruitment policies by pointing to the increasing number of young men growing up in fatherless homes surrounded by crime. Coaches who choose not to suspend defendants frequently say that the team's ''structured'' environment will help reform them. Such rationalizations are small comfort to the victims.
title: Colleges Protect Athletes, Not Students

text: In addition to requiring colleges to revoke scholarships of athletes formally charged with violent crimes, the N.C.A.A. should insist that college administrations and disciplinary boards, not coaches or athletic directors, decide whether to reinstate the scholarships if charges are dropped or if players are found not guilty.
title: Colleges Protect Athletes, Not Students

text: Left to their own devices, colleges can't be counted on to protect students. James McIntyre was convicted of rape last month, and New Mexico State finally revoked his scholarship. Had the university belatedly found its conscience? Not likely. After a 1-10 season, the coach was dismissed; he is being replaced by an assistant coach from Nebraska.
title: Colleges Protect Athletes, Not Students

text: Hugging an isolated stretch of the Rio Grande along the Mexican border, Starr County has long had a reputation as a haven for smugglers. In past decades, the booty was alcohol or cattle; these days, it is drugs.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: But even as people here have become accustomed to periodic crackdowns by drug enforcement officials and arrests of local citizens, no one can quite recall a sweep of the magnitude of a recent Federal operation. In all, 79 people were arrested and charged with involvement in a marijuana-smuggling ring that Federal officials describe as a multimillion-dollar enterprise.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: Nearly all the defendants are from Starr County, which the Census routinely lists as one of the poorest in the nation, or two adjoining counties, Zapata and Hidalgo. Assets from the drug ring are said to have been plowed into several popular local businesses, including the Golden R Meat Market, a convenience store in Roma, and the Fronton Car Wash and Body Repair Shop.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: In Fronton, a farming hamlet a few miles west of Roma where a half-mile dirt road leads to the Rio Grande, 15 of the 400 residents were rounded up and sent to jail in Houston, 350 miles north. These arrests were made in a one-day sweep last month that began when Federal and state authorities set up a roadblock and checked the licenses of everyone leaving Fronton.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: The crackdown has stunned just about everyone here and left both supporters and critics of the operation fearful. Most family members and supporters of the defendants said they were afraid of retaliation by law-enforcement authorities if they spoke out against the Government's effort. And people who favor the crackdown said they feared retaliation by major drug rings based in Mexico or by the local families who they said had helped smuggle drugs for years. Many people refused to give their names when discussing the case.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: In Starr County, even those with a public profile seemed disinclined to express their opinions.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: ''If these people are guilty, then what the Government has done is a good thing,'' Judge Jose Martinez, the chief elected official of Starr County, said.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: But Mr. Martinez quickly added: ''I'd hate to think innocent people are being harassed. I have no indication one way or another.''
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: While some welcome the operation as a sign that the authorities are finally getting serious about drug smuggling, many others insist that the Government went much too far, with many innocent people swept up in its wake.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: ''This whole thing is out of control,'' said Clemente Sandoval, whose brother-in-law, Jorge Luis Garcia, a ranch hand for one of the families that has been described as ringleaders of the smuggling, was among those arrested.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: ''I just don't think Jorge was involved in this at all,'' he said. ''If he was making all this money off of drugs, why was he broke all the time? Why were they cutting off his electricity every other month?''
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: Prosecutors in the United States Attorney's office in Houston, who plan to try all 79 defendants together, said they could not discuss the specifics of Mr. Garcia's or any other defendant's case. In offering a broad outline of the charges, though, the prosecutors have said that a few local families with ranching and other business interests have for years been allowing Mexican smugglers to bring marijuana onto their land and store it there.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: Mr. Garcia, a 44-year-old father of six, is charged on a variety of counts, including conspiracy to possess with intent to distribute up to 2,200 pounds of marijuana and conspiracy to commit money laundering. Five men -- Pedro Moreno and Rudolfo Arias and three brothers, Ramiro, Ricardo and Roberto Riojas -- have been charged with engaging in a continuing criminal enterprise under what is often called the ''kingpin statute'' and could face life in prison.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: Most of the other defendants, including Mr. Garcia, are charged with abetting them. The authorities say they have seized at least 13,000 pounds of marijuana in Starr County in the last three months.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: George Garcia, 19, Mr. Garcia's son, was one of the few people willing to discuss the case. He said his family was trying to scrape together money to hire a lawyer. No one in the family has been able to travel to Houston to see Mr. Garcia, so their contact has been limited to a few brief telephone calls.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: ''Is there a drug trade here?'' said the younger Mr. Garcia, who is studying law enforcement at a community college. ''Yes, sir, right here on the river. Everyone knows that. But they've arrested a lot of innocent people, my father included.''
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: Some people here said they did not wish to speak publicly because they were angry at both the smugglers and the law-enforcement officials.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: ''There are drugs in this area, and I blame the people involved, but the people I blame most of all is the Government,'' said a man taking a pause from yardwork in front of his small house in Fronton.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: ''They knew all about it for years, and they let it get out of hand,'' the man said. ''They let sons get caught up with their fathers. They just let this go on too long.''
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: The man also expressed bitterness that the crackdown on his neighbors, some of whom he considered friends, would do ''next to nothing'' in the overall war on drugs.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: ''They're never going to get the big guy in this,'' he said. ''The big guy's in Mexico.''
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: Federal drug officials, who say the Texas-Mexico border is an increasingly important conduit for drugs from South America, do not necessarily disagree with the Fronton man's assessment.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: ''For us to have a lasting impact, no question, more must be done in Mexico,'' said Donald F. Ferrarone, special agent in charge of the Houston field division of the Drug Enforcement Administration.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: Nonetheless, Mr. Ferrarone said, while the crackdown here did little to affect the overall supply from Mexico, it did succeed in breaking ''an extremely important chain'' in the distribution network.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: At the Lamb of God Catholic mission in Fronton, the Rev. Hugo Van den Bussche declined to answer questions about the recent arrests or what they had done to the spirit of the community.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: ''I'm sorry, I never talk publicly about drugs or drug dealing,'' Father Van den Bussche said. ''I feel my place as a pastor is not to talk about it. Even in church, I never talk about drugs. Never.''
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: Especially in Fronton, a ramshackle collection of battered ranch-style houses and trailers on concrete blocks, a common refrain is that the place is so poor, the extent of the drug problem must be overstated by the Government.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: ''This is no Miami,'' said Luis Pena, owner of the Fronton Postal and Grocery, whose brother was among those arrested. ''This is no millionaire paradise. You can see the houses; you can see how the people dress.''
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: Others expressed anger that economic conditions were so bad, and said they understood, without condoning it, how people were lured into the drug trade.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: ''People are desperate,'' said Anna Sandoval, 32, a Fronton native who works as a teacher's aide. ''They have kids, they have meals to eat, they have doctors' bills to pay.''
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: Still, there are incongruous signs of wealth here, some of which, the authorities say, can be explained by drug money: new pickup trucks, satellite dishes, glimpses of impressive houses from padlocked gates.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: Mr. Pena, the store owner, said that the vast majority of people in Fronton were decent and hard working, and that the crackdown had hurt many, himself included. He said his sales, typically around $10,000 a month, had dropped by half.
title: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

text: ''Many of my customers were taken away, you see,'' he said. ''And the people that are left, they're not coming out. The town is completely dead. I guess they're worried. Or scared. Or shocked.''

text: Mexico has rebuffed a request by the United States to allow American drug agents to carry sidearms for their own protection inside Mexico and to have full diplomatic immunity, United States and Mexican officials say.
title: Mexico Rejects U.S. Request On Sidearms for Drug Agents

text: Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, head of the Clinton Administration's anti-drug effort, raised the issue most recently in a meeting here in mid-December. Mexican officials refused to approve the request, but indicated they would engage in further talks on the issue.
title: Mexico Rejects U.S. Request On Sidearms for Drug Agents

text: ''We can't authorize it,'' said the Mexican Attorney General, Jorge Madrazo Cuellar. He said having armed agents of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration in Mexico would be ''a complete break'' with the 1992 agreement that governs the role of the agents.
title: Mexico Rejects U.S. Request On Sidearms for Drug Agents

text: Mexico said it would allow D.E.A. agents to carry arms in Mexico only if Mexican anti-drug police are given the same privilege in the United States, a Mexican official said.
title: Mexico Rejects U.S. Request On Sidearms for Drug Agents

text: Since General McCaffrey took charge of drug policy in early 1996 he has gone out of his way to applaud Mexico for its enforcement efforts, generating unusually warm relations between the countries on drug issues. Because of improved cooperation, Mexico eradicated large areas of heroin poppies and marijuana crops and reduced flights of large cargo jets carrying drugs over Mexico.
title: Mexico Rejects U.S. Request On Sidearms for Drug Agents

text: But the two sides have made no progress on the status of D.E.A. agents.
title: Mexico Rejects U.S. Request On Sidearms for Drug Agents

text: The issue is delicate for Mexico, which is reluctant to make concessions to the United States that seem to compromise its sovereignty. The American request is especially sensitive for President Ernesto Zedillo because of elections scheduled for July 1997 in which his party will battle for control of the national Congress with opposition groups who have criticized him for yielding too much to the United States.
title: Mexico Rejects U.S. Request On Sidearms for Drug Agents

text: But American officials feel strongly as well. Although the search for better protection dates back years, the United States' concern increased after a joint task force was created in 1995 to coordinate anti-drug operations along the border.
title: Mexico Rejects U.S. Request On Sidearms for Drug Agents

text: Some 18 American agents from the Drug Enforcement Administration, Customs and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are based in the United States but move frequently across the border to work with counterparts in Mexico. They go unarmed and are not officially shielded by standard diplomatic immunities from local arrest and prosecution.
title: Mexico Rejects U.S. Request On Sidearms for Drug Agents

text: In the last eight months, death threats against Mexican and American drug agents in the border area have increased to the point of alarm, an American official said. Six Mexican agents from Tijuana, the city just south of the border from San Diego, were killed in 1996.

text: Three men were charged with murder yesterday in the shooting deaths of an off-duty police officer and a Queens businessman last week. The arrests, which came after one suspect was picked up on a minor drug charge, were hailed by Police Commissioner Howard Safir as an especially gratifying example of how the city's crackdown on ''quality of life'' crimes can lead to major arrests.
title: 3 Charged in Killings of Officer and Businessman in Queens

text: ''This case was solved based on a minor arrest, which we constantly talk about,'' Mr. Safir said, ''paying attention to small crimes and you solve big crimes. This is a perfect example of it.''
title: 3 Charged in Killings of Officer and Businessman in Queens

text: Many folks are wondering why a generation exposed to an unprecedented barrage of anti-drug messages has nonetheless stepped up its use of alcohol and other drugs (news article, Dec. 20). A recent comment by Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the White House director of national drug policy, might give us a hint. He said that, despite parents' own youthful drug peccadillos, their message to youngsters should be ''unambiguous: zero tolerance.''
title: Zero Tolerance on Drugs Sends Wrong Message

text: But the human use of mind-altering substances is complex and rife with ambiguities: consider cancer patients using marijuana, junkies holding jobs, Native Americans using sacred peyote. The lure of innocent pleasure co-exists with the threat of addiction, the promise of spiritual enlightenment and the urgency of relieving pain. Unambiguous drug education denies these complexities. To succeed, drug education must deal honestly with them.
title: Zero Tolerance on Drugs Sends Wrong Message

text: The use of illegal drugs by adolescents continued to rise this year, raising fresh questions about the effectiveness of drug prevention programs for schoolchildren.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: In the latest national survey, released yesterday, 40 percent of high seniors interviewed said they had used illegal drugs in the past year, compared with 39 percent from a survey in 1995. Half said they had tried drugs at some time in their lives and nearly a quarter said they had done so in the past month.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: The number of high school sophomores who said they had used drugs in the past year rose to 37.5 percent this year, from 33.3 percent in 1995. Among eighth graders, the number climbed to 23.6 percent, from 21.4 percent, confirming that experimentation is beginning at a younger age.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: Marijuana accounts for nearly 90 percent of such drug use, but alcohol is still much more widely used by teen-agers than illegal drugs, according to the review, the annual Monitoring the Future Survey.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: Announcing the findings at a news conference in Washington, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala, said, ''The survey tells us that drug use among young people is at unacceptable levels, that the core of the problem is marijuana and that we must fight aggressively to change these trends.''
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the White House's director of national drug policy, described the survey's findings as ''a disaster'' and said drug use would worsen before it slowed down and reversed.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: ''We have not adequately taken a new generation and educated them about the dangers of drug abuse,'' General McCaffrey said later in an interview. The Government would spend more on drug prevention and education over the next five years, he said.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: Lloyd D. Johnston, the principal investigator for the annual survey, which is conducted by the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research, also took a pessimistic view.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: ''We're clearly moving in the wrong direction and continuing to do so,'' Dr. Johnston said.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: He expressed particular concern about the daily use of marijuana. Nearly 5 percent of high school seniors admitted smoking marijuana every day, compared with only 2 percent four years ago.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: But marijuana has not returned to its greatest level of popularity, in 1978, when half of high school seniors said they had used it in the previous year, and 11 percent said they did so daily. This year, 35.8 percent of seniors admitted smoking marijuana in the last 12 months, as did 33.6 percent of high school sophomores and 18.3 percent of eighth graders.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: Mitchell Rosenthal, an addiction psychiatrist who heads Phoenix House, a network of drug treatment facilities, said the surge in marijuana use by 8th- and 10th-grade students was especially alarming. The younger the drug user, Dr. Rosenthal said, the more harm there is to his or her development. He said those younger users would be more likely to try other drugs in a few years.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: Dr. Johnston, a social psychologist, attributed increased drug use among teen-agers to what he called ''generational forgetting.'' When drug use declines, as it did in the 1980's, he said, young people do not witness its consequences as much.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: ''It's a form of informal learning, and that, I think, has diminished substantially,'' he said. ''When informal learning declines, formal learning must take its place.''
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: The survey did find more cautiousness about harder drugs. Use of cocaine among seniors surveyed rose to 4.9 percent this year, from 4 percent in 1995. Only 1 percent admitted using heroin in the previous year.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: The survey, which receives financing from the National Institute on Drug Abuse, is considered the most reliable gauge of teen-age drug use because it is based on questionnaires completed anonymously by 49,000 students at 435 public and private schools, rather than at home, where their parents are.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: David L. Rosenbloom, the director of Join Together, a coalition of community organizations fighting substance abuse, observed that the survey also showed that the majority of children are not using marijuana or other drugs, and that alcohol and tobacco pose more serious problems.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: Among seniors, 72.5 percent reported drinking alcohol in the last year, and 51.9 percent said they had been drunk. Forty percent of 10th graders and nearly 20 percent of 8th graders also reported having been drunk. Even so, the numbers were slightly lower than last year's.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: ''We can turn all of these around by giving young people consistent and repeated messages from parents, schools and the media about the risks of these substances to their health and future,'' Mr. Rosenbloom said. Such messages, he said, were not consistently delivered.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: Joel Brown, an educational consultant in Berkeley, Calif. who studied drug education programs in California schools, said that teen-agers there were turned off by ''just say no'' programs that maintained that any use of drugs or alcohol was wrong and that users should be punished. ''Many times, the kids are more sophisticated than the teachers,'' Mr. Brown said.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: But a critic of traditional drug policies said the survey proved they have not worked.
title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise

text: Arnold S. Trebach, president of the Drug Policy Foundation, which advocates more lenient drug laws, said: ''It is no surprise that marijuana is easy for young people to buy when that drug's market is completely unregulated.''
