text: A GIVER'S AGENDA: A special report.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: At the peak of a storm last February, several of the nation's most gifted philosophers and political scientists met for a weekend at the Westchester County estate of George Soros, the Hungarian-born billionaire financier. As the wind rattled the windows, Mr. Soros raised a glass in honor of his guests and gave them a challenge: if they were to advise him on how to spend more money each year than the Ford Foundation does on philanthropy, much of it in the United States, what would they suggest?
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: ''It was an astonishing session, as well as the most expensive philosophical tutorial anyone has ever had,'' said Alan Ryan, at the time a professor at Princeton and now the warden of New College at Oxford.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: The philosophers' weekend debate, one of several ''Soros retreats,'' as one participant called them, was pivotal in shaping the latest phase of Mr. Soros's extraordinary philanthropic career. For after spending $1.1 billion, most of it since 1989 trying to transform the former Soviet bloc into thriving capitalist democracies, or what he calls ''open societies,'' Mr. Soros, deeply concerned that America's own open society is eroding, is bringing his philanthropy home. Along the way he is shaking up the philanthropic world.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: A man who often seems to donate millions on impulse, Mr. Soros plans to devote half his annual giving -- more than $350 million last year, almost all of it overseas -- to five domestic issues: immigrants' rights, death and dying, drugs, education and criminal justice. While other foundations and philanthropists are more comfortable healing the sick, housing the poor or feeding the hungry, Mr. Soros is unabashed in pursuing a political agenda.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Almost singlehandedly, for instance, Mr. Soros financed successful ballot initiatives this fall in Arizona and California to permit the use of marijuana for medical purposes. The support brought furious criticism from many conservatives, government officials and drug experts, who called it an arrogant social experiment that they fear is a disastrous first step toward full legalization of marijuana and other drugs.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: But Mr. Soros, who amassed most of his net worth of $2 billion by taking huge risks in the currency and other financial markets, is undaunted by any fury. He says the philosophers' weekend reinforced his determination to greatly increase his domestic giving -- since 1994, he has committed $90 million -- out of concern that the conservative drift in the United States has bred indifference to genocide abroad and to suffering and injustice at home.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: ''The core of an open society is under attack in our laissez-faire society,'' Mr. Soros said in an interview, adding that he wanted to foster debate about divisive issues.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: His giving has inspired comparisons to an earlier age.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: ''George Soros is the only American who rivals the great philanthropists of the 1890's, John D. Rockefeller Sr., Andrew Carnegie and Julius Rosenwald,'' said Nelson Aldrich Jr., the editor of The American Benefactor, a quarterly, and who is himself a cousin of the Rockefellers.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Alfred Stepan, who helped found the Central European University, a $55 million Soros project in Budapest, noted the scale of Mr. Soros's philanthropy. ''If you rank a donor by assets, Soros is nothing,'' said Mr. Stepan, a fellow at All Souls College at Oxford. the Ford Foundation, for example, which committed $342 million in 1996, has assets estimated at $8 billion. But, Mr. Stepan added, ''if you measure it by dispensed gifts, especially in proportion to income, Soros is the world's single largest donor, individual or foundation.''
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: More than sheer numbers make Mr. Soros stand out, however.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: ''Soros is successful because his giving is openly political and daring,'' said David Rieff, a writer who serves on one of Mr. Soros's boards. ''He is determined to use his money to change the nation's social agenda and is tough-minded about achieving his goals.''
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Mr. Soros, 66, never tires of expounding, in his Hungarian accent, often arcane theories about how the world works -- a ''failed philosopher,'' he calls himself. He studied under Sir Karl Popper, whose critique of Marx and other proponents of historical determinism, expounded in the book ''The Open Society and Its Enemies,'' deeply influenced his thinking. Of slight build, well tanned, with wire-rimmed glasses and expensive suit, Mr. Soros would not stand out in a room of multimillionaires as a multibillionaire.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: There is only a hint in his deliberately calm tone of the toughness of someone who escaped the Nazis as a Jewish adolescent in Budapest and immigrated to the United States in 1956 to found an off-shore investment fund known today for its financial brinkmanship and unparalleled success. Having ''broken'' the Bank of England in 1992 by betting that Britain would devalue the pound, Mr. Soros exudes confidence -- arrogance, some detractors call it -- a quiet certainty that his self-made wealth makes him worthy of being listened to.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: None of his giving has created more fury than his support for a new approach to drug policy. Conservative critics say that in the guise of fostering debate about politically charged issues, Mr. Soros is trying to impose his liberal and misguided policy agenda on an unwitting public.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Public records show that since 1993 he has donated some $15 million to foundations and groups that favor changing the nation's drug policies. Ethan A. Nadelmann, head of the Lindesmith Center, a New York City institute founded in 1994 with Mr. Soros's money and budgeted for $828,000 in 1996, has called for legalization of marijuana and other drugs.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: In addition to this charitable, or tax-exempt, support, he donated more than $1 million to the ground-breaking state ballot initiatives on drug laws in California and Arizona, contributions that are not tax deductible. Both measures were overwhelmingly approved by voters in November.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: California's new law allows marijuana to be grown and used by anyone, even a minor, with an oral recommendation from a doctor to treat ''any other illness for which marijuana provides relief.'' Arizona's measure allows doctors to prescribe any of 117 banned drugs, including marijuana, LSD and heroin, for a ''seriously ill or terminally ill patient.'' It also releases prisoners serving time for personal possession of drugs.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: ''Neither initiative would have made it on the ballot were it not for George Soros,'' said Stu Mollrich, a consultant to the California measure's opponents. Three former Presidents, senior Clinton Administration officials, state law-enforcement officials and prominent drug and medical experts opposed one or both measures.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: But Mr. Soros expresses no regrets and says he is ready to support similar initiatives in other states. Denying that he favors across-the-board legalization of drugs, he says he supports ''rational debate'' about what constitutes a ''saner drug policy.'' Since a drug-free America ''is an unattainable dream, our policy should aim at reducing harm connected with drugs.'' Specifically, that means ''saving our jails for violent criminals and predatory drug dealers, not nonviolent drug addicts willing to undergo treatment or the occasional marijuana smoker,'' he said.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: That has not persuaded some drug-policy experts, who said Mr. Soros had given money not for debate, but to weaken drug laws.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Herbert D. Kleber, vice president of the National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, said that while Mr. Soros was ''playing around'' with the idea of legalization of drugs, ''people will die from it.''
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Mr. Soros dismisses such criticism, arguing that drug policy is surrounded by ''hysteria, passion and extremism.'' When it comes to drugs, he said, ''even our politicians have become extremists by trying to cater to popular sentiment which has been whipped up and exploited for political purposes.''
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Mr. Rieff, the writer, said that Mr. Soros's lifetime of struggle against often deadly adversaries had made him impervious to such attacks. ''If you've fled the Nazis, fought the Communists and battled your way to the top of the West's financial markets, a nasty column about you in a newspaper is no big deal,'' Mr. Rieff said.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Aryeh Neier, the human rights advocate who is Mr. Soros's closest adviser and president of the Open Society Institute, the nonprofit foundation that supervises much of Mr. Soros's domestic giving, attributed Mr. Soros's shift in focus partly to his dismay at America's failure to ''seize the revolutionary moment'' offered by the fall of the Berlin Wall and collapse of the Soviet Union -- he felt the country should have poured money into supporting democratic impulses in the former dictatorships, Mr. Neier said. Then came the genocide in Yugoslavia, with a belated American response. (Mr. Soros gave $50 million in late 1992 to help alleviate the suffering of Bosnia's tormented civilian population.)
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Mr. Soros was further ''repulsed,'' Mr. Neier added, by the ''Gingrich revolution,'' the triumph of conservative Republicans in the 1994 Congressional races, which symbolized for Mr. Soros the state's abandonment of its obligations to citizens, particularly the poor and immigrants. And finally, Mr. Soros said, he was worried about the extent to which ''market values and excessive individualism'' were permeating the professions of medicine, law, journalism and politics, turning them into businesses rather than callings.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Mr. Soros has shown little interest in achieving political change through traditional channels. He gives relatively little, by his standards, to candidates or major parties. His largest contribution this year was $100,000 to the Democratic National Committee, plus a total of $5,000 to three Senate candidates and $500 each to 25 Congressional candidates, mostly Democrats and a few liberal Republicans.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Nor does he assume that his giving will insure political influence. ''I can already see the President if I want to,'' he said.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Rather, Mr. Soros, like most philanthropists, seems to know that his charitable contributions can provide even greater prominence and control.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Yet although he has written that he indulges his ''messianic fantasies'' through his giving, he is shrewd and sensitive enough to the rules of democracy not to try to impose his views directly. Instead, he uses his money to foster debate about his agenda, hoping that an educated public will agree with him.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: So Mr. Soros, advised by Mr. Neier and Gara LaMarche, both veterans of the Human Rights Watch organization, directs his spending to wide-ranging grass-roots projects that he hopes will help transform the nation's political culture and protect Americans from what he calls ''unintended consequences'' of bad government policy. There is variety in subject and amount:
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: *A $50 million commitment to the Emma Lazarus Fund, a project started in September to help legal immigrants attain full participation in American society. Mr. Soros described the grant as a spontaneous response to his ''outrage,'' as an immigrant, over the recent law denying legal immigrants several types of public assistance and benefits.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: *A $15 million commitment for three years to the Project on Death in America. The effort, headed by Kathleen M. Foley, a doctor and senior pain specialist at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, supports projects that enhance comfort, dignity, care and relief from pain for the dying. Mr. Soros says he is trying to end America's ''denial of death.''
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: *A $12 million commitment over three years to the Algebra Project, which seeks to improve mathematics skills of rural and inner-city public school students throughout the country.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: *The creation last spring of the Center on Crime, Communities and Culture, headed by Nancy Mahon, an expert on prisons. She has already awarded $1.4 million in grants to more than two dozen groups to support projects like prison guard training and research on how film and television affect individual and community perceptions of crime.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: The Open Society Institute board approved in principal over the weekend $7 million more for criminal justice as part of $50 million in new pledges for 1997. Mr. Soros's domestic giving is increasing exponentially, from $15 million this year to what Mr. Soros says will eventually be more than $100 million a year. Until recently, less than 10 percent of his annual giving was spent domestically.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Too Restless To See It Through?
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Few grant-makers challenge the unorthodox nature of some of Mr. Soros's giving or his usual lack of support for either Jewish causes or traditional philanthropy. But some critics wonder whether he can sustain his interest in a domestic agenda.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: A fellow foundation director remarked on Mr. Soros's intellectual restlessness. ''He focuses on something and then moves on,'' said the grant-maker, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ''And he likes to see results quickly. He has now chosen areas where it's hard to see results quickly. Does he have the staying power?''
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Mr. Soros says he does. As evidence, he points to what foundation officers call the ''professionalization'' of his giving, or its institutionalization. Last year, for example, Mr. Soros published the first comprehensive annual report on his foundations' projects. Mr. Neier and Mr. LaMarche, both highly regarded professionals in the foundation community, have insisted on strict budgets and project evaluations.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: ''Soros has not surrounded himself with yes men,'' Mr. Rieff said. ''They talk back; they disagree. And they are running the projects, not George.''
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: His failures abroad also reinforced the need for more structure and accountability, he and his associates say. His Russian foundation, for example, has undergone three reorganizations since Mr. Soros learned that much of its budget was diverted into Swiss bank accounts and luxury cars.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: The new emphasis on American philanthropy has resulted in an expansion of the Open Society Institute's American staff, to more than 160 employees today from 64 in 1994. But the staff is still lean by foundation standards, and its members are not as well paid as their philanthropic counterparts. The foundations' offices on 57th Street overlooking Central Park and Carnegie Hall -- in the same building as Mr. Soros's business offices -- are spare.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: ''Why would we take pay cuts and smaller offices to come to work for a billionaire?'' Mr. LaMarche said. ''Because of the chance to do truly creative, risky giving.''
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Some question whether Mr. Soros, whose charity finances 50 offices and employs more than 1,000 people worldwide, is starting up too quickly and spreading himself too thin. That is a concern, Mr. LaMarche conceded. ''But all these issues are interconnected and must be addressed simultaneously if we are to see results,'' Mr. LaMarche said.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: Mr. Soros hopes that his giving will prompt other foundations to support risky projects and research. He said he knew that, like some of his early projects in Eastern Europe, China and South Africa, some American projects may fail.
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: ''I don't have all the answers,'' he said. ''But I know what questions to ask. And after all, I can't take it with me.''
title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity

text: After arresting more than 70 people in the last month and confiscating assets that included ranches, vehicles and a convenience store, Federal officials say they have broken up one of the largest marijuana distribution rings operating along the Mexican border.
title: Big Marijuana Ring on Border Broken Up, Federal Officials Say

text: Concentrated in Starr County, a remote area along the Rio Grande that is often listed in census records as one of the most impoverished counties in the nation, the ring smuggled more than 100 tons of marijuana across the border over the last decade and sent it on to at least nine states, United States Attorney Gaynelle Griffin Jones said here this week in announcing a 179-count indictment. All but a handful of the 79 people named in the action have been apprehended, she said.
title: Big Marijuana Ring on Border Broken Up, Federal Officials Say

text: Lawyers for many of those arrested said the sweeping nature of the Government's arrests, in some cases involving entire families, was unwarranted.
title: Big Marijuana Ring on Border Broken Up, Federal Officials Say

text: ''Cicero said it centuries ago -- extreme justice is extreme injustice, and this epitomizes a case of extreme justice,'' said Michael J. Garza, a lawyer in McAllen, Tex., who represents Renato Riojas, one of the 79 defendants.
title: Big Marijuana Ring on Border Broken Up, Federal Officials Say

text: Another defense lawyer involved in the case, Al Alvarez, said that the consolidation of all the cases into one giant prosecution in Houston, where most of the drugs were said to have been sent before going north, would make it far more difficult for many of those charged to mount an adequate defense against the charges.
title: Big Marijuana Ring on Border Broken Up, Federal Officials Say

text: ''I think it's wrong,'' Mr. Alvarez said. ''People can't afford to have lawyers in a protracted, long trial in a distant forum.'' But Federal officials defended the approach, saying the arrests were based on intensive surveillance that included wiretaps and videotapes in some cases. They also said they had seized more than 13,000 pounds of marijuana in the last two and a half months. The crackdown on South Texas smuggling highlights what Federal officials say is the increasing importance of the Mexican border as a means of getting all kinds of drugs into the United States.
title: Big Marijuana Ring on Border Broken Up, Federal Officials Say

text: ''In the old days, so to speak, back in the 80's, it used to come by boat,'' said Judi Lombardino, an assistant United States attorney in charge of the case. ''Now it's coming through South Texas and through Mexico.''
title: Big Marijuana Ring on Border Broken Up, Federal Officials Say

text: Donald F. Ferrarone, special agent in charge of the Houston field division of the Drug Enforcement Administration, said the South Texas ring was ''as big as any domestic marijuana operation that we have in this country.'' But, he added, it still only acted as one of many distribution conduits for a huge supply network on the Mexican side.
title: Big Marijuana Ring on Border Broken Up, Federal Officials Say

text: ''For us to really have a lasting impact, we must have and get more results on the Mexican side as well,'' Mr. Ferrarone said. ''But this is an extremely important chain in the drug trafficking overall picture as it comes out of Mexico.''
title: Big Marijuana Ring on Border Broken Up, Federal Officials Say

text: Many of the defendants face 10 years or more imprisonment while five of them, Pedro Moreno, Rudolfo Arias, and three brothers, Ramiro, Ricardo and Roberto Riojas, could face life imprisonment for running a continuing criminal enterprise under what is called the ''kingpin statute.'' Among the lesser defendants, nearly all of them from the Rio Grande Valley or the Houston area, is a sheriff's deputy in Starr County. The indictments also contend that much of the profits were laundered into real estate or business investments, including the Double R Feed and Seed in Mission, Tex., the Fronton Car Wash in Fronton, Tex., and the Golden R Meat Market, a convenience store in Fronton.

text: Joseph Chagra, a Texas lawyer who admitted his complicity in the first assassination of a Federal judge in more than a century, died last Sunday in Thomason Hospital in El Paso. He was 50.
title: Joseph Chagra, 50, Lawyer Linked to Assassination, Dies

text: His son, Joseph Jr., said Mr. Chagra's death was caused by injuries from an automobile accident on Dec. 6 that also killed two passengers.
title: Joseph Chagra, 50, Lawyer Linked to Assassination, Dies

text: Mr. Chagra returned to El Paso in 1988 from a Federal prison in Stafford, Ariz., where he had served six and a half years of a 10-year sentence for conspiracy.
title: Joseph Chagra, 50, Lawyer Linked to Assassination, Dies

text: Mr. Chagra was a pivotal figure in a dramatic 1979 murder case, and his testimony helped convict Charles Voyde Harrelson, the father of the actor Woody Harrelson, of killing Judge John H. Wood Jr., an enemy of drug traffickers.
title: Joseph Chagra, 50, Lawyer Linked to Assassination, Dies

text: ''I asked him if he was the one who murdered Judge Wood, and he said he was,'' Mr. Chagra testified in a San Antonio Federal Court.
title: Joseph Chagra, 50, Lawyer Linked to Assassination, Dies

text: On the morning of May 29, 1979, Judge Wood, 63, was slain in the driveway of his town house in San Antonio, struck in the back by a bullet from a high-powered rifle.
title: Joseph Chagra, 50, Lawyer Linked to Assassination, Dies

text: The assassination came at the height of a Justice Department campaign to slow the flow of illicit drugs across the Mexican border.
title: Joseph Chagra, 50, Lawyer Linked to Assassination, Dies

text: Almost immediately, investigators turned to Mr. Chagra's plush law offices. Mr. Chagra was one of three sons of a Lebanese rug merchant who had emigrated from Mexico to El Paso. The three had risen from an unremarkable middle-class upbringing to live among El Paso's wealthiest residents.
title: Joseph Chagra, 50, Lawyer Linked to Assassination, Dies

text: Less than a year before Judge Wood was slain, Lee Chagra, Joseph's older brother, who had defended numerous narcotics suspects in Judge Wood's court, was killed in his office by armed robbers.
title: Joseph Chagra, 50, Lawyer Linked to Assassination, Dies

title: Joseph Chagra, 50, Lawyer Linked to Assassination, Dies

text: The Chagras said they were convinced that Judge Wood, who was scheduled to preside over Jimmy's case, had a bias against them. Judge Wood denied any impropriety and refused to remove himself from the case. Jimmy's trial was scheduled to begin on the day the judge died.
title: Joseph Chagra, 50, Lawyer Linked to Assassination, Dies

title: Joseph Chagra, 50, Lawyer Linked to Assassination, Dies

title: Joseph Chagra, 50, Lawyer Linked to Assassination, Dies

text: TRAFFICKING in illegal drugs often seems to defy basic economic principles.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: When the authorities seize a trove of heroin, cocaine or marijuana, logic would dictate a predictable effect: a shortage of supply that, given constant demand, should drive up prices, perhaps beyond the reach of some prospective customers.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: Yet even after many sizeable, well-publicized seizures, the street price seldom changes. Sometimes, it even drops.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: Law-enforcement officials, who intercepted nearly 100 tons of drugs in the United States last year, argue that seizures produce other benefits. Without them, the officials say, traffickers would grow more brazen; drugs would become so plentiful that many more people, including teen-agers and younger children, would be tempted to try them. Critics of the nation's drug war say that the negligible impact on supply or price proves that seizures are largely a waste of time and money.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: Free-market theories of supply and demand seem inadequate to analyze and develop a counter-strategy against what is, at its core, a criminal activity. For one thing, it defies reliable economic analysis because so much data is incomplete. For another, as it turns out, drug seizures apparently affect warehouse inventory much more than actual street supply.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: Law enforcement officials know how much narcotics they seize. But traffickers don't report how much they manage to sneak past the police. Americans spend about $49 billion a year to buy illegal drugs, according to one estimate by the Government.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: ''The numbers are, in fact, just decorations on the policy process, rhetorical conveniences for official statements without any serious consequences,'' writes Peter Reuter, who teaches drug policy at the University of Maryland. ''Indeed, the irrelevance of the numbers is itself a condemnation of drug policy decision making.''
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: One reliable number is the Federal budget, which includes more than $15 billion this year for drug enforcement, treatment and prevention. Price also can be monitored. And frustrated investigators acknowledge that with the market glutted, many of the much-heralded drug seizures haven't seemed to affect supply.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: ''The fact that product is coming in and prices don't change means that it is still available at that level,'' said Patrick Harnett, chief of the Narcotics Division of the New York City Police Department. ''It's going to come in and it's going to come in in hundreds of different ways.''
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: So much so that traffickers may have as much trouble storing it as importing it. Investigators found a record 21.4 tons of cocaine in a warehouse in the Sylmar area of Los Angeles seven years ago. Only this month, six tons of cocaine were seized from another warehouse in Tucson, Ariz.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: ''I think there is an incredible stockpile in this country when we knock off 10 or 20 tons and the price doesn't increase,'' said Carlo Boccia, head of the Drug Enforcement Administration's operation in metropolitan New York.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: ''There's excess inventory at every stage,'' said Mark A. R. Kleiman, a specialist on drug policy at the University of California at Los Angeles. ''That inventory acts as a flywheel and reduces the impact of any shock.''
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: Moreover, he says, the authorities typically overstate the dollar value of confiscated drugs by calculating not the wholesale price, like $9,000 per pound for cocaine or $40,000 for heroin, but what the consumer might pay somewhere down the line.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: Evaluating seizures by this projected street value, Professor Kleiman said, is like estimating losses from cattle rustling according to the price of a steak in a New York restaurant. A more accurate measure would be the lower cost to the trafficker of replacing the drug, which can be less than $1,000 per pound of cocaine when it leaves Colombia.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: Professor Reuter suggested that drug syndicates build a projected loss from seizures into their budgets, just as they set aside substantial sums for bribes or drug couriers.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: Confronting a stagnant American demand for cocaine, the Cali cartel diversified in the early 1990's into home-grown heroin, which was marketed, through cocaine distributors, at discounts that undercut the price charged for Asian heroin. By last year, Colombian heroin accounted for 62 percent of the domestic seizures of heroin, compared to almost zero as recently as 1992, according to the Drug Enforcement Administration.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: Some experts speculate that cocaine prices have declined not merely because of stagnating demand but also more competition among street dealers, who have been forced to accept a smaller markup. The street price itself -- $5 for a ''nickel'' vial of crack cocaine sufficient for one mind-altering high or $10 for a ''dime'' bag of heroin for a single fix -- has stayed remarkably constant. To squeeze out more profit, dealers dilute the purity.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: Recreational demand for drugs can vary widely. But among addicts, demand becomes inelastic.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: If drugs were legalized or if there was no interdiction, air-expressing a couple of pounds of cocaine from Bogota to Miami would cost less than $100, Professor Reuter said. Instead, traffickers have to pay a smuggler $10,000 or more to provide the same service.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: ''Interdiction can claim credit for accomplishing that,'' Professor Reuter told the Senate Judiciary Committee.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: It took the smashing of the Medellin cartel in Colombia to drive up cocaine prices in 1990 before the rival Cali cartel filled the vacuum. Cocaine itself is worthless if no one wants to snort, smoke or inject it. ''You can't even patch ceilings with it,'' Mr. Boccia said.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: But the police go after drugs to catch not just the dealers, but also the suppliers' profits, piling up in soiled, crumpled dollar bills. ''When they lose money on the way back, it really hurts them because it almost made it home,'' Chief Harnett said.
title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply

text: New Coat for a Duck
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: TOM THOMAS usually paints houses. Now he has painted a duck. There isn't much difference, he said. Except that when painting a duck, ''you have to climb on its back to use the roller.''
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: The owner of Island-Wide Coating Company, Mr. Thomas, of Miller Place, recently painted the Big Duck in Flanders. White, of course. A Day-Glow yellow Big Duck would have been as popular as a pink Montauk Lighthouse. And Mr. Thomas believes in tradition. He is a third-generation painter. He is the first generation, however, to paint a fowl.
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: ''I volunteered,'' he said. ''The Big Duck is the gateway to the Hamptons. She should look nice. And she looked kind of neglected. She had mildew on her back. So I stopped into the gift store and I said I would paint the duck at no charge, if anybody was interested. The next day I got a call. They were interested.''
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: They were also in a hurry. Officials of Suffolk County and the Friends for Long Island's Heritage, which oversee the duck, wanted it painted in time for the Big Duck Lighting. You didn't know the duck was lighted each year? For some, it's as important a holiday custom as the lighting of a tree. And, usually, it's a lot more fun. Where else can you see politicians like Suffolk County Executive Robert J. Gaffney singing ''Duck the Halls'' and other duck-inspired holiday songs?
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: So Mr. Thomas had his work to do. His paint was supplied free from the Sherwin Williams store in Riverhead. He figured it would be about a seven-gallon duck. ''First we had to prepare the duck,'' he said. ''We washed her down with Clorox.'' Mr. Thomas has decided the Big Duck is a she, ''although it's kind of hard to tell,'' he said. ''She is at ground level.''
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: After painting the body using spray and a roller, it was time to paint the beak, a bright orange. ''That was the trickiest,'' he said. ''I leaned the ladder on the neck. All I could think of is, 'If I break this beak they'll lynch me.' I also painted her eyes black. Well around the eyes. Her eyes are actually tail lights, you know.''
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: Car drivers did double-takes as Mr. Thomas worked feverishly. It's not every day one sees a man astride a duck. But he made the deadline. Last week the duck, with its new coat of white, was lighted. ''They put a little sign in front of it thanking me for painting the duck,'' he said. ''That was real nice.'' And so it seems is Mr. Thomas, who may epitomize the holiday season. ''It's fulfilling to do for others,'' he said. Painting a duck is one thing, he said, ''But what I would really like to do is find a little old lady who needs her house painted. I'd do it for nothing, and that would make me very happy.''
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: Platinum was hot in Huntington last week, and that meant so was security. With the Platinum Guild International selecting Freedman Jewelers as the site for a platinum convention, security was tight on Route 110. ''The guards are all around but you won't see them,'' Jack Mizrachi of Freedman said. ''They are out on the street looking like Huntingtoners.''
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: Just what a typical Huntington resident looked like made for an interesting street scene. Was that man in the Dallas Cowboys jacket armed, or just tired of the New York Jets? And was that really a gyro a man was holding as he looked out the window from the Skorpios Mediterranean cafe?
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: Besides guards there were 12 video cameras. ''Platinum is the most precious metal,'' Eric Freedman said. And therefore the most expensive. And what good is platinum without precious gems to adorn it? ''There's nothing better to cradle diamonds,'' Mr. Mizrachi said, holding up a $30,000 bracelet. ''Diamonds are white and so is platinum.''
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: For many years people used white gold as their white metal. Platinum was popular before World War II. During the war it was needed for war materials, so it was banned for jewelry. Later it was out of fashion. But in the 90's platinum is back. ''The real revolution started about five years ago,'' said Andrew Meyer, a platinum jewelry-designer from Philadelphia. Tom Heyman of Oscar Heyman and Brothers, one of the most prestigious jewelry companies in the world, said ''gold is very nice; but if you want a really elegant piece of jewelry, you want platinum.''
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: Amy Levin of Woodbury wanted to be elegant, she said. She was looking to have a platinum bracelet made. Mariana Fidalgo had on a platinum necklace, but only temporarily. Miss Fidalgo, 20, usually works in a clothing store down the street from Freedman's. The other night she was modeling a $26,000 necklace. Among those admiring it was a shopper, Ruth Gehnrich of Huntington. ''We were at Tiffany's yesterday,'' Mrs. Gehnrich said. ''But we prefer buying local.'' Mrs. Gehnrich's wedding rings were platinum. ''But I was only married 10 years ago,'' she said ''My husband Herman was ahead of his time.''
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: Platinum may be in, but the owner of Freedman's wasn't wearing any. What was that bracelet on Mr. Freedman's wrist? ''It's an old I.D. bracelet,'' he said. ''My Uncle Ernie gave it to me for my bar mitzvah. I haven't taken it off in 37 years.''
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: When Howard A. Glickstein recently marked his 10th year as dean of the Touro Law School in Huntington, among those offering their congratulations was the Nassau County Bar Association. Knowing of Dean Glickstein's fondness for fine wine, the association presented him with several, including a 1993 Chateau Mouton Rothschild. Each year the label for the wine carries a specially designed work by artists like Salvador Dali and Marc Chagall. The 1993 label was done by the French artist Balthus, who loves to paint nudes. But the nude woman he painted for 1993 was censored on the bottles shipped to the United States. Thus Mr. Glickstein received a bottle with a blank label. Ever the purist, he searched out a bottle with the nude. ''It cost me $100,'' he said. ''Without her, it's a $60 bottle.'' But he will be seeing her for some time. ''I won't open the bottle for 20 years,'' he said. . . Someone has been censoring signs in the Springs, a community in the Town of East Hampton. Most residents call the community simply Springs. So when three new ''Welcome to the Springs,'' signs went up, someone took exception. He, she, or perhaps they, used black paint to omit the ''the'' on two of the signs. The third sign wasn't defaced because it had already been mowed down by a car.
title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

text: Susanna C. is not sure exactly how it happened. She was 17, living with her boyfriend at his aunt's home. And she was high on marijuana. It was not the first time she had used drugs, and it would not be the last. But this time was different.
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: ''I came home from work,'' she said. ''I was tired. I don't remember smoking anything. I must have blocked it out. I still try to remember to this day.
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: ''I don't know what they put in that reefer, but later, I freaked out. I sat up in bed, and the bed was caving in under me. I was shaking. I kept on hearing voices. My boyfriend looked like Frankenstein. I started hallucinating. I felt horrible.''
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: The marijuana Susanna smoked that night was laced with LSD, which triggered schizophrenia. She now relies on daily medication to keep the demons out of her head. She has been in psychiatric hospitals, in homeless shelters and on the streets. These are some of her stories:
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: She can remember a time when she was 18. She had moved back in with her mother and was watching television in the living room. Her stepfather was in the bedroom; he beckoned her in.
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: ''I go in the room,'' she recalled. ''He pushed me on the floor.''
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: Susanna's sister came home just in time. Too scared to speak to her mother about the thwarted sexual assault, Susanna wrote her a letter. That day, Susanna's stepfather was kicked out, and so was Susanna.
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: She lived on the streets, begging for money. The Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan was her bedroom, and cocaine became a blanket that comforted her.
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: Susanna, now 34, has also endured a miscarriage and a tubal pregnancy. She has been in a tangled web of relationships tainted with domestic violence and drug abuse. One night, she tried to hang herself at Kingsboro Psychiatric Center in Brooklyn.
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: One of her most haunting memories is of her grandmother's funeral.
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: ''I stare at my grandmother's casket,'' she said. ''I look at her, and it looks like she's crying to get up out of there. I wasn't ready for this. I didn't know that once you die, that's not you anymore. All I know is that I saw my grandmother lying there, looking like she wanted someone to help her get out of that casket, and it freaked me out. I started crying.''
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: Far more frightening was a night Susanna spent in a homeless shelter. Her medication had run out. She remembers thinking of her grandmother and beginning to hallucinate. She thought she heard a hearse outside.
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: ''I heard the car door slam, pow!'' she said. ''I said, 'Uh-oh, they must be coming to get me.' I heard something like wheels coming down the hall, I thought that was my casket. Someone was coming to get me.''
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: Susanna said she had not known what would happen if she stopped taking her medication; she learned that the hard way.
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: Today, Susanna works part time greeting customers at a Gap clothing store in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. She found the job with the help of the Metro Club, a psychiatric rehabilitation program run by the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The Times pays all administrative costs of the fund's annual appeal, so donations go directly to helping people like Susanna.
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: At the Metro Club, Susanna helps in the kitchen, is head of the maintenance unit and often helps with clerical work. Sha'Wanda Manuel, Susanna's case manager at the Metro Club, said she had seen Susanna do a complete turnaround, from being isolated and curt to being open and kind. Susanna has learned to understand her illness, Ms. Manuel said, and she no longer blames only herself for her troubled past.
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: But the memory of hardship will never leave her.
title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence

text: Jonathan Larson, who created the hit rock opera ''Rent,'' died as he was about to achieve success. Following is an account of the last days of his life and the first days of his production, assembled from the accounts of co-workers (in italic print) and from a New York State Department of Health case report released yesterday.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: At the New York Theater Workshop between the Bowery and Second Avenue in the East Village, ''Rent'' is in the final, frantic days of rehearsal before previews begin. In theater terminology, the period is ''10-out-of-12 days,'' when the actors may be kept at work for 10 hours out of a maximum of 12. At the New York Theater Workshop, this is a day when lighting, sound, costumes, props, sets are being integrated into the production.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: 6:30 P.M.: Cast and crew return after a dinner break to continue rehearsing the second act. The song ''Seasons of Love'' is being heard through the sound system for the first time. Jonathan Larson, who is seeing his musical -- a contemporary American version of the Puccini opera ''La Boheme'' -- come to life seven years after it was conceived, is not feeling well and nearly collapses backstage.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: 6:45 P.M.: Mr. Larson is taken by ambulance to the Cabrini Medical Center emergency room at 227 East 19th Street. After eating dinner and reportedly smoking a small amount of marijuana, he had complained of severe chest pain, shortness of breath and dizziness. A friend remembers him saying, ''My chest is killing me.'' Paramedics make a presumptive diagnosis: ''pleuritic chest pain,'' pain worsened by breathing.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: 7 P.M.: An emergency room physician takes and reviews an electrocardiogram. A second emergency room physician examines Mr. Larson. In his notes, he says, ''no cardiac disease . . . just finished producing a play . . . increased stress.'' X-rays are taken.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: 8 P.M.: Mr. Larson complains of dizziness and shortness of breath. A nurse's notes report him saying, ''I can't take a breath.'' A friend asks the doctor about Mr. Larson's condition and says he is told: ''I can't find anything wrong. You'll be out of here in one hour since I want to pump his stomach.'' Mr. Larson is given pain medication. Food is drained from his stomach.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: 10:15 P.M.: Mr. Larson is given 50 grains of charcoal to absorb toxins. He is instructed to take a bland diet for 24 hours and told to return to the emergency room if necessary. He returns home.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: In the morning, a radiologist at Cabrini reviews the chest X-rays, which he says are accompanied by paperwork that lists ''pain'' under a heading of clinical history. He finds the X-rays normal. Mr. Larson's roommate says he continues to feel discomfort.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: In the theater, Monday is traditionally a day off, but some of the technical staff is working on ''Rent.'' Around the New York Theater Workshop, the feeling is that it is a good thing Mr. Larson can stay home and rest.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: Early afternoon: James C. Nicola, the artistic director of the workshop, speaks to Mr. Larson by phone. Mr. Larson seems better.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: 1 P.M.: Another 10-out-of-12 day. Technical rehearsals resume.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: 4 or 4:30 P.M.: In a phone conversation, Mr. Larson tells Mr. Nicola that doctors have told him he has a virus or a flu, and that he should stay home.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: About 11 P.M.: Mr. Larson is taken by a friend to the emergency room at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center, at Seventh Avenue and West 11th Street in Greenwich Village, after complaining of ''not feeling right,'' a low-grade fever and chest pain. A triage nurse documents his chief complaint as ''right chest pain.''
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: The nurse notes that the patient describes the pain as possible heartburn and says he was seen at Cabrini for the same symptoms two nights earlier. The patient rates the severity of the pain at 7 on a scale of 10. The nurse classifies the case as urgent, but does not speak with a physician about the vital-sign readings.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: 12:40 A.M.: Mr. Larson is seen by an emergency room physician. The physician notes that the patient complains of ''sharp inspiratory right-sided chest pain.'' A chest X-ray and electrocardiogram are ordered. The physician interprets the chest X-rays and EKG as normal. Mr. Larson's condition is diagnosed as viral syndrome and he is discharged in ''improved'' condition.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: During the cab ride home, Mr. Larson complains of pain and tightness in the chest. ''Nothing has changed,'' he is reported to have said. He arrives home in the early morning hours. Later in the morning, a radiologist at St. Vincent's interprets the X-rays as essentially normal. He reports: ''Heart size is at upper limit of normal.'' He does not find any problem that requires a recall of the patient. A cardiologist reads the EKG and indicates a question of myocardial infarction, a heart attack. There is no evidence of any follow-up.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: Mr. Larson tells his father he still has chest pain, pain in his lower back and low-grade fever.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: 7:30 P.M.: Mr. Larson, looking pale and exhausted, arrives at the theater.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: 8 P.M.: At the 150-seat theater, the curtain rises on the first complete performance ever of ''Rent.''
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: Midnight: In an interview with a New York Times reporter, he speaks of his need to respond in some way to his friends coping with AIDS and to celebrate the lives of people who have died young.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: 12:10 A.M.: His interview completed, Mr. Larson drops in on a production meeting at the theater.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: 12:30 A.M.: Looking pale and exhausted, Mr. Larson leaves the theater in a cab, planning to meet with Mr. Nicola and Michael Greif, the show's director, at 9 A.M. at the Time Cafe at Lafayette and Third Streets.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: After 12:30 A.M.: Mr. Larson arrives home.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: 1 or 1:30 A.M.: At the theater, the production meeting ends.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: About 3:30 A.M.: Mr. Larson's roommate arrives home. Mr. Larson is lying on the kitchen floor. He is unresponsive. 911 is called. Emergency Medical Service responds. Mr. Larson is declared dead. He is 35 years old. His body is removed later by the Medical Examiner's office.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: Noon: The first preview of ''Rent'' is canceled after news of Mr. Larson's death reaches the theater.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: An autopsy is performed. The cause of death is listed as ''aortic dissection due to cystic medial degeneration of unknown etiology'' -- a tear in the body's main blood vessel. Toxicology results are negative for all substances.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: 8 p.m. The curtain rises on the first preview.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: Glowing reviews begin to appear. The six-week run sells out immediately. In the months to come, ''Rent'' will move to Broadway. The show will win four Tony awards, including the prize for best musical, and Jonathan Larson will win the Pulitzer Prize for drama, posthumously.
title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death

text: New shop owners have a rule of thumb: Open around Thanksgiving, and by Christmas you could reap 25 percent of the year's gross sales. Perhaps that's why four home stores chose this season to debut.
title: Hemp Gets Cinderella Treatment

text: WILL civilization ruin hemp? The weed formerly known as cannabis sativa has achieved elegant status at Planet Hemp, at 423 Broome Street (near Crosby Street), which features home furnishings made of hemp fiber.
title: Hemp Gets Cinderella Treatment

text: Two of its owners are Laura Weymouth and John Howell, who is the chief executive of the Hemp Company, a Manhattan concern that promotes hemp products.
title: Hemp Gets Cinderella Treatment

title: Hemp Gets Cinderella Treatment

text: Jennifer M. did not drink much in the mornings, maybe a swig of vodka at home or a beer on her way to school, just enough to make a teen-age alcoholic feel that she could face the day.
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: ''I'd wake up in the morning, I'd be depressed,'' said Jennifer, who is 17. ''I couldn't even go to school unless I had a drink.''
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: She started drinking when she was in ninth grade, on scholarship at a prestigious preparatory school in Brooklyn.
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: ''It was more of a party thing,'' she said. ''We were 14. We were young. It was fun. Let's go get beer. Then I started doing it myself. The 10th and 11th grades were a blur to me.''
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: She hid bottles in her bedroom and scrounged for money to buy more.
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: The drinking led to a suicide attempt in April.
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: ''There was nothing to drink and everything was closed,'' she said. ''It was a Saturday night, 1 A.M. I just came home from being with my friends. I don't know if I was thinking, 'Let me die.' I just wanted to go to sleep. I just didn't want to be there anymore.'' She took painkillers, allergy medicine, whatever she could find.
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: Jennifer's mother, Susan, took her to a hospital and sought counseling from the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, an affiliate of the UJA-Federation, one of seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. But Susan never noticed that Jennifer was helping to empty the bottles in her liquor closet.
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: Susan, a single parent since Jennifer was 10 months old, had problems of her own. After losing the job she had had for nine years running a pediatrician's office, she took a lower-paying job at an eye-care center. She lost her health insurance and had a hard time paying the bills. When Jennifer failed to come home one night, Susan found out about the drinking.
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: ''That night I told my mother,'' Jennifer said. ''We were in the living room. She was crying and saying, 'Why are you doing this to me?' I just came out and told her, 'Ma, I have a drinking problem.' I knew she believed me, but I don't think she knew how serious I was.''
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: Susan took Jennifer to Holliswood Hospital, a psychiatric hospital in Queens. She did not have insurance, so she begged for Jennifer to be admitted, promising to pay the bill by credit card.
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: When Jennifer was released three weeks later, she and Susan were referred to the Jewish Board's Break Free program, which provides therapy and peer counseling for teen-agers who are addicted to drugs or alcohol, and to support groups for their parents, at its Neptune Avenue office in Brighton Beach.
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: Through the UJA-Federation, Break Free is supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, so when teen-agers like Jennifer need treatment, they get it -- even if their parents cannot afford to pay. The fund's 85th annual appeal, now under way, runs through Feb. 28. The Times pays all administrative costs, so the money goes directly to services.
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: Jennifer attended the four-hour afternoon sessions at Break Free regularly, but she had relapses. She spent a night drinking with two friends and smoked marijuana. That night, she carved a line in her left wrist with a knife. After a second three-week stay at Holliswood Hospital, she went back to Break Free and did not drink for a month.
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: ''I got 30 days together and I thought, 'O.K., now I can go to a club.' '' At the club, she nearly drank herself into a coma.
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: Friends took her to the emergency room at Kings Highway Medical Center. Susan, desperate, tried to enroll her in Medicaid. ''I was never on Medicaid or welfare,'' she said. ''I would never take any kind of charity except in a desperate situation.''
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

text: ''CASH RULES everything around me.'' So goes the refrain to ''C.R.E.A.M.,'' a hit by the rap supergroup Wu-Tang Clan. A haunting fable of ghetto economics, the song depicts a grim world of ''stick-up kids, corrupt cops and crack rocks,'' where ''drug loot'' is the only way for the young black men that haunt its street corners to earn a living. While ''C.R.E.A.M.'' reflects the rough-and-tumble life that the group's members had growing up in housing projects on Staten Island, its money-obsessed chorus takes on new meaning in the wake of Wu-Tang's success.
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: In less than four years, Wu-Tang Clan has evolved into a hugely profitable hip-hop conglomerate that has made the industry rethink how it does business. Wu-Tang has used a brash entrepreneurial approach to build an empire that largely ignores common wisdom regarding contracts, marketing and choosing record companies.
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: The group's 1993 debut album, ''Enter the Wu-Tang (36 Chambers),'' sold well over a million copies, paving the way for a string of hit solo records by its members Method Man, Ol' Dirty Bastard, Raekwon and, most recently, Ghostface Killah, whose first solo album , ''Ironman,'' has sold nearly 500,000 copies since its release in October. The group's forthcoming album will be one of the most anticipated rap releases of the new year. Two of the group's 10 members set up their own record labels, and four have begun to develop their own offshoots; in addition, Wu-Tang has started a popular clothing line, Wu-Wear, featuring everything from ski jackets to watches. While their peers have ventured into those areas, few have tackled them with the panache of Wu-Tang. ''What these guys have done -- without taking a single business school course -- is to go right to the head of the class in terms of strategy development,'' said James I. Cash, a professor of business administration at Harvard Business School and a specialist in entrepreneurship and information technology.
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: At the core of Wu-Tang's success is RZA, the group's mastermind and producer. A wiry, intense 27-year-old, he quotes from the I Ching, Sun Tzu's ''Art of War'' and Machiavelli as easily as he rattles off chart positions and sales figures. Leaving Sony Music's Manhattan headquarters recently after a meeting about his new label, Razor Sharp, which will be distributed by Epic Records, a subsidiary of Sony, RZA talked about Wu-Tang's success. ''I don't like to talk numbers, man, but it's big,'' he said of his deal with Sony. (He also runs Wu-Tang Records, an independent imprint favoring more underground sounds.) '' 'C.R.E.A.M.' really says what we went through to get this money. And cash does rule everything around me, but it don't rule me. That's how come we got it. It's good because we came from the bottom of the bottomless pit.''
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: In the late 1970's, RZA (born Robert Diggs) began to hone his musical skills in the Killer Hills housing project on Staten Island. There he and his cousins Genius (Gary Grice) and Ol' Dirty Bastard (Russell Jones), who would go on to become founders of Wu-Tang, practiced hip-hop routines in basements while engaging in petty crime. While RZA says his friends ''bought sneakers and shirts, I spent my money on D.J. and musical equipment. I stole my clothes!'' His introduction to business, he says, came from selling marijuana on street corners. ''You could sell weed and make a little money,'' he said, ''but most of it gets made for the guy you're selling it for. It's the same thing in the music business, except it's legal.''
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: That lesson was driven home after early recording contracts that he and Genius had went sour around 1990. RZA felt that he and Genius had been naive about the record industry, allowing themselves to be marketed poorly and shortchanged financially; vowing never to make that mistake again, he read up on corporations and decided to apply his street savvy to any future deals.
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: IN 1992, WU-TANG CLAN WAS formed, proffering a mystical bent unusual in hip-hop. An aficionado of kung fu movies, RZA took the group's name, which means sword family, from a martial arts style; he also assigned each member of the group a superhero persona drawn from the comic books he grew up reading. Wu-Tang's lyrics address the grim realities of the ghetto without glamorizing them, as much of gangsta rap does. RZA's seductively murky beats and snippets of dialogue from mafia movies, for example, add to the group's underground flavor.
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: When record companies ignored Wu-Tang's early demonstration tapes, RZA collected $100 from each member to put out its debut single, ''Protect Ya Neck.'' Selling copies from the trunks of cars, the group traveled from Virginia to Ohio, promoting itself to radio programmers. When ''Protect Ya Neck'' turned into a regional hit, the same labels that had rejected the group came calling, but now Wu-Tang had some leverage. ''They offered us small amounts of money, like $200,000 for all eight members,'' said RZA. ''So I said, 'Forget the money; let's get a deal that gives all of us the power to get more deals.' ''
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: WU-TANG eventually settled on Loud Records, an unproven independent company distributed by RCA that offered an unheard-of deal: the group would take less advance money in exchange for creative control and its members would be free to sign anywhere else as solo artists.
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: RZA also took the unusual step of encouraging other members of the group to sign solo deals with labels not known for hip-hop. RCA, for example, was considered moribund, with little rap presence. And when Genius signed with Geffen, the company no longer even had a black-music department. ''I chose those labels because they didn't have anybody we'd have to compete with,'' RZA said. ''At the time, nobody could see the value of it.''
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: RZA's instincts were right. Wu-Tang's RCA debut album sold more than one million copies, and Raekwon's first solo effort sold more than 700,000 copies for the label. Genius and Ol' Dirty Bastard's solo albums have also sold well over 500,000 copies each for Geffen and Elektra.
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: Mr. Cash says there is a business term for RZA's seemingly unorthodox approach. ''With entrepreneurial activity,'' he said, ''we talk about 'getting above the noise level,' meaning every time you have an idea, there's probably another dozen people with the same idea. 'The question is, How will you get your idea leveraged when the other 11 won't? Frequently that involves going with a segment that's historically not been aligned with what you do. You would think that would be 180 degrees from where a group like Wu-Tang Clan would need to be. I can't imagine the conversation that unfolded when they walked in.''
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: RZA, however, remembers one of those conversations well. ''I sat in front of the whole Geffen staff and told them if they spend this much money, you can make a gold or platinum record. It's a no-brainer. And when we sold 100,000 that first week, they were like, 'This guy is right.' Same thing with Sony. We made a big deal, but the deal is going to pay for itself in three more months. That's my whole business philosophy: you can spend less and make more. We sold 700,000 units with Genius; that means Geffen will gross $7 million, and it only cost $700,000 to make. Geffen was never in the rap business, but they're in it now.''
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: RZA has also built bridges between competing record labels. ''I tried to bring all the different record companies together with a 'Wu Family Tree' advertising campaign last winter,'' he said. ''Four labels -- RCA, Elektra, Geffen, Def Jam -- came together, and we all sold double that week.''
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: COMPARING THIS MOVE to Microsoft's producing software for a competitor, Apple Computers, Mr. Cash calls the approach ''co-opetition.'' ''It's a strategy that combines the terms competition and cooperation,'' he said. ''It replaces the old strategy that had companies sitting in either a competitor box, a supplier box or a buyer box.''
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: With Wu-Wear, the Wu-Tang empire continues to expand. There are already retail outlets on Staten Island and in Atlanta, and others are planned soon in Norfolk, Va., Los Angeles and Sacramento, Calif. Pointing to the group's trademark ''W'' logo emblazoned on his T-shirt, Cappadonna (Darryl Hill), a group member, said: ''It's like a Timberland stamp. Whenever you see that symbol, you can bet that it's the best of hip-hop.''
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: In yet another marketing ploy, RZA recorded the single ''Wu-Wear,'' which urges listeners to abandon other clothing brands in favor of theirs.
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: Ultimately, RZA says, the group's wheeling and dealing extends the idea of unity on which Wu-Tang was founded. ''We took the theme of our next album from a kung fu movie called 'The Eight-Diagram Pole Fighter,' '' he said. ''It's about nine siblings that go to war with their father. When they stayed together, they defeated everybody. The point is, when Wu Tang came together, we vowed brotherhood to each other. When you stick together with your brothers, man, you can't lose.''
title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs

text: In 1983, a year after Nicholas L. Bissell Jr. became Somerset County Prosecutor, he filed a lawsuit to remove Franklin Township's Mayor from office. His complaint? Misconduct in office, he said, because she had distributed fliers at a township Council meeting criticizing a police investigation of several rapes.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: In 1989, William B. Wahl, the director of Somerset County's governing body, the Board of Chosen Freeholders, apparently angered Mr. Bissell by questioning raises for his staff and demanding that the County Auditor audit the Prosecutor's office. Subsequently, Mr. Bissell accused Mr. Wahl of stealing a political campaign sign from a yard and then lying about it.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: Complaints that Mr. Bissell had abused his power were made with the New Jersey Attorney General's office on behalf of both the Mayor and Mr. Wahl. No action was taken against Mr. Bissell in either case, the lawyers who made the complaints said.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: These stories and others told in interviews over the last week raise questions about how diligently the Attorney General's office monitored Mr. Bissell's performance or that of any of New Jersey's other 20 county prosecutors. They also raise questions about New Jersey's system of choosing and approving its prosecutors: they are nominated by the Governor and formally reviewed by the State Senate Judiciary Committee, which has no staff or money to investigate nominees.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: In the wake of Mr. Bissell's conviction last May on charges of abuse of power, embezzlement and tax and mail fraud, and of his suicide Nov. 26, the Attorney General, Peter Verniero, has begun to review the ways his office supervises New Jersey's 21 county prosecutors. For the moment, Mr. Verniero said, he is not certain how extensive any changes will be.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: ''Reform might be too strong a word,'' he said. ''I don't want to indict the entire system because of one prosecutor gone astray.''
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: But Edwin H. Stier, who was director of the Attorney General's Division of Criminal Justice -- the office that oversees the county prosecutors -- from 1977 to 1982, the year Mr. Bissell began his first term, said it was time for a major overhaul of the way New Jersey selects its county prosecutors and evaluates their performance in office. He said the ''terrible tragedy'' of the Bissell case should serve as ''a model to learn from'' and guide changes.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: ''The potential for harm is so great that you can't say we have 20 good ones and one bad one,'' Mr. Stier said. ''You need 21 good ones.''
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: Mr. Stier, whose law offices are in Somerset County, said he had known Mr. Bissell for 15 years. ''Bissell was operating on or way over the edge,'' Mr. Stier said. ''That was clear if you look at how his office was run.''
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: But he called Mr. Bissell shrewd and engaging and said he curried favor with his supervisors in the Attorney General's office by aligning himself with them against more independent-minded county prosecutors seeking greater latitude for their offices. County prosecutors, he said, exercise considerable law enforcement power and the state, in its obligation to insure their public accountability, should emphasize that prosecutors must always exercise their authority with restraint.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: He suggested two changes: requiring a specific minimum level of experience, preferably in criminal justice administration, and establishing, after a prosecutor takes office, a specific set of criteria to judge performance, especially the exercise of authority and discretion. The state law giving the Attorney General supervisory power over prosecutors makes evaluations optional. Mr. Stier suggested the process become mandatory and include well defined standards of conduct.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: Chuck Davis, a spokesman for the Attorney General's office, said Mr. Bissell's file in Trenton did not contain any formal written evaluations by superiors.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: He said there were 14 complaints in it, filed since he took office 14 years ago. Mr. Davis declined to disclose the nature of any of them, on grounds some contained confidential information and some were sent to the Attorney General anonymously. He also did not say how the complaints were dealt with.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: In the case of the Franklin Township Mayor, Nancy Henry, her lawyer, Henry Furst, said: ''Nobody did a thing. They never called me. They never asked me about it.'' It was not clear whether her case was among the 14. Mr. Stier, who made the complaint on behalf of Mr. Wahl, the director of the freeholders, said he was told afterward that the case had been investigated and that Mr. Bissell had done nothing wrong.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: Mr. Furst said he sent a booklet of documents, including a strong rebuke of Mr. Bissell by a Federal appeals court in Philadelphia, to the New Jersey Senate's Judiciary Committee in 1988. At the time, it was considering Gov. Thomas H. Kean's nomination of Mr. Bissell for a second five-year term. Mr. Furst said the committee sent him a thank-you note but nothing about its view of the Bissell-Henry fight.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: It apparently did little to tarnish the committee's view of Mr. Bissell. On May 26, 1988, it approved Mr. Bissell's reappointment by voice vote. A week later, the full Senate unanimously approved it.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: A State Senator on the committee at the time, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he did not recall any criticism of the Bissell renomination. The committee, he said, has no staff or money to conduct its own investigations of nominees and routinely ''rubber stamps'' the Governor's recommendations unless strong objections are raised.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: Mr. Bissell's biggest booster in the Senate, John H. Ewing, a Republican from Somerset County, said he eagerly approved the Prosecutor's renomination. Under longstanding courtesy rules in the New Jersey Senate, all nominees for county prosecutor must have the backing of the senators in their county.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: Senator Ewing said he did not recall anyone from the Governor's office or the Judiciary Committee raising questions about Mr. Bissell.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: ''He was tough on criminals,'' Mr. Ewing said. ''I O.K.'d him, the county chairman O.K.'d him. What he was doing was not brought to my attention as a reason to hold him up.''
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: New Jersey is one of only a few states that choose their county prosecutors through nomination by the governor and confirmation by a legislative body; in most states, they are elected. Generally, appointed prosecutors undergo a greater degree of prenomination screening and background checks and tighter supervision by supervisors once in office, said James Polley, director of government affairs for the National District Attorneys Association in Alexandria, Va.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: At the time of his renomination and in the months afterward, Mr. Bissell was cultivating his image as a hard-nosed foe of drug dealers and endearing himself in Trenton with his seizures of drug suspects' money and property. In the 1990's, his office confiscated $3.7 million in cash alone. Since his conviction and suicide, the Attorney General's office has started poring over old spending records in an effort to insure that all the seized money was spent on law enforcement projects as required by state law, Mr. Davis, the Attorney General's spokesman, said.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: While in office, Mr. Bissell guarded these records closely and routinely rebuffed efforts by one Somerset County citizen, John Paff, to inspect them. Mr. Paff said he went to Trenton in 1992 and asked the Criminal Justice Division to compel Mr. Bissell to release documents on the seized money. The officials refused, Mr. Paff said.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: Two drug suspects who were targets of Mr. Bissell's office, Isaac Wright and Gregory Fuhs, took their grievances against him to court and prevailed this fall after years of legal fighting. Mr. Wright won a new trial on a drug kingpin charge after detectives testified that a 1989 cocaine seizure in the case was conducted without a search warrant and that Mr. Wright's accomplices gave perjured testimony against him in exchange for leniency. Mr. Fuhs's case dates to his arrest in 1988, after Mr. Bissell began his second term, on charges of growing marijuana plants at his home. Immediately afterward, Mr. Bissell's office seized $65,000 from Mr. Fuhs's bank account. In early October, a jury returned a $50,000 malpractice verdict against Mr. Fuhs's lawyer after finding that the money was confiscated without Mr. Fuhs's written consent.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: Throughout his second term, Mr. Bissell kept seized funds in his office or in a bank founded by a friend, in violation of state regulations requiring that seized drug money be turned over to the county treasurer. The funds were audited by his bookkeeper and friend, Thomas Wagner, who ultimately testified in Mr. Bissell's Federal trial last spring that he helped Mr. Bissell and his wife, Barbara, file false Federal income and corporate income tax returns.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: Mr. Bissell was also convicted of skimming about $146,000 from two gasoline stations he owned in Somerset County, of threatening to plant cocaine in the car of an oil company official who complained the stations were dirty, and of operating the stations in violation of state ethics laws prohibiting county prosecutors from earning outside income.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: Federal prosecutors said the crimes occurred during the 1990's.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: Robert J. Del Tufo, New Jersey's Attorney General from 1990 to 1994, said he and his top aides in the Criminal Justice Division had ''absolutely no knowledge'' that Mr. Bissell had committed any crimes. And he said he personally did not know of complaints against Mr. Bissell during his tenure.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: Mr. Del Tufo praised him for creating a training academy for police officers and firefighters, broadening drug education programs in schools, and helping with crackdowns on carjackings in adjacent counties. He described him as messianic and dynamic, as well as arrogant and abrasive.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: ''Sometimes his judgment was flawed and he acted too precipitously,'' Mr. Del Tufo said. But he said he was unaware of any criminal wrongdoing.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: ''I think hindsight is at play here and I think it's unfair,'' he said.
title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials

text: ON a blustery Tuesday last January, Junot Diaz was summoned from his day job to the phone. A year out of graduate school, he made photocopies at Pfizer Pharmaceuticals in Manhattan by day and wrote fiction at night and in the early morning. When he hung up, he cried: ''Yo! Somebody wants to buy my book! I quit!''
title: Outsider With a Voice
