text: That was the beginning of this year of being published and praised.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: The book, ''Drown,'' is a collection of short stories based on his life growing up in the Dominican Republic and in a tough Latino neighborhood in Perth Amboy.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: For months, years, he had been sending stories to magazines like The New Yorker, where they were ignored. Finally he received a response.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: ''Junot just leaped out of the mail pile,'' said Lois Rosenthal, the editor of Story magazine, which first published John O'Hara and Carson McCullers, among other renowned writers. ''His voice was so incredibly fresh and so powerful. I called immediately. I said, 'Who are you?' ''
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: The answer? He is an unflinching observer, an insider, of tough teen-age Latino immigrants in New Jersey. Of hand-to-mouth lives and of mind-numbing jobs. Of young men who get money making penny-ante drug sales and give some to their mothers to spend at the mall, or who steal from the boss's cash register to buy lingerie for a girlfriend. He writes of what he knows without compromise, but he invests his stories with love. Feeling like an outsider in the world of the moneyed and successful, he never thought his stories would be popular.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: His outsider status actually places him firmly within a long tradition in American literature, from ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' to the novels of Zora Neale Hurston. Reviewing ''Drown'' in The New York Times Book Review, David Gates, the author of ''Jernigan,'' wrote, ''Mr. Diaz transfigures disorder and disorientation with a rigorous sense of form.'' His portrait of a Dominican teen-ager's ''hard-working and neglectful, weak-willed and tyrannical'' father, ''filtered through the son's feelings of love, longing and anger . . . wrings the heart with finely calibrated restraint.''
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: Unfortunately for Mr. Diaz, 27, his new success almost makes him long for his photocopying days. He's used to hanging out with his impecunious artist friends, going to their poetry readings on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, their art exhibitions in tenement halls. But lately his days have consisted of back-to-back interviews and literary-celebrity parties. ''Terribly weird,'' he said.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: His homes, his familiar places, are across the river and across the country. He was born in Santo Domingo, came to the United States when he was 7, grew up in Perth Amboy, and attended Kean College and Rutgers University. The New Jersey of which he writes is the one he knows: a place of blue-collar towns and Latino immigrants, of tostones (mashed fried plantains) and malls and roads where ''beer bottles grow out of the weeds like squashes.'' His neighborhood, he writes, ''was separated from all other communities by a six-lane highway and the dump.''
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: People think of New Jersey as ''a place of transit, temporary -- an exit off the highway,'' he said. ''The New Jersey I wrote about isn't hidden. It just isn't the suburbs and isn't the turnpike or the Garden State.'' Mr. Diaz's settings are specific and precise -- at first, too precise for his editors in Manhattan.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: ''They said, 'Make it not so New Jersey.' They said, 'Make it anywhere.' But it's not anywhere,'' he said. ''I love this state. New Jersey for me is so alive with history. It's old, dynamic, African-American, Latino.''
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: In Mr. Diaz's stories, living rooms are decorated in ''Contemporary Dominican Tacky.'' High school buddies go bar-hopping in New Brunswick -- ''a nice city, the Raritan so low and silty you don't have to be Jesus to walk over it.'' He continues: ''None of the chicas ever dance with us, but a glance or a touch can keep us talking . . . for hours.''
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: Summers, playing stickball in the parking lot, ''the heat . . . was like something heavy that had come inside to die. . . . At around midnight abuelas, with their night hair swirled around spiky rollers, shouted at us from their apartment windows. Sinverguenzas! Go home!''
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: He writes in the language of immigrant teen-agers, a mix of English and Spanish and street slang. He does not italicize or translate Spanish or slang words.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: ''I write for the people I grew up with,'' he said. ''I took extreme pains for my book to not be a native informant. Not: 'This is Dominican food. This is a Spanish word.' I trust my readers, even non-Spanish ones.''
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: Thus ''Drown'' ushers its readers -- Latino and non-Latino -- into the sounds, smells and sights of the world of Latino immigrants' children: the strip malls of Route 9; the refrigerator with its embarrassing Government cheese; the utility room with an oil-splotched floor that provides privacy for lovemaking and the teen-agers' fading memories of Carribbean mango trees and impoverished barrios. Split between two cultures and languages, these teen-agers must create their own. This is what Mr. Diaz explores.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: LATE one morning, after a Fox Television interview and before a flight to London for a publicity tour, Mr. Diaz, who now lives in New York, took the time to do something unusual for him these days. He got behind a steering wheel, his shaved head in profile exposing the arch of his skull, much like an Egyptian portrait sculpture. A slight but muscular man, he has a fine-featured face. Even sitting quietly in the driver's seat he seemed taut with energy, like a big cat.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: ''I miss driving, always,'' he said. He directed the car south, to his college town, New Brunswick, where Rutgers University had opened his world.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: When Mr. Diaz was at Oldbridge High School in Perth Amboy, his father lost his job as a forklift driver. ''The poverty,'' Mr. Diaz said. ''It's hard to wrap my brain around it.'' He said he made ''miserable'' grades, distracting himself by drinking, smoking ''buddha'' (marijuana) and reading, constantly. It was the last of these three escapes that his friends considered weird. A cousin, entering Mr. Diaz's bedroom, told him, ''These stacks of books ain't getting you out of here.''
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: Mr. Diaz went on to the one college that admitted him, Kean College in Union, which ''woke me up to how much I enjoyed education,'' he said. He transferred to Rutgers when a Kean professor told him, ''Yo! This school can't hold you.''
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: At Rutgers he discovered things he hadn't imagined existed in high school. He took courses in Latino and African-American history. Although Latinos at Rutgers ''were still invisible,'' he said, he met some students who were politically active. At Rutgers he came to see himself -- and assert himself -- as a Dominican, an American and a writer. He discovered ''a desire to express myself,'' he said. ''Yo! I could do this!''
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: He transformed his conviction into skill and craft at Cornell University, where he studied writing in graduate school. ''When he left Cornell, there was little obvious promise he was even going to survive by writing,'' said Paula Moya, a college friend who now teaches English at Stanford University.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: Driving seems to relax him. He parks at Monument Square in New Brunswick and scans the dry fountain, the sculpture of the square-jawed Union soldier erected shortly after the Civil War, and the three theaters across Livingston Street.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: ''You never forget the discovery years,'' he said, his voice matter-of-fact rather than sentimental. ''First kisses. The first time you try certain foods.''
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: He headed down Livingston Street to the New Brunswick Free Public Library, with its milky, opaque floors and stacks of books, where he found books about inner-city streets and barrios. ''I'd be so many times sitting here chilling,'' he said. ''They had a mad staff at this library.'' (Mad meaning great.)
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: Inside the atmospheric old library, he pulls up ''Drown'' on the computer -- taking more satisfaction in finding it there, perhaps, than in displays at Barnes & Noble.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: The next stop was an old haunt, a little Thai restaurant in a Piscataway strip mall that serves spicy, creamy, neon-orange iced tea. He used to go at night when half-naked Thai wrestlers would grapple with each other in the foot or two of space between tables.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: Seated in a tight booth, Mr. Diaz seems very at home. It's his kind of town, his kind of place.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: ''That's what's going to save him,'' Ms. Rosenthal said. ''Somebody in his position could have his head turned. But what Junot cares about is the work. He knows what's important. That's going to keep him grounded.''
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: Indeed, Mr. Diaz said he was finding the business of writing -- as opposed to the art and the craft -- stupefyingly dull. ''I've met so many writers who want to talk about agents, advances, publishers,'' he said. ''That's not what I'm about. I started writing with no interest in money. I'm not saying my vision is pure. But I write my soul apart.''
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: 'We Weren't Made Out of Loot': A Junot Diaz Sampler
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: On the days we have no deliveries the boss has us working at the showroom, selling cards and poker chips and mankala boards. . . . The boss keeps me in front of the store . . . Only when he needs my Spanish will he let me help on a sale. . . . I slouch behind the front register and steal. I don't ring anything up, and pocket what comes in. . . . A hundred-buck haul's not unusual for me and back in the day, when the girlfriend used to pick me up, I'd buy her anything she wanted, dresses, silver rings, lingerie. Sometimes I blew it all on her. She didn't like the stealing but . . . we weren't made out of loot and I liked going into a place and saying, Jeva, pick out anything, it's yours. This is the closest I've come to feeling rich.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: Nowadays I take the bus home and the cash stay with me. I sit next to this three-hundred-pound rock-and-roll chick who washes dishes at the Friendly's. She tells me about the roaches she kills with her water nozzle. Boils the wings right off them. On Thursday I buy myself lottery tickets -- ten Quick Picks and a couple of Pick 4s. I don't bother with the little stuff.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: Each payday I take out the old calculator and figure how long it'd take me to buy a pool table honestly. A top-of-the-line, three-piece slate affair doesn't come cheap. You have to buy sticks and balls and chalk and a score keeper and triangles and French tips if you're a fancy shooter. Two and a half years if I give up buying underwear and eat only pasta but even this figure's bogus. Money's never stuck to me, ever.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: Most people don't realize how sophisticated pool tables are. Yes, tables have bolts and staples on the rails but these suckers hold together mostly by gravity and by the precision of their construction. If you treat a good table right it will outlast you. Believe me. Cathedrals are built like that. There are Incan roads in the Andes that even today you couldn't work a knife between two of the cobblestones. The sewers that the Romans built in Bath were so good that they weren't replaced until the 1950's. That's the sort of thing I can believe in.
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: From the short story ''Edison, New Jersey,'' in ''Drown,'' by Junot Diaz (Riverhead Books).
title: Outsider With a Voice

text: NEARLY four years ago, the public was mad as hell at the dizzying costs of the savings and loan crisis. And Federal District Judge Mariana R. Pfaelzer seemed to capture the public mood when she doubled the suggested Federal sentence and ordered Charles H. Keating Jr. to prison for 12 1/2 years for defrauding and destroying the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, a $3.4 billion disaster. She justified her popular decision by calling Mr. Keating's crimes ''staggering.''
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: William P. Barr, the United States Attorney General at the time, chimed in: ''Mr. Keating as much as any man has come to symbolize the excesses that led to the collapse of the thrift industry.''
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: But this neat moral drama took a different turn last week. In a conspicuously terse decision, Judge Pfaelzer on Monday overturned the criminal conviction of the beaming arch-villain of the savings and loan crisis. And that came just months after Mr. Keating, 73, had his state criminal conviction thrown out, on the grounds that the judge had instructed the jury improperly.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: What happened to our understanding that the mess was caused by a bunch of devious swindlers? And what happened to the anger over the $132 billion that the crisis cost taxpayers?
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: The most remarkable aspect of this coda to the savings and loan morality tale was that when Mr. Keating strolled to freedom, few people seemed to care, and those that did believed that the real culprit was not simple fraud but misguided Government policies.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: And in some ways, many experts argue, that is good news: The biggest financial debacle in American history was painful, it swelled the Federal budget deficit, it made a lot of people rich at taxpayer expense, but ultimately it had a modest impact on the financial markets and now, just a few years later, it seems like distant history. We've moved on.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: Which is not say there were not egregious crimes and losers as well as winners. The thrift industry collapsed in large measure because it was outmoded. Congress had designed it after World War II to focus on taking deposits and providing home mortgages to bring the dream of home ownership to more Americans.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: But because the thrifts were singularly reliant on mortgages they were particularly vulnerable to being whipsawed by sharp jumps in interest rates, as happened in the late 1970's. Congress responded by allowing the thrifts to plunge into a variety of new businesses in which they had little experience. The coming disaster was turbocharged when the Government eased up on overseeing the thrifts.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: Crooks found the thrifts easy pickings. And the savings and loans, unprepared for their new business, threw away tens of billions of dollars in ill-considered investments. When the real estate market crashed, nearly everyone involved lost their shirts.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: Belatedly, Government bureaucrats were forced to seize and sell nearly $500 billion worth of real estate, mortgages, resort hotels and race horses -- something they were woefully unprepared to handle. There were clearly sweetheart deals on some of these sales. Billionaires like Ronald O. Perelman and the Bass Brothers acquired what were ultimately highly profitable thrifts at what some experts said were fire-sale prices.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: In each of those deals, the taxpayer was the loser. Of the $160 billion that the overall clean-up will probably cost, the taxpayer paid $132 billion.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: But there was a silver lining: the Government put an unprecedented amount of assets in private hands in just a few years. Even the real estate market, which some feared would be disrupted for years because of the number of apartment buildings, ranches, office towers and undeveloped lots unloaded, bounded back.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: Today, the economic news is largely upbeat and taxpayers are worried about which mutual fund to buy, not how much Mr. Keating cost them.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: ''The good news is we've forgotten,'' said Bert Ely, a banking consultant. ''It's behind us, even if you have some scoundrels walking free.''
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: Mr. Keating, of course, will not forget the episode soon; he, and his son, an executive at his company, spent four and a half years in prison and he insists they are virtually penniless. A handful of his other executives pleaded guilty to felonies. The law firms and accounting firms that worked for Mr. Keating and scores of failed thrifts have paid out $2.4 billion.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: But some good may have come of it all, at least in hindsight. There were 3,262 Federally chartered thrifts in 1985, just as the crisis was gaining steam, with $1.1 trillion in assets; as of the middle of this year, there were 1,436 such thrifts with assets totaling $771 billion.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: Many experts say that this leaves room for commercial banks and other financial institutions to provide the same services, but much more efficiently.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: Despite the efforts of Government officials, and the media, to seize on the chicanery of some savings and loan owners, records now show they accounted for a modest portion of the losses -- perhaps 5 percent.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: Several years ago, a Federal commission concluded that the scale of the crisis resulted largely from ''a systematic breakdown in the political system.'' And now even some former prosecutors agree that the villain is faceless. ''Keating is an emblem of nothing other than the fact that the media made him a symbol of something he was never a symbol of,'' said Ira H. Raphaelson, a former Justice Department special counsel.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: So what have we learned? Mr. Keating is free and bitter, and Government regulators say they are wiser. And the white elephant that Mr. Keating built near Phoenix for $300 million, the Phoenician, one of the greatest symbols of excess, is now owned by Sheraton and is one of the hottest resorts in the country. Its restaurants are said to be selling quite a lot of Hardy's Perfection cognac, a treat that goes for $450 a snifter in these post-excess times.
title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life

text: ICONOGRAPHY AND ELECTRONICS UPON A GENERIC ARCHITECTURE: A View From the Drafting Room. By Robert Venturi. (MIT, $40.) As the author of one of this century's most influential texts on the building art, ''Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture,'' the Philadelphia-based architect Robert Venturi is in the unenviable position of having every subsequent book of his measured against that 1966 classic. Yet this absorbing new collection of Mr. Venturi's exceptionally literate articles, lectures, letters and aphorisms written over the past two decades offers rewarding insights into a creative intelligence as wide-ranging and iconoclastic as ever. In several respects this is the most thought-provoking architecture book of the year.
title: Architecture

text: In the two opening essays Mr. Venturi calls for a more audacious use of advanced electronics in today's architecture. He proposes that sophisticated video systems could make the facades and interiors of otherwise intentionally ordinary structures into glittering LED equivalents of the hieroglyphic-emblazoned temples of ancient Egypt or the mosaic-encrusted churches of the Byzantine era. This latest conflation of architectural history and commercial vernacular imagery is likely to set establishment teeth on edge, just as Mr. Venturi's other high-low appropriations have done since the 60's. In a lengthy list of ''Valid Rantings'' he writes, ''I am always out of step.'' But that is precisely the burden -- and imperative -- of the vanguard artist.
title: Architecture

text: Among the best pieces here is the poignant summing up Mr. Venturi submitted for his 50th prep school class reunion. Though he is content with ''the reasonable balance between extremes of satisfaction and frustration'' in the fruitful career he has made with his wife and partner, Denise Scott Brown, the author laments how much America has changed since his graduation in 1942, ''when we were considerably a land of the free and home of the brave.''
title: Architecture

text: Equally moving is his tribute to another maverick Philadelphia architect, the Victorian virtuoso Frank Furness, whose bold new vision of the cityscape proved too jarring for many of his contemporaries, much as his admirer's work has been. This quirky, opinionated volume seethes with unspent passions beneath the surface of its elegant prose and no doubt will provide interpretive riches for future biographers of this complex and contradictory figure.
title: Architecture

text: THE PARTHENON: And Its Impact in Modern Times. Edited by Panayotis Tournikiotis. (Melissa Publishing/Abrams, $75.) Built by the architects Ictinus and Callicrates atop the Acropolis in Athens during the fifth century B.C., the temple of Athena Polias -- more familiarly known as the Parthenon -- is among the most exhaustively studied of ancient monuments. Thus yet another monograph on the largest Doric shrine (and, the book says, the only Greek temple made wholly of marble) seems at first superfluous.
title: Architecture

text: But the 11 essays assembled by Panayotis Tournikiotis, an architect who teaches at the National Technical University in Athens, focus not only on the perfectly proportioned sanctuary itself but also on its long life as an icon of Western civilization at its noblest. In his chapter on ''The Parthenon as Cultural Ideal,'' Savas Kondaratos, who teaches at the Athens School of Fine Arts, traces its history as a symbol of lofty aspirations through the ages. From the Imperial Roman writer who already regarded the goddess of wisdom's house as a nostalgic vestige of ''the good old days,'' through its recycling as a church -- Our Lady of Athens -- and then a mosque, to Le Corbusier's piquant comparison of the temple's sleek lines to those of a Delage motor car, the Parthenon has reflected changing spiritual and social values in the guise of enduring principles.
title: Architecture

text: BOROBUDUR. By Louis Frederic. Photography by Jean-Louis Nou. (Abbeville, $125.) We often think of the Buddhist esthetic in terms of the enigmatic austerity of a Zen dry garden, but the seven-acre Javanese shrine of Borobudur, built about A.D. 800, is as iconographic and grandiose as any work of Christian architecture. Indeed, the purpose of this stupendous stupa was similar to that of the great Gothic cathedrals: to replicate in enduring three-dimensional form the journey from earthly travail to eternity and, for the benefit of the unlettered, to illustrate sacred texts through sculpture (here some 1,460 bas-relief panels totaling more than a mile and a half in length).
title: Architecture

text: The pinnacle of Indonesian art, the flattened volcanic rock pyramid of Borobudur was raised by the Sailendra dynasty and then abandoned within a century of its completion as religious tides shifted across the archipelago. What remains is an overpowering treasure not nearly so well known in the West as it ought to be. Presented in the glorious photographs of Jean-Louis Nou (who died in 1992) and the detailed and articulate explications of Louis Frederic, it is now more fully comprehensible than ever before.
title: Architecture

text: This massive book was designed by Molly Shields with an uncanny grasp of her subject's spiritual nature. The book's almost-square format approximates that of the sanctuary itself, whose mandala-like plan is reproduced throughout to orient the reader within this intricate structure. One completes this paper pilgrimage disinclined to dispute the ancient belief that cosmic Borobudur represents ''the center of the center.''
title: Architecture

text: MONASTERIES OF GREECE. By Chris Hellier. (Tauris/St. Martin's, $50.) For pure vicarious pleasure, this animated and illuminating tour of the religious communities of the Byzantine Empire, conducted by Chris Hellier, a journalist and photographer, is a transporting experience. Steeped in the arcane political and ecclesiastical history of the Eastern Orthodox Church, Mr. Hellier elucidates the forces that have shaped the architectural character of these devotional outposts. As he points out, the visual impact of these slowly accreted complexes ''depends on their extraordinary siting as much as the architecture itself: the complete ensembles are far more impressive than their component parts.''
title: Architecture

text: Most dramatic of all are the vertiginous ''monasteries in the air'' of the Meteora region in northern Greece. The otherworldly atmosphere of the Roussanou Monastery and several other aerie-abbeys perched atop astonishing rock outcroppings has worked against their survival as contemplative retreats. Not invading infidels but tourist hordes have prompted the monks and nuns of the Meteora to flee to quieter surroundings, save for those who ''have accepted their summertime role as ticket sellers and monastic guides.''
title: Architecture

text: DESIGN AND COLOR IN ISLAMIC ARCHITECTURE: Eight Centuries of the Tile-Maker's Art. By Michael Barry. Photographs by Roland and Sabrina Michaud. (Vendome, $85.) The Koran's prohibition against graven images has channeled the artistic energies of Islamic peoples into a staggeringly inventive decorative tradition. This visually overwhelming album evokes its topic with appropriate splendor. After one is immersed in it, the debates about color, ornament and pattern that have raged in Western architecture throughout this century of modernism seem ludicrous.
title: Architecture

text: The thrilling panoramas and hypnotic details that Roland and Sabrina Michaud have photographed during 30 years of travels around the Middle East and Central Asia are complemented by the informative commentaries of Michael Barry, an expert on Afghanistan. Not only are some of the landmarks depicted here now inaccessible to Americans, but many of the arabesques that enrich them are more legible in these telephoto close-ups than in situ.
title: Architecture

text: For example, the Michauds capture the delicate mesh of radiating and concentric lines on the turquoise tile dome of the Shrine of Shah Nematollah in Mahan, Iran. That geometric but also naturalistic motif harks back, Mr. Barry explains, to the spider web ''spun across the mouth of the Prophet's Cave which served both to hide, and to reveal, the network of emanations of the Divinity made manifest.''
title: Architecture

text: APOSTLE OF TASTE: Andrew Jackson Downing, 1815-1852. By David Schuyler. (Johns Hopkins University, $35.95.) The architect, horticulturist, writer and planner Andrew Jackson Downing, killed in a steamboat accident at 36, nevertheless lived long enough to secure a permanent place in American cultural history. Though many of Downing's ideas stemmed directly from English Romanticism, his indigenous approach to domestic, garden and park design -- including the Gothic Revival houses and picturesque grounds he illustrated in his best-selling pattern books -- could never be confused with European antecedents.
title: Architecture

text: Downing's immense affection for the natural setting, and especially that of his native Hudson River Valley, awakened his vast readership's pride in their nation's landscape. Thus he laid the groundwork for public support of many later projects by others, including Frederick Law Olmsted's urban oases, the national park system and the conservation movement.
title: Architecture

text: Incredibly, until this thoughtful work by David Schuyler, a professor of American studies at Franklin and Marshall College, there had been no full-scale biography of this seminal polymath. ''His vision of American society was, like Jefferson's, rooted in the soil,'' Mr. Schuyler writes of Downing, ''although for him the garden had joined and perhaps superseded the farm as the bedrock of the republic.''
title: Architecture

text: GOTTFRIED SEMPER: Architect of the Nineteenth Century. By Harry Francis Mallgrave. (Yale University, $50.) Little remembered today except by architectural scholars who prize him as a brilliant theorist and by music lovers who esteem his majestic Dresden Hoftheater, the German architect Gottfried Semper bore the full brunt of the profound political and technological upheavals that racked his homeland from the Napoleonic Wars until its unification. Thus impelled to rethink the very origins and premises of building, Semper in turn affected the ideas of progressive contemporaries from his friend Richard Wagner to Louis Sullivan and other architects of the Chicago School.
title: Architecture

text: Semper's thriving early career in Saxony came to an abrupt halt with his involvement in the failed revolution of 1848. During a forced exile he wrote two hugely ambitious books -- ''The Four Elements of Architecture'' and ''Science, Industry and Art'' -- in which he used the evolution of building prototypes to help explain the comprehensive changes of his own period. After years as an educator in Switzerland, Semper made a triumphant late-life comeback in Dresden (to erect his second opera house there) and Vienna (as architect of the sumptuous Kunsthistorisches Museum and the Hofburg Theater).
title: Architecture

text: This meticulously researched and lucidly written account of Semper's life and works by Harry Francis Mallgrave, the Willard K. Martin Distinguished Visiting Professor at the University of Oregon, is a valuable contribution that fills a giant gap in English-language architectural literature. Mr. Mallgrave is always faithful to the inquiring spirit of his worthy subject.
title: Architecture

text: ACCENTS AS WELL AS BROAD EFFECTS: Writings on Architecture, Landscape, and the Environment, 1876-1925. By Mariana Griswold Van Rensselaer. Edited by David Gebhard. (University of California, $45.) The Edith Wharton of American architectural criticism, Mariana Griswold Van Rensselaer (1851-1934) moved in the same upper-class New York, Newport and expatriate circles as her younger contemporary, turning a similarly analytical eye on the transformation of urban life during the Gilded Age. Van Rensselaer's championing of H. H. Richardson -- her 1888 biography of him was the first monograph on an American architect -- and McKim, Mead & White proved her ability to recognize some of the finest designers of her time.
title: Architecture

text: She signed her books as Mrs. Schuyler Van Rensselaer, but her husband disdained her literary efforts. Only after she was widowed, at 33, did she throw herself fully into her career, which also included writing poetry, fiction and translations. Though she chafed at empty social observances (she wrote a scathing attack on the ritual of formal calls), her privileged position afforded her a self-confident perspective. Her still-relevant essay on the architect-client relationship, reprinted here, shows a keen understanding of the dynamics of artistic patronage.
title: Architecture

text: This welcome anthology was completed shortly before its editor, the architectural historian David Gebhard, died last year. His sensitive introduction is a well-deserved encomium to a pioneering predecessor and a graceful coda to his own role as an advocate of the American Renaissance that Van Rensselaer did so much to promote.
title: Architecture

text: CHARLES RENNIE MACKINTOSH. Edited by Wendy Kaplan. (Glasgow Museums/Abbeville, $60.) Few architects of any period command the international cult following that surrounds Charles Rennie Mackintosh, the turn-of-the-century Glaswegian whose craggy architecture and etiolated furnishings are the focus of the retrospective on him being held at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through Feb. 16. This splendid catalogue, which now belongs at the top of the extensive list of Mackintosh publications, is a remarkable achievement.
title: Architecture

text: Thanks to the superlative series of essays edited by Wendy Kaplan, the former chief curator of the Wolfsonian Museum in Miami Beach, we can now appreciate Mackintosh unencumbered by the old canard that he was neglected and destroyed by his ungrateful Scottish homeland. The insouciant chic of his Art Nouveau schemes masked an underlying tension in his work that paralleled a similar disjunction in his personality. This gifted, troubled artist's building career, over soon after he was 40, was cut short by his alcoholism and depression, shifts in public taste and the cataclysm of World War I. His last 15 years were devoted to painting stylized botanicals and landscapes notable for their tight architectural composition.
title: Architecture

text: The miracle is that Mackintosh achieved as much as he did: 10 buildings (including one masterpiece, the Glasgow School of Art), dozens of interiors, scores of decorative objects, and some 400 furniture schemes, adding up to a captivating design legacy that remains unsurpassed. The century that began so promisingly for him ends with a longing backward glance at this fragile genius.
title: Architecture

text: DRAWN FROM THE SOURCE: The Travel Sketches of Louis I. Kahn. By Eugene J. Johnson and Michael J. Lewis. With an essay and site photographs by Ralph Lieberman. (Williams College Museum of Art/MIT, paper, $20.) It has long been acknowledged that the drawings Louis I. Kahn made on his three sojourns around the Mediterranean -- in 1928-29, 1950-51 and 1959 -- played a pivotal role in his growth as America's greatest postwar architect. Yet never before have these potent depictions been scrutinized as tellingly as they are in this concise catalogue accompanying the exhibition of the same name, on view at the Jewish Museum in New York through Dec. 15, organized by Eugene J. Johnson and Michael J. Lewis, who teach art history at Williams College.
title: Architecture

text: Educated during the waning years of the Beaux-Arts tradition -- which stressed the primacy of draftsmanship and the study of Greek and Roman landmarks -- the young Kahn set off on his first Grand Tour a year before the Great Depression began. His early drawings, such as those of the Tuscan hill town of San Gimignano (whose stalky defensive towers he would adapt in his Brutalist buildings of the 1950's and 60's), prefigured his rise as a revivifier, rather than mere copyist, of historical forms.
title: Architecture

text: As he matured, Kahn shunned prosaic visual reportage in order to distill the essence of a place, the equivalent of inspired travel writing. He dug deeper to expose emotions rather than resemblances, altering his deft technique for the blazing facades and shadowy colonnades of the Pharaonic tombs in Egypt's Valley of the Kings or the giddy arches and rocketing pinnacles of St. Mark's Basilica in Venice. In light of these revealing documents it is clear why Kahn's own architecture embodied an authenticity and grandeur conspicuously lacking in much other midcentury modernism.
title: Architecture

text: TADAO ANDO: Complete Works. Edited by Francesco Dal Co. (Phaidon/Chronicle, $75.) TADAO ANDO: The Colours of Light. By Richard Pare. (Phaidon/ Chronicle, $95.) If any present-day architect can be said to have inherited the mantle of Louis I. Kahn it is Tadao Ando, who works in his native Osaka. Mr. Ando's minimalist concrete structures convey the same geometric power and numinous play of light as those of that American master. Furthermore, the buildings of both men are invariably monumental in scale regardless of their size, accounting for their compelling physical presence and spiritual aura.
title: Architecture

text: The award of the 1995 Pritzker Prize to Mr. Ando only endorsed the widespread critical opinion that he is foremost among the gifted generation of Japanese architects who emerged during the boom years of the 1980's. All the more singular for being self-taught, this 55-year-old former truck driver and boxer maintains a deep respect for his country's architectural traditions, coupled with a determination to recast them in contemporary terms.
title: Architecture

text: Edited by the Italian architectural historian Francesco Dal Co, ''Tadao Ando: Complete Works,'' a career survey and critical compilation, is the best book to appear thus far on this major artist, whose creative tangent is still very much in the ascendant.
title: Architecture

text: For those who have never visited an Ando building (all but four of which are in Japan), the magnificent photographs by Richard Pare in ''Tadao Ando: The Colours of Light'' come as close to putting you there as any publication is likely to achieve. These poetic images merit Mr. Ando's praise of them as possessing ''a phantasmic beauty beyond real time.''
title: Architecture

text: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Christmas Books issue of December 1995. It is meant to suggest some of the high points in this year's fiction, poetry, nonfiction, mysteries and science fiction. The books are arranged alphabetically under genre headings.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: ANNAM. By Christophe Bataille. (New Directions, $15.95.) This austere, spooky short novel concerns an 18th-century French mission to Vietnam, which failed because of inflexibility and ignorance.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: ANTS ON THE MELON: A Collection of Poems. By Virginia Hamilton Adair. (Random House, $21.) Short, vigorous lyrics by an accomplished, original American poet who was never so bold as to offer a collection before.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: ATTICUS. By Ron Hansen. (HarperCollins, $22.) A rich, disturbing novel whose title character forgives his prodigal son more than most readers would be inclined to forgive.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF MY MOTHER. By Jamaica Kincaid. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.) A shocking fable of willed nihilism whose paranoid protagonist defines herself and her world through acts of simple hatred.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: BABEL TOWER. By A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $25.95.) In the third entry of a projected tetralogy about her own times, Ms. Byatt incarnates her awareness of fiction's fictiveness in a provincial Englishwoman who lusts for sex and books both.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: BATTING AGAINST CASTRO: Stories. By Jim Shepard. (Knopf, $22.) Various in style and subject, imaginative and mysterious in conception; in the title story, Cuba's future leader challenges an American visiting team in 1951.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE BEAUTY OF MEN. By Andrew Holleran. (Morrow, $24.) A bold, contrary novel whose hero, a gay man nearing 50, finds in his life a claustrophobic vacancy that owes more to a modern atrophy of spirit than to homosexuality.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: BEHIND THE SCENES AT THE MUSEUM. By Kate Atkinson. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) This impressive first novel, a multigenerational tale of a spectacularly dysfunctional Yorkshire family, transmutes the native gloom to guilty merriment.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: BELLE DU SEIGNEUR. By Albert Cohen. (Viking, $34.95.) A profoundly disturbing novel, published in France in 1968 and promptly canonized, about the doomed love affair of a cosmopolitan cynic and a slave to feminine cliches about passion.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: BIRDSONG. By Sebastian Faulks. (Random House, $25.) A novel (the author's fourth) in which the ''hell of the trenches'' of World War I is played out in the literal underworld of mine and countermine, and the past recaptured through the decoding of a sapper's diary in the 1970's.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE BOOK OF MERCY. By Kathleen Cambor. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) Ms. Cambor's absorbing first novel concerns a family (father an alchemist, children a psychiatrist and a priest) first broken but later mostly restored by the centripetal force of mutual forgiveness.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: BRAIN FEVER. By Valerie Sayers. (Doubleday, $23.95.) A failed academic breaks down and flees in this deep, ambitious novel, a case study of the workings of insanity, mercy and faith.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: BURNING YOUR BOATS: The Collected Short Stories. By Angela Carter. (John Mac-rae/Holt, $30.) A strange, dangerous world, full of surprises and reversals, comes to life in this collection, which includes six previously uncollected tales by this English writer, who died in 1992.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: CIVILWARLAND IN BAD DECLINE: Stories and a Novella. By George Saunders. (Random House, $22.) Cool and wicked satires, mostly taking place in theme parks where reality is created by the owners and external perceptions are fenced out.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: COYOTE V. ACME. By Ian Frazier. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.) A collection of short humor pieces full of moments of dazzling nonsense and pure joy.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: CROSS CHANNEL. By Julian Barnes. (Knopf, $21.) Short stories, crowded with understated or invisible meanings; the characters are English or Irish, living in France; the Channel is a metaphor for separations of a far more intimate kind.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: CROWS OVER A WHEATFIELD. By Paula Sharp. (Hyperion, $22.95.) In this novel, the effects of child abuse reverberate over decades, from a small Wisconsin town to New York City.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: DANCING AFTER HOURS: Stories. By Andre Dubus. (Knopf, $23.) Gracious and graceful short fiction, chiefly about love, that addresses matters closer to the province of poetry than of the novel.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: DEATH IN THE ANDES. By Mario Vargas Llosa. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) In his 11th novel, the Peruvian writer uses the story of a police investigation in the mountains to explore the political, social and religious complexities of his country.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE DEBT TO PLEASURE. By John Lanchester. (Holt, $20.) A delicious first novel by a British editor and food critic; his hero and narrator, the self-confident, loquacious Tarquin Winot, travels through France, measuring out his life by menus.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: DERBY DUGAN'S DEPRESSION FUNNIES. By Tom De Haven. (Metropolitan/Holt, $23.) An antic rags-to-rags novel whose narrator, a hack strip and pulp writer, struggles to earn a living in a world where commerce inevitably conquers art.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: DON'T CALL IT NIGHT. By Amos Oz. (Harcourt Brace, $22.) Mr. Oz's 11th novel is a middle-aged-love story of good intentions and very small deeds (but big enough in Israel, where ''ordinary'' is a condition to which many passionately aspire).
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE DREAM OF THE UNIFIED FIELD: Selected Poems 1974-1994. By Jorie Graham. (Ecco, $23.) This collection of philosophically and historically alert poems won a Pulitzer Prize in April.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: DROWN. By Junot Diaz. (Riverhead, $21.95.) Ten shapely stories (a first collection) in which the dislocation and disorder Mr. Diaz sees in the lives and languages of Dominican-Americans are transfigured by his rigorous sense of form.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE DROWNING ROOM. By Michael Pye. (Gran-ta/Viking, $22.95.) Fate and ambition contend in this novel, whose heroine, a landlady in 17th-century New Amsterdam, visits in memory her lowlife past in the original Amsterdam.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: AN EXPERIMENT IN LOVE. By Hilary Mantel. (Holt, $23.) This novel deploys love in many forms, chiefly in support of war between Carmel, whose mother is a strategist of rising in British society, and Karina, rotund and well fortified.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE FACULTY OF USELESS KNOWLEDGE. By Yury Dombrovsky. (Harvill/HarperCollins World, $26.) The master work of the late years of a distinguished (and repeatedly imprisoned) Soviet novelist, a half-allegorical narrative about imagination and its suppression.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE FAMILY MARKOWITZ. By Allegra Goodman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) Linked short stories about the fortunes of an American Jewish family, especially its indomitable matriarch, through three generations of crisis.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: A FATHER'S KISSES. By Bruce Jay Friedman. (Donald I. Fine, $22.95.) A wickedly funny novel about a none-too-bright widower who becomes a professional hit man, rubbing out people who deserve to die.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE FIGURED WHEEL: New and Collected Poems, 1966-1996. By Robert Pinsky. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.) An accomplished collection by a poet who captures for poetry such large intellectual concerns as history and culture, as well as the pleasures of storytelling and humor.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: A FINE BALANCE. By Rohinton Mistry. (Knopf, $26.) Set in India, this novel by a Bombay-born Canadian concerns four mismatched strangers who in adversity bond into an accidental human family, staving off catastrophe (for a while).
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE FLAMING CORSAGE. By William Kennedy. (Viking, $23.95.) The sixth novel in the author's Albany cycle is set 30 years earlier than the others, and concerns not the Phelans but the Daughertys, Edward and the mysterious Katrina.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: FROM BONDAGE: Volume 3 of ''Mercy of a Rude Stream.'' By Henry Roth. (St. Martin's, $25.95.) The first posthumous installment of Roth's huge fictional reconsideration of his life, begun some 40 years after his masterpiece, ''Call It Sleep.''
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE GHOST ROAD. By Pat Barker. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $21.95.) A hybrid of fact and possibility, this final novel in a trilogy of World War I has as its subject the dawning protest of the war's insanity and its fearsome carnage.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE GIANT'S HOUSE: A Romance. By Elizabeth McCracken. (Dial, $19.95.) Set in the 1950's, this novel tells of the unlikely romance of an old maid librarian and a juvenile giant.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: GIVE US A KISS: A Country Noir. By Daniel Woodrell. (Holt, $22.50.) In the pre-Wal-Mart town of West Table, Mo., a family feud endangers a marijuana patch and a thin layer of California mysticism intrudes on the Ozark ridges.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE GOLDEN ROPE. By Susan Fromberg Schaeffer. (Knopf, $25.) In alternating passages, twin sisters describe the repercussions when one of them mysteriously leaves.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: GREY AREA: And Other Stories. By Will Self. (Grove, $22.) British fiction in which all reality is virtual reality, and the characters sound like assemblages of bodily functions (there are lots of mucilaginous splats).
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: HEAT WAVE. By Penelope Lively. (HarperCollins, $22.) A rumination by the English novelist on the ways in which the past refuses to stay buried, with tragic consequences.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE HIDE. By Barry Unsworth. (Norton, $22.) Published in Britain in 1970, this dense, dark novel portrays the corruption of innocence in a particularly nasty slice of English countryside.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: HIGH LATITUDES: A Romance. By James Buchan. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) A cheeky, subversive novel of corporate intrigue whose heroine is a harsh, fearless businesswoman of 30.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: I'M LOSING YOU. By Bruce Wagner. (Villard, $23.) Mr. Wagner's trenchant second novel is set in Hollywood, where its characters strain for success in a silly, unfriendly universe that has forced them to incorporate AIDS into their humor.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: INDIAN KILLER. By Sherman Alexie. (Atlantic Monthly, $22.) A grim novel, with flashes of ceremonial laughter; the lives of its principal characters, all of them Indians, are deranged by a series of gruesome (scalping included) murders.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: INFINITE JEST. By David Foster Wallace. (Little, Brown, $29.95.) The author's considerable satirical and mimetic powers and his endless erudition together sustain this 1,079-page novel of the near future, in which the highest value is addictive entertainment.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: IN THE BEAUTY OF THE LILIES. By John Updike. (Knopf, $25.95.) Over four generations, an American family transfers its allegiance from religious to cinematic illusions in this novel that tracks the national quest for an improved reality.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: IN THE HOLD. By Vladimir Arsenijevic. (Knopf, $20.) A moving, personal novel concerned with the extinction of friends and friendships and the demoralization of youth in the Yugoslav wars.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: INTO THE GREAT WIDE OPEN. By Kevin Canty. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $21.95.) This first novel is a modern romance that engagingly presents the ancient premises that opposites attract and that young love is doomed.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: JACKSON'S DILEMMA. By Iris Murdoch. (Viking, $22.95.) In her 26th novel, the author delivers a psychologically rich tale of romances thwarted and revived, with characteristic philosophical depth.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: JOHN'S WIFE. By Robert Coover. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) A look at heartland America, revolving around the wife of a successful business tycoon who captures the interest of every man except her husband.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: LAND GIRLS. By Angela Huth. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $23.95.) Three young Englishwomen, working on a farm to spare men for combat, come each to a different maturity in this calm and engaging novel of wartime Britain.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: LAST DAYS OF THE DOG-MEN: Stories. By Brad Watson. (Norton, $19.) The vulnerability of marriage is the paramount theme of this crisp first collection of short fiction about men and women -- and dogs -- in the American South.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: LAST ORDERS. By Graham Swift. (Knopf, $23.) The multiple narrators of the author's sixth novel explore the experience of a group of middle-aged Englishmen and their families as they carry out the last wish of one of their number.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE LAST THING HE WANTED. By Joan Didion. (Knopf, $23.) In Joan Didion's dark, disaffected and politically opaque Caribbean, an American woman walks into her father's ruined life of arms deals, conspiracies and American intervention.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: A LAZY EYE: Stories. By Mary Morrissy. (Scribner, $21.) An elegant but grimly perceptive collection by an Irish writer whose stories are populated by women who suffer humiliation, then strike back at inappropriate targets.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: LIES OF THE SAINTS. By Erin McGraw. (Chronicle, paper, $11.95.) In this graceful collection of stories, good-natured characters manage to make marriage and parenthood work despite the messiness, and conclude that imperfect lives are well worth living for.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE LIFE OF GOD: (As Told by Himself). By Franco Ferrucci. (University of Chicago, $22.) An eclectic fictional history of God's disappointment over the limits of humanity's intelligence.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: LIFE WITHOUT WATER. By Nancy Peacock. (Longstreet Press, $16.95.) An unassuming but bold first novel that dares to interpret the 1960's, an era as unintelligible now as then, through the exposure of a hippie-flavored, dope-scented idyll to sexual tension and jealousy.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: LINES OF FATE. By Mark Kharitonov. (New Press, $25.) This powerful, digressive metafiction tracks a scholar's pursuit of a philosopher who wrote on the backs of candy wrappers because the knowable human truths are small enough to fit.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: MANHATTAN NOCTURNE. By Colin Harrison. (Crown, $24.) A street-smart and ordinary-smart thriller about a tough newspaper guy who bruises his sense of self by collision with a bad woman.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE MANIKIN. By Joanna Scott. (Holt, $22.50.) A ripe Gothic novel, set in a gloomy mansion stuffed full of brooding characters and ominous appurtenances; a success because the author, not the genre, is always in perfect control.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: MARTIN DRESSLER: The Tale of an American Dreamer. By Steven Millhauser. (Crown, $24.) A conjuring trick of a novel, set in late-19th-century New York, about a bootstrap capitalist's trip up the entrepreneurial ladder.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: MASON'S RETREAT. By Christopher Tilghman. (Random House, $22.) A decayed great house on Maryland's Eastern Shore propels its inheritor into a stately, absorbing tragedy in this first novel.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE MIDDLE HEART. By Bette Bao Lord. (Knopf, $25.) This long-running (about 75 years) novel is a lightly disguised history of China itself; its characters are compelled to renounce loved ones, political beliefs and personal morals to survive.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: MONA IN THE PROMISED LAND. By Gish Jen. (Knopf, $24.) Gish Jen's hopeful, intelligent second novel addresses the problem of American tribalism through young characters who simply switch identities whenever useful or necessary.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: MORALITY PLAY. By Barry Unsworth. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $22.50.) Medieval English players re-enact a child's murder in order to solve it in this bravura novel that shines period sensibilities on current (and timeless) issues.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE MUSIC: Stories. By James Hamilton-Paterson. (Cape/Trafalgar Square, paper, $17.95.) Intelligent, imaginative stories that seem to argue that contemplation of musical phenomena can lead to an understanding of everything else in life.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: MY OTHER LIFE. By Paul Theroux. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Mr. Theroux impersonates himself in an episodic novel that succeeds in endowing with credibility a highly unsympathetic character before evoking pity for him.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE NIGHT IN QUESTION: Stories. By Tobias Wolff. (Knopf, $23.) Fifteen peppery short stories about people caught unwittingly in the act of being themselves; set in hot circumstances, from a metropolitan daily to the Vietnam War.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: ON WITH THE STORY: Stories. By John Barth. (Little, Brown, $23.95.) A cerebrally challenging, characteristically post-modern collection of stories within a story whose two narrators face personal catastrophe wisely, foolishly or both.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE ORCHARD ON FIRE. By Shena Mackay. (Moyer Bell, $18.95.) Ms. Mackay's seventh novel is a deft and affecting coming-of-age story whose narrator recalls in maturity dark encounters she could not reveal to her parents when she was 8.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE OTHER FAMILY. By Jacqueline Carey. (Random House, $22.) A first novel that captures both the surface textures of the late 1960's and their irrelevance as hippie-flavored middle-class folks went on with lies and adultery as usual.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: PRIMARY COLORS. By Anonymous. (Random House, $24.) A roman a clef about the 1992 Democratic primaries, frightening in its disclosures of the real passions of politicians.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SANTA EVITA. By Tomas Eloy Martinez. (Knopf, $23.) A dazzling novel in which the sanctified corpse of Eva Peron supports meditations on memory, mythology and national character.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SEEING CALVIN COOLIDGE IN A DREAM. By John Derbyshire. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) Strange, bouncy and amiable, this first novel is narrated by a Chinese immigrant banker who lives on Long Island and turns to Calvin Coolidge for enlightenment.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SHORT STORIES OF LANGSTON HUGHES. Edited by Akiba Sullivan Harper. (Hill & Wang, $25.) Better known as a poet, Hughes also wrote short fiction throughout his long career, and this selection shows its many facets: satiric, political, ironic.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SISTER. By A. Manette Ansay. (Morrow, $24.) A melancholy, meditative novel about a young woman struggling to come to terms with a past she has never entirely left behind.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SLOWNESS. By Milan Kundera. (HarperCollins, $21.) The fast-moving modern world, where speed is a form of ecstasy, may not be the best of all possibles, Mr. Kundera suggests in this philosophical, almost polemical novel (his first written in French, not Czech), which cuts back and forth between this century and the 18th.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SMALL CEREMONIES and THE BOX GARDEN. By Carol Shields. (Penguin, paper, $10.95 each.) The earliest novels of last year's Pulitzer Prize fiction winner, published in Canada in the 1970's; they concern the divergent lives of a pair of sisters, one comfortable, one not; the author's patience and generosity are fully present already.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SO FORTH: Poems. By Joseph Brodsky. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.) A posthumous collection, written in his final decade, in which the great Russian emigre emerges as a complete and above all familiar human being.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE SPIRIT LEVEL. By Seamus Heaney. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.) Mr. Heaney's first book of poems since his Nobel Prize draws the reader into ethics, psychology and religion, with the author striking balances and seeking equilibrium.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE STATEMENT. By Brian Moore. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $22.95.) An old and guilty man is on the run from vengeance in this thriller that re-creates the self-examination and self-deception of Frenchmen who collaborated in the Holocaust.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SUSPECTS. By Thomas Berger. (Morrow, $23.) A crime-and-punishment novel by a master of the loony; his inconsequent, incompetent characters patently allude to the O. J. Simpson case and cast.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE SWEETHEART SEASON. By Karen Joy Fowler. (Marian Wood/Holt, $23.) A first-person narrator imagines her mother's life in 1940's Minnesota, lived (like many others) in submission and innocence without seeming dopey.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: TABLOID DREAMS: Stories. By Robert Olen Butler. (Holt, $22.50.) Highly accomplished fiction that seeks out and transmutes degraded headline cliches (''Every Man She Kisses Dies'') into substances of lyricism and wonder.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE TAILOR OF PANAMA. By John le Carre. (Knopf, $25.) With the Soviet Union sunk, Mr. le Carre fetches up in the New World with a savagely satirical, nonviolent thriller, in which a tailor fabulates for British intelligence.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: TALES FROM THE IRISH CLUB: A Collection of Short Stories. By Lester Goran. (Kent State University, paper, $12.) Stories more like life than fiction, about irruptions of disorder into the cozy small society of the Ancient Order of Hibernians.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: TALES OF BURNING LOVE. By Louise Erdrich. (HarperCollins, $25.) A funeral forms the comic centerpiece of this novel, as four widows bound by a common thread (all of them once married to the dear departed) come together during a blizzard to compare notes -- and to try to keep warm.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: TALKING IN BED. By Antonya Nelson. (Houghton Mifflin, $22.95.) A first novel from a highly praised short-story writer describes the turmoil -- both sad and funny -- that ensues when two mostly happy marriages meet and become entangled.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: TEN INDIANS. By Madison Smartt Bell. (Pantheon, $23.) A middle-aged man tries to overcome burnout by bringing the discipline of the martial arts to the inner city.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: TRAPLINES. By Eden Robinson. (Metropolitan Books/Holt, $23.) Stories by a young Canadian whose effectively anonymous, deadpan prose assimilates the discovery that Canadians are as weird and violent as anyone else on this continent.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: UNLOCKING THE AIR: And Other Stories. By Ursula K. Le Guin. (HarperCollins, $22.) At their best, these stories constitute a lightly ironic, playful and somewhat fantastic fiction of ideas concerned with the experience of women.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE VERACRUZ BLUES. By Mark Winegardner. (Viking, $22.95.) A remarkable first novel, set in Mexico and concerned with two major mythologies: American baseball (seen from outside) and the Great American Novel.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: WE WERE THE MULVANEYS. By Joyce Carol Oates. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $24.95.) Ms. Oates's 26th novel lets fate dissect a proud, happy, likable family, a bunch so uncannily well observed the reader is happy to hang around watching them work out a kind of redemption.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: WILL YOU ALWAYS LOVE ME? And Other Stories. By Joyce Carol Oates. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $23.95.) The competence of Ms. Oates's highly verbal characters does not surpass the power to give suffering a name; compassion is available, healing is not.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE WOMAN WHO WALKED INTO DOORS. By Roddy Doyle. (Viking, $22.95.) This novel shows that the inner life of a battered housewife can be as rich and as filled with implication as that of a character in Joyce or Proust.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: WORST FEARS. By Fay Weldon. (Atlantic Monthly, $21.) A snappy whodunit of the heart, the author's 21st novel concerns a woman whose husband died in circumstances that grow more complex and humiliating as the tale proceeds.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE YELLOW ADMIRAL. By Patrick O'Brian. (Norton, $24.) The 18th chapter of the Aubrey-Maturin series contains all the elements fans find dear: adventure on the high seas and stimulating, sometimes outrageous dialogue.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: YOU'RE SO BEAUTIFUL: Stories. By Eileen FitzGerald. (St. Martin's, $21.95.) A low-key collection, spare and affectionate, whose modest, mostly nice characters are alarmed and threatened by the attention of others.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: ZENZELE: A Letter for My Daughter. By J. Nozipo Maraire. (Crown, $20.) A novel in the form of a single long letter, meant to prevent a woman of Zimbabwe from losing her national heritage.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: AN ACCIDENTAL AUTOBIOGRAPHY. By Barbara Grizzuti Harrison. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Passionate yet disinterested yet wholly immoderate, Ms. Harrison re-examines many previous subjects with an eye sharper than ever.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: ALL RIVERS RUN TO THE SEA: Memoirs. By Elie Wiesel. (Knopf, $30.) Still unequaled at bringing home the horrific disorientation of the Holocaust, the author remains reticent about his own passage from little boy to icon, private person to public; a second volume may be more expansive.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: ALVIN AILEY: A Life in Dance. By Jennifer Dunning. (Addison-Wesley, $30.) A compassionate and painstakingly reported biography, by a dance critic at The Times, of a choreographer whose demons were unusually exacting.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: AMERICAN TRAGEDY: The Uncensored Story of the Simpson Defense. By Lawrence Schiller and James Willwerth. (Random House, $27.50.) A behind-the-scenes account of the defense team in the O. J. Simpson murder trial.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: ANDREW WYETH: A Secret Life. By Richard Meryman. (HarperCollins, $35.) A biography not of one artist but of a whole family of them; its journalistic approach encourages self-explication by talented, crotchety people who already understand themselves pretty well.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: ANGUS WILSON: A Biography. By Margaret Drabble. (St. Martin's, $35.) A frank, affectionate and judicious life of Wilson (1913-91), whose fresh, revolutionary fiction in the 1940's and 50's was as angry as the Angries and often funnier.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE ARCHITECT OF DESIRE: Beauty and Danger in the Stanford White Family. By Suzannah Lessard. (Dial, $24.95.) A moving inquiry into the psychology of architecture and the structure of family, by a descendant of the great architect and bounder Stanford White.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: ARGUING ABOUT SLAVERY: The Great Battle in the United States Congress. By William Lee Miller. (Knopf, $35.) A scholar's account of a long (1835-44) brawl over whether Congress could constitutionally even discuss slavery; its surprising hero is John Quincy Adams.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: ASHES TO ASHES: America's Hundred-Year Cigarette War, the Public Health, and the Unabashed Triumph of Philip Morris. By Richard Kluger. (Knopf, $35.) A battleship of a book (at over 800 pages), this formidable account includes interviews with industry insiders and enemies.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: AT A CENTURY'S ENDING: Reflections, 1982-1995. By George F. Kennan. (Norton, $27.50.) A collection of essays and talks by the distinguished diplomat shows that his special strength is his ability to divine Russia.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: AT THE STILL POINT: A Memoir. By Carol Buckley. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) Deft, evocative, generous recollections by the youngest of William F. Buckley Jr.'s nine siblings; a lot of her life was hellish, but she seems to have emerged in health.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: AUDEN. By Richard Davenport-Hines. (Pantheon, $30.) A life of the poet that contains some new material but is less a chronological biography than a meditation on central themes of Auden's life: grace, sin, Christianity, homosexuality.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: AUTOPSY ON AN EMPIRE: The American Ambassador's Account of the Collapse of the Soviet Union. By Jack F. Matlock Jr. (Random House, $35.) A scrupulously sober, fair-minded and intelligent analysis of the Soviet collapse, by a diplomat who was on the scene from 1987 to 1991.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: BLAKE. By Peter Ackroyd. (Knopf, $35.) The life of England's incorruptible, irrepressible visionary poet, artist and cosmic revolutionary, with fearless explications of Blake's works.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: BLOOD AND IRON: From Bismarck to Hitler, the von Moltke Family's Impact on German History. By Otto Friedrich. (HarperCollins, $30.) Brisk and entertaining, this history of a family that was influential in the German military for centuries was the last book by Otto Friedrich, a journalist and historian who died this year.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: BLOOD SPORT: The President and His Adversaries. By James B. Stewart (Simon & Schuster, $25.) With care and narrative skill, the author recounts the tangles of the Whitewater affair and the suicide of Vincent Foster.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: BLOOMSBURY RECALLED. By Quentin Bell. (Columbia University, $24.95.) A cheerful, amiable, charitable account of Bloomsbury's men and women, by a son of one such couple.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: BORN TO REBEL: Birth Order, Family Dynamics, and Creative Lives. By Frank J. Sulloway. (Pantheon, $30.) An M.I.T. research scholar presents a daring hypothesis: that birth order is a powerful determinant of personality (firstborns conventional, later-borns innovative).
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: BREAKING THE NEWS: How the Media Undermine American Democracy. By James Fallows. (Pantheon, $23.) An indictment of the irresponsible power, upper-crust alienation and plain clownery the author sees, and believes others see, in television and the press.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: BYZANTIUM: The Decline and Fall. By John Julius Norwich. (Knopf, $35.) The third and final volume of a spirited narrative history of the Eastern Roman Empire, a politico-religious institution now as little known in the West as when crusaders sacked Constantinople in 1204.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: CALIFORNIA FAULT: Searching for the Spirit of a State Along the San Andreas. By Thurston Clarke. (Ballantine, $24.) A good-humored foray into the nation's ultimate place, where a psychologist proposes that earthquake phenomena may cause U.F.O. sightings by altering brain function.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: CHARDIN. By Marianne Roland Michel. (Abrams, $125.) A monumental and lavishly illustrated study of the 18th-century French master of the still life.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: CHARLES IVES: A Life With Music. By Jan Swafford. (Norton, $30.) This generous biography lays out in detail the life and character of a distinguished composer and top-notch crank.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE CLOISTER WALK. By Kathleen Norris. (Riverhead, $23.95.) An intensely meditative poet conveys the religious and cultural texture of time spent in a Benedictine monastery in Minnesota.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: COMPOSITION IN BLACK AND WHITE: The Life of Philippa Schuyler. By Kathryn Talalay. (Oxford University, $30.) The heartbreaking career of a child prodigy, daughter of a black father and a white mother, reared as a force-fed genius; she was courageous enough to live to 35 before her death in a helicopter crash.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE CONTROVERSY OF ZION: Jewish Nationalism, the Jewish State, and the Unresolved Jewish Dilemma. By Geoffrey Wheatcroft. (Addison-Wesley, $25.) An engrossing essay, by a non-Jewish journalist, on the genesis of Zionism and its consequences for Jews around the world.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE CORRESPONDENCE OF SHELBY FOOTE & WALKER PERCY. Edited by Jay Tolson. (Center for Documentary Studies/Norton, $27.50.) The epistolary evidence of a lifelong friendship that survived distance, difference and even success.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: DAMNED TO FAME: The Life of Samuel Beckett. By James Knowlson. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) Chosen by Beckett to write his life, Mr. Knowlson produces new anecdotes and new intellectual materials that illuminate the accomplishments and regrets of this great gloomster.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: DESERT QUEEN. The Extraordinary Life of Gertrude Bell: Adventurer, Adviser to Kings, Ally of Lawrence of Arabia. By Janet Wallach. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $27.50.) A Middle Eastern expert's version of the woman so bold and smart British diplomats had to accept her influence.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE DIARIES OF DAWN POWELL: 1931-1965. Edited by Tim Page. (Steerforth, $32.) Covering the last 34 years of Powell's life, these recently discovered diaries show the acid vision that marked this great unrecognized novelist.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: DINNER WITH PERSEPHONE. By Patricia Storace. (Pantheon, $25.) A poet's observant memoir of a year in Greece, as inquisitive about the modern Greeks as it is mindful of the past.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: DINOSAUR IN A HAYSTACK: Reflections in Natural History. By Stephen Jay Gould. (Harmony, $25.) In his seventh collection of smoothly polished essays, America's Grand Explainer of difficult scientific ideas shows no sign of diminishing zeal for knocking concepts together until an understanding emerges.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: DINOSAURS OF THE FLAMING CLIFFS. By Michael Novacek. (Anchor/Doubleday, $24.95.) A stirring tale of recent glorious fossil troves in the Gobi Desert, by a senior curator at the American Museum of Natural History.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: DOSSIER: The Secret History of Armand Hammer. By Edward Jay Epstein. (Random House, $30.) How an adventurer-businessman cultivated the powerful from Lenin to George Bush and got rich and famous but not respectable.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: DUBIOUS CONCEPTIONS: The Politics of Teenage Pregnancy. By Kristin Luker. (Harvard University, $24.95.) A wise, thoughtful book arguing that concerns about teen-age pregnancy reflect a public mood rather than a demographic reality.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: DUCHAMP: A Biography. By Calvin Tomkins. (John Macrae/Holt, $35.) The first full-dress biography of the pre-eminent conceptual artist and wag of the 20th century.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: EDOUARD MANET: Rebel in a Frock Coat. By Beth Archer Brombert. (Little, Brown, $29.95.) A life of the painter, a rebel in art but otherwise a committed bourgeois, that is also an authoritative guide to French society in Manet's time.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: EMERSON AMONG THE ECCENTRICS: A Group Portrait. By Carlos Baker. (Viking, $34.95.) Published posthumously, this study of the Transcendentalists of 19th-century New England gracefully illuminates what made Emerson so magnetic.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE END OF SCIENCE: Facing the Limits of Knowledge in the Twilight of the Scientific Age. By John Horgan. (Helix/Addison-Wesley, $24.) A bracing argument by a science journalist that the best and biggest discoveries are behind us.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE ENDS OF THE EARTH: A Journey at the Dawn of the 21st Century. By Robert D. Kaplan. (Random House, $27.50.) Ominous travel writing about countries whose increasing poverty may pose grave consequences for the whole world.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE ESSENTIAL GOMBRICH: Selected Writings on Art and Culture. By E. H. Gombrich. Edited by Richard Woodfield. (Phaidon/Chronicle, $49.95.) A selection from the writings of Sir Ernst Gombrich, showing his broad range of learning and lucidity of expression.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: EUROPE: A History. By Norman Davies. (Oxford University, $39.95.) An idiosyncratic, vigorously written, sometimes weird account of the story of the continent.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: EVA LE GALLIENNE: A Biography. By Helen Sheehy. (Knopf, $37.50.) A biography of the actress, written with full access to her letters, scrapbooks, scripts and unpublished manuscripts.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: FIELDS OF BATTLE: The Wars for North America. By John Keegan. (Knopf, $30.) The where and why of the critical conflicts that produced this country, embedded in an eminent British historian's extravagant (and gratifying) affection for the United States.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: FIRST COMES LOVE. By Marion Winik. (Pantheon, $23.) A memoir by a young woman of resilient character who traversed the self-indulgent 1980's all the way, from drugs and debauchery to laundry and baby bottles.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: FLORENCE: A Portrait. By Michael Levey. (Harvard University, $35.) A profound inspection of Florence's monuments, linked to the cultural, political and financial history that made them.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: FORD MADOX FORD: A Dual Life. Volume 1: The World Before the War. By Max Saunders. (Oxford University, $55.) A scholar proposes that Ford's real-life compulsion to fabricate found its transfiguration in the epistemological collapse of his masterpiece, ''The Good Soldier.''
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: FOUNDING FATHER: Rediscovering George Washington. By Richard Brookhiser. (Free Press, $25.) A noble and effective effort to comprehend a figure whose almost eerie political intelligence is hidden from us by the self-restraint and impersonality that he was brought up to think were virtues.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: FROM LUCY TO LANGUAGE. By Donald Johanson and Blake Edgar. (Peter A. Nevraumont/Simon & Schuster, $50.) The paleoanthropologist who discovered the skeleton known as Lucy joins a science writer to present an encyclopedic compendium of current knowledge of human physical and cultural evolution.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: FULL HOUSE: The Spread of Excellence From Plato to Darwin. By Stephen Jay Gould. (Harmony, $25.) A distinguished paleontologist readably explains why complex organisms (like us) are not evidence that evolution favors complexity, and why nobody can hit .400 anymore.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: GHOST OF A CHANCE: A Memoir. By Peter Duchin with Charles Michener. (Random House, $27.50.) Brave, stylish and self-effacing, this autobiography of a society bandleader records, among other things, a mighty strange childhood under the care of W. Averell Harriman.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: GOD HAS NINETY-NINE NAMES: Reporting From a Militant Middle East. By Judith Miller. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) From eight Arab countries, plus Iran and Israel, the author, a former Cairo bureau chief of The Times, brings word of the state of Islam: complex and evolving.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: GOD'S CHINESE SON: The Taiping Heavenly Kingdom of Hong Xiuquan. By Jonathan D. Spence. (Norton, $27.50.) A history of the pseudo-Christian movement that convulsed 19th-century China, adumbrating Maoist messianism.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: GOOD NATURED: The Origins of Right and Wrong in Humans and Other Animals. By Frans de Waal. (Harvard University, $24.95.) A plausible account of the evolution of such moral elements as guilt, altruism and sympathy toward the oppressed.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996
