text: GRAND EXPECTATIONS: The United States, 1945-1974. By James T. Patterson. (Oxford University, $35.) A sweeping, meticulous synthesis of 30 years, from unique prosperity and influence to uncertainty and social fragmentation.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: GREAT BOOKS: My Adventures With Homer, Rousseau, Woolf, and Other Indestructible Writers of the Western World. By David Denby. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) In a lively journey of the mind, a middle-aged film critic re-enrolls in two core humanities courses at Columbia.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: HARD LANDING: The Epic Contest for Power and Profits That Plunged the Airlines Into Chaos. By Thomas Petzinger Jr. (Times Business Books/Random House, $30.) How management and labor, irreconcilable and incorrigible, ran the deregulated industry into the ground; by a veteran Wall Street Journal reporter.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: HEAVEN'S COAST: A Memoir. By Mark Doty. (HarperCollins, $24.) A terrifying and elegant document of the age of AIDS and the consequences of learning that one's lover has it; mostly furious, at last transcendent.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: HELLMAN AND HAMMETT: The Legendary Passion of Lillian Hellman and Dashiell Hammett. By Joan Mellen. (HarperCollins, $32.) A dual biography that unflinchingly presents its subjects' flaws, personal and political.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: HENRY MILLER: The Paris Years. By Brassai. (Arcade, $23.95.) Written by the photographer, who died in 1984, and illustrated with his images, this account lovingly re-creates Paris in the 30's and tells how the young Miller absorbed it all.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: HITLER'S WILLING EXECUTIONERS: Ordinary Germans and the Holocaust. By Daniel Jonah Goldhagen. (Knopf, $30.) The author, who teaches government and social studies at Harvard, contends that a deep-rooted German anti-Semitism ultimately led to the Final Solution.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: I.D.: How Heredity and Experience Make You Who You Are. By Winifred Gallagher. (Random House, $23.) A deft recounting of the history and science of temperament and personality by a journalist who integrates a tremendous field of theory and research.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: INDEPENDENT SPIRIT: Essays. By Hubert Butler. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) A selection from the work of a little-known Irish man of letters, whose reflections on his homeland and world affairs demonstrate courage, intelligence and grace.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE INHERITANCE: How Three Families and America Moved From Roosevelt to Reagan and Beyond. By Samuel G. Freedman. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) The rise and fall of the New Deal coalition in the Northeast, exemplified in the transitions of immigrant families to suburbians.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: IN MEMORY'S KITCHEN: A Legacy From the Women of Terezin. Edited by Cara De Silva. (Jason Aronson, $25.) Not a cookbook, though it has 70 recipes, but a Holocaust document, compiled as an act of defiance in a concentration camp and miraculously transmitted to the compiler's daughter in 1969
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: INTO THE WILD. By Jon Krakauer. (Villard, $22.) An otherworldly report on Christopher McCandless, a young American whose quest for purity of life brought him to the Alaskan wilderness, where he soon starved to death.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: ISAIAH BERLIN. By John Gray. (Princeton University, $19.95.) An examination (by an Oxford scholar) of Britain's most many-minded cultural figure, a man for whom thought and narrative are much the same and the ends of life are manifold.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: I WANT TO THANK MY BRAIN FOR REMEMBERING ME: A Memoir. By Jimmy Breslin. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) Successful brain surgery inspired Mr. Breslin to recall some fine stuff from a remarkable life in journalism.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: JESSE: The Life and Pilgrimage of Jesse Jackson. By Marshall Frady. (Random House, $28.50.) A journalist's quest for the inner character of a figure who is both a man of insatiable ego and a devoted political moralist.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: JOHN MARSHALL: Definer of a Nation. By Jean Edward Smith. (Holt, $35.) The first modern biography of the great Chief Justice of the United States shows how his jurisprudence was formed by the moral and political lessons of his life.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: JOURNEY TO THE LAND OF THE FLIES: And Other Travels. By Aldo Buzzi. (Random House, $23.) Four delightful essays in stream-of-consciousness tourism; every good thing reminds the author, a Milanese polymath, of some other good thing elsewhere in time or space.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: LEAVING A DOLL'S HOUSE: A Memoir. By Claire Bloom. (Little, Brown, $23.95.) The actress's account of her harrowing years with the novelist Philip Roth.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: LIEUTENANT NUN: Memoir of a Basque Transvestite in the New World. By Catalina de Erauso. (Beacon, $16.95.) An unrepentant account of her own rogueries by a woman who fled the convent to go for a soldier in 1600.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: LIFE AS WE KNOW IT: A Father, a Family, and an Exceptional Child. By Michael Berube. (Pantheon, $24.) A stringently unsentimental memoir, exploring family life and thought, by the father of a son with Down syndrome.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: A LIFE OF PICASSO. Volume 2: 1907-1917. By John Richardson with the collaboration of Marilyn McCully. (Random House, $55.) The continuing drama of Picasso's life, presented with wit, learning, energy, affection, patient analysis and some 1,000 black-and-white illustrations.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: A LIFETIME BURNING IN EVERY MOMENT: From the Journals of Alfred Kazin. Selected and edited by the author. (HarperCollins, $26.) Insightful notes on nearly 60 years of a well-spent literary life, by the distinguished liver himself.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: LIGHT YEARS: A Memoir. By Le Anne Schreiber. (Lyons & Burford, $20.) Richly detailed and reflective, the author's meditations on nature, love and loss reveal layers of memory and meaning.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE LIVELY ARTS: Gilbert Seldes and the Transformation of Cultural Criticism in the United States. By Michael Kammen. (Oxford University, $35.) A biography of the cultural commentator who vigorously championed the claims of lowbrow art.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE LIVING AND THE DEAD: Robert McNamara and Five Lives of a Lost War. By Paul Hendrickson. (Knopf, $27.50.) A worthy attempt to understand what nobody understands: why Mr. McNamara, the brightest of all possible Secretaries of Defense, preached and pursued the Vietnam War long after privately losing faith in it.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: LOOKING AT GIACOMETTI. By David Sylvester. (John Macrae/Holt, $27.50.) The author, who knew Alberto Giacometti and posed for him, reflects on an artist whose work was about the act of seeing.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE LOVE AFFAIR AS A WORK OF ART. By Dan Hofstadter. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) A rewarding study of five 19th-century French literary couples and their frustrations as they tried to sustain both life and art in an era that was determined to separate the two realms.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: LUSH LIFE: A Biography of Billy Strayhorn. By David Hajdu. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50.) Mr. Hajdu's remarkably detailed research brings Duke Ellington's great collaborator out of the double invisibility of being both black and gay.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: MAN TO MAN: Surviving Prostate Cancer. By Michael Korda. (Random House, $20.) The publisher and novelist offers an unflinching medical memoir, finished nine months after prostate surgery, that crusades against silence.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: MARY THROUGH THE CENTURIES: Her Place in the History of Culture. By Jaroslav Pelikan. (Yale University, $25.) Marian devotion examined, principally through music, art and literature, by a distinguished historian of Christian theology.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: MEMOIRS. By Mikhail Gorbachev. (Doubleday, $35.) In telling the story of his life, the former leader of the Soviet Union reveals that he has kept his idealism.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: MESSAGES FROM MY FATHER. By Calvin Trillin. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.) The New Yorker writer offers a sensitive and affectionate portrait of his immigrant father.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE MIDDLE EAST: A Brief History of the Last 2,000 Years. By Bernard Lewis. (Scribner, $30.) A distinguished scholar examines the dramatic rise and long decline of the Islamic world.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE MINDS OF BIRDS. By Alexander F. Skutch. (Texas A&M University, $29.95.) After a lifetime of study, the great ornithologist argues that birds have both intelligence and consciousness, similar to that of humans.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: MISSISSIPPI: An American Journey. By Anthony Walton. (Knopf, $24.) A compassionate meditation, by the son of black immigrants to Illinois from Mississippi, on his journey to the old country and on the realities of life there as it used to be and as it is now.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE MOST DANGEROUS MAN IN DETROIT: Walter Reuther and the Fate of American Labor. By Nelson Lichtenstein. (Basic Books, $35.) An elegant, intelligent portrait of the American labor movement in midcentury and of a dominant contributor to both its rise and its decline.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: MOTHERS OF INVENTION: Women of the Slaveholding South in the American Civil War. By Drew Gilpin Faust. (University of North Carolina, $29.95.) How the war subverted life and identity, seen in the writings of more than 500 women.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: MY DARK PLACES: An L.A. Crime Memoir. By James Ellroy. (Knopf, $25.) A rough, strenuous true-crime book with the distinction that the author is not only a competent novelist but the son of the victim, his mother, murdered in 1958.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE NET OF DREAMS: A Family's Search for a Rightful Place. By Julie Salamon. (Random House, $25.) A dangerously ambitious but largely successful effort by a secular Jew to visit and comprehend the tragic European past.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: NO L COWARD: A Biography. By Philip Hoare. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) The life of an outstanding wit and entertainer of our century, well researched, lucid and chock-full of amusing gossip about the great and not so great.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: NO INTERMISSIONS: The Life of Agnes de Mille. By Carol Easton. (Little, Brown, $29.95.) Even with de Mille's privileges of birth and talent, the price of her achievements as choreographer, author and lecturer, Ms. Easton tells us, was constant combat (she was skilled at that too).
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: NO PASSION SPENT: Essays 1978-1995. By George Steiner. (Yale University, $30.) The sage of titanic humanism speaks for the unified inheritance that is exemplified by works of high culture.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: NOT ENTITLED: A Memoir. By Frank Kermode. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) One of the best-known and most learned literary critics of our time tells not all but well, especially in a long, sharply observed section on World War II.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: NOTES FROM A SMALL ISLAND. By Bill Bryson. (Morrow, $25.) The astute, funny record of a valedictory tour of Britain by a good-natured Iowan who learned and loved its insular peculiarities during almost 20 years of residence.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: NOT WITHOUT HONOR: The History of American Anticommunism. By Richard Gid Powers. (Free Press, $30.) An evenhanded history that argues that the American anti-Communist movement was far more diverse -- and honorable -- than is often acknowledged.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: OLD SOLDIERS NEVER DIE: The Life of Douglas MacArthur. By Geoffrey Perret. (Random House, $32.50.) A fine new version of the oft-told and always readable story of destiny's tot and how he rose in power and charisma until he tried that stuff on President Harry S. Truman.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE OPEN SORE OF A CONTINENT: A Personal Narrative of the Nigerian Crisis. By Wole Soyinka. (Oxford University, $19.95.) The 1986 Nobel laureate uses his country's reversion to dictatorship to examine the very concept of nationhood, in which he still sees possibilities.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: ORSON WELLES: The Road to Xanadu. By Simon Callow. (Viking, $32.95.) The rise and rise again of the self-propelled, ego-intoxicated Welles fills this fat biography, which ends with ''Citizen Kane'' in 1941, when Welles was 26 (a second volume is planned for his descent from apogee).
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: OUR STOLEN FUTURE: Are We Threatening Our Fertility, Intelligence, and Survival? -- A Scientific Detective Story. By Theo Colborn, Dianne Dumanoski and John Peterson Myers. (Dutton, $24.95.) The thesis: man-made chemicals are disrupting animal reproduction everywhere. The proposal: find out if this is really so, soon.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: PATTON: A Genius for War. By Carlo D'Este. (HarperCollins, $35.) This admirably objective biography displays America's most spectacular general of World War II both when he was very, very good and when he was horrid.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: PEARL S. BUCK: A Cultural Biography. By Peter Conn. (Cambridge University, $29.95.) Scholarly and methodical but a thriller anyhow; the tale of an admirable feminist, antiracist, humanitarian and multiculturalist whose life was clouded by the contempt of serious critics for her Nobel Prize.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE PHYSICS OF STAR TREK. By Lawrence M. Krauss. (Basic Books, $18.50.) The chairman of the physics department at Case Western Reserve University uses the television show to explore what is and is not scientifically possible in regions where man has never gone before.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE PILLARS OF HERCULES: A Grand Tour of the Mediterranean. By Paul Theroux. (Putnam, $27.50.) A horrible tourist but a grand interlocutor, Mr. Theroux talks to whomever he meets, yielding slice after slice of the strangeness of everyday life around the great inland sea.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: PREVIOUS CONVICTIONS: A Journey Through the 1950's. By Nora Sayre. (Rutgers University, $37.95.) A memoir that recalls the intelligentsia, the politics and the changing social mores of the 50's.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: PURSUED BY FURIES: A Life of Malcolm Lowry. By Gordon Bowker. (St. Martin's, $29.95.) This careful biography of the driven author of ''Under the Volcano'' nominates him for ''least-known British literary genius of the 20th century.''
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: RACING TO THE BEGINNING OF THE ROAD: The Search for the Origin of Cancer. By Robert A. Weinberg. (Harmony, $27.50.) A biologist's dramatic accounts of the people on the front lines, imbued with the excitement of biomedical investigation.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: REFLECTED GLORY: The Life of Pamela Churchill Harriman. By Sally Bedell Smith. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) A massively researched biography of the American Ambassador to France whose romantic life is the stuff of legend.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: A RIVER LOST: The Life and Death of the Columbia. By Blaine Harden. (Norton, $25.) A calm dispatch on a contentious subject, the transformation of a wild river into a servile canal.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: ROSEBUD: The Story of Orson Welles. By David Thomson. (Knopf, $30.) An astute, fascinating, altogether unboring study whose large-scale pronouncements capture the essence of Welles's life better than they do the facts themselves.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE RUN OF HIS LIFE: The People v. O. J. Simpson. By Jeffrey Toobin. (Random House, $25.) A comprehensive account of the O. J. Simpson murder trial that comes to the conclusion that Mr. Simpson was guilty but was acquitted thanks to the defense lawyers' success in shifting the focus to race.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SAHARA UNVEILED: A Journey Across the Desert. By William Langewiesche. (Pantheon, $24.) No romantic Araby here, just the discoveries of a tough independent traveler, alert to the moral and material situations of the inhabitants.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE SCANDAL OF PLEASURE: Art in an Age of Fundamentalism. By Wendy Steiner. (University of Chicago, $24.95.) This defense of the potentiality of art is a spirited rebuttal of those who think its pleasures trivial or dangerous.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE SCHOOLS WE NEED: And Why We Don't Have Them. By E. D. Hirsch Jr. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The author of ''Cultural Literacy'' proposes an extensive national curriculum with standardized tests, reasoning that the more you know, the easier it becomes to know yet more.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SCIENCE ON TRIAL: The Clash of Medical Evidence and the Law in the Breast Implant Case. By Marcia Angell. (Norton, $27.50.) An accessible, passionate indictment of the ignorance, opportunism and social indifference that enriched lawyers and a few plaintiffs, though the available scientific evidence was against them.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SEARCHING FOR MEMORY: The Brain, the Mind, and the Past. By Daniel L. Schacter. (Basic Books, $27.) An excellent summary of the last 20 years of research, with a section of special relevance on ''recovered'' memories, so prominent lately in child abuse cases.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SEASON OF BLOOD: A Rwandan Journey. By Fergal Keane. (Viking, $22.95.) The first-person testimony of a television correspondent who visited Rwanda during the slaughter that took the lives of up to a million people in 1994.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE SEED IS MINE: The Life of Kas Maine, a South African Sharecropper, 1894-1985. By Charles van Onselen. (Hill & Wang, $35.) A veritable epic of the Transvaal, constructed from the life of a black farmer of great skill and indomitable will.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SHADES OF FREEDOM: Racial Politics and Presumptions of the American Legal Process. By A. Leon Higginbotham Jr. (Oxford University, $30.) A study by the eminent black jurist of the history of American law and racial segregation.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE SHADOW MAN. By Mary Gordon. (Random House, $24.) The novelist describes her search for the truth about her dead father, and comes to terms with the real man -- uneducated, anti-Semitic, previously married -- behind the lies.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SILVER RIGHTS. By Constance Curry. (Algonquin, $21.95.) An account of a black family's struggle to educate its children in Mississippi's public schools in the 1960's, inspiring as to result (seven of eight are university graduates), appalling as to process (the white kids never let up on them).
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: THE SIZE OF THOUGHTS: Essays and Other Lumber. By Nicholson Baker. (Random House, $25.) Excursions in nomenclature, syntax, information retrieval and fractal thinking, performed by a mind on a tightrope.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: SOME REMARKABLE MEN: Further Memoirs. By James Lord. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50.) A true but not naive believer in the privileges and obligations of genius recalls and assesses the life performances of some substantial artistic figures.
title: Notable Books of the Year 1996

text: This week, the Supreme Court heard arguments that the Brady law violates states' rights. The law imposes a five-day waiting period on handgun purchases to allow checks of criminal records. While most law enforcement organizations support the law, some county sheriffs oppose a provision that requires them to do the background checks. They object, as Justice Antonin Scalia puts it, that the Brady law ''makes the states dance like marionettes on the fingers of the Federal Government.''
title: Why the Brady Law Is Constitutional

text: The sheriffs' argument should be rejected. The Brady law asks state and local law enforcement officers to make only reasonable and minimal efforts to aid in insuring that guns stay out of criminal hands. It makes sense to ask local sheriffs to check such things as state arrest records. It's not clear why states' rights advocates think a Federal bureaucracy would be any better. Background checks do not invade states' rights any more than Federal laws requiring local law enforcement authorities to report missing children or traffic fatalities.
title: Why the Brady Law Is Constitutional

text: The reason is that, in the Brady law, the Federal Government has not commanded the states to make any policy. That sort of command, the Supreme Court has held, indeed would violate states' rights. In a 1992 decision, the Court held that Congress could not order the state of New York to pass laws regulating disposal of low-level radioactive waste or to take title to such waste itself. In an opinion by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, the Court held that such a law wrongly ''commandeers'' the state's legislative process. To solve a national problem, Congress may not pass the buck to the states, because ''state officials may bear the brunt of public disapproval,'' while Federal officials enjoy a free ride. Lines of electoral accountability are blurred: Voters won't know which set of bums to throw out.
title: Why the Brady Law Is Constitutional

text: The New York principle makes good sense, but the Brady law does not violate it. Congress has made all the hard policy choices on handgun control and bears the brunt of any public disapproval. When the local sheriff performs a background check, he or she is not being forced to make any policy judgments on behalf of the state. If a handgun purchaser doesn't like the background check, it is clear that Congress is to blame.
title: Why the Brady Law Is Constitutional

text: If the sheriffs were to win their challenge, the victory would likely be symbolic. Congress could simply make the background checks a condition of Federal grants. The Supreme Court has long held that the Government may require states to adhere to Federal policy in order to receive funds. For example, the Government induced the states to raise the minimum drinking age by making it a condition for receiving Federal highway funds. The sheriffs might applaud such an alternative on the ground that the Government would then be financing its mandate to them. But this money would not have to go to the sheriffs or pay their full costs to pass constitutional muster.
title: Why the Brady Law Is Constitutional

text: In recent years, Congress has made some serious encroachments on the traditional state and local role in criminal law enforcement, but the Brady law isn't one of them. Congress has federalized crimes that were traditionally state and local matters. Federal prisons are filled with home marijuana growers and local carjackers, who now occupy space that could be better used for violent criminals whose operations are truly interstate. These new criminal laws have proliferated not because it is good policy but because it is good politics. As Chief Justice William Rehnquist once remarked, ''The political combination of creating a Federal offense and attaching a mandatory minimum sentence has become a veritable siren song for Congress.''
title: Why the Brady Law Is Constitutional

text: In 1995, the Supreme Court stepped in to slow down this federalization of crime, by striking down a Federal law forbidding gun possession in schools.
title: Why the Brady Law Is Constitutional

text: If states' rights advocates were serious about curbing Congress in this area, they would not fight the routine duties required by the Brady law. Rather they would try to persuade Congress to take a more sensible approach to crime control. Yet many opponents of the Brady law have supported passage of these new and unnecessary Federal criminal laws. They should reconsider.
title: Why the Brady Law Is Constitutional

text: TWO weeks ago tomorrow, the Friday before the Cowboys were to lose at Giants Stadium, the word was on the street. And three days before the Cowboys were to dominate the Redskins on Thanksgiving, the word was in headlines in The Fort Worth Star-Telegram: Leon Lett had tested positive for drugs.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: Because of confidentiality clauses, mum was the word in the National Football League and Players Association offices as well as for Lett and his lawyers until Commissioner Paul Tagliabue ruled on the Cowboy defensive tackle's appeal over test collection and processing details.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: Finally, on Tuesday evening, the word was official: Lett was suspended for one year without pay.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: Since Lett had been banned for four games in the 1995 season for having tested positive for marijuana, when his recent test turned up positive, his one-year suspension was automatic under the N.F.L.'s drug policy.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: But the N.F.L. needs to speed up its appeal process.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: Its slowness in taking 11 days from the time the word first filtered out allowed the 6-foot-6-inch, 291-pound defensive tackle, who was on his way to All-Pro honors this season, to play two games he didn't deserve to be in.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: According to an N.F.L. spokesman, Greg Aiello, the checking on test collection and processing was ''done as quickly as possible.''
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: Ideally, the checking on Lett's appeal should have been done immediately after the word was on the street, in time for Lett to be banned for the Giants game two days later, which the Cowboys lost, 20-6.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: But the checking should certainly have been done early last week in time for a ruling sometime before the Cowboys' crucial divisional Thanksgiving Day game against the Redskins in Texas Stadium.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: Yes, the appeal process must be fair to a player, but it must also be fair to the opponents of that player's team.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: Ever since Charles Haley's spinal surgery early this season, Lett has been the Cowboys' best defensive lineman, the power behind their pass rush. He was a huge factor in the 21-10 victory over the Redskins that lifted the Cowboys into a share of first place in the National Conference East.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: In retrospect, Lett didn't deserve to play against the Redskins. With quicker action on his appeal, he would not have played. Maybe the Cowboys would have won anyway. Maybe not.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: The Redskins aren't the only team that could be affected by the slow appeal process. The Cowboys' victory on Thanksgiving could be the difference in home-field locations in the Super Bowl XXXI playoffs for the other N.F.C. contenders: the Redskins, Eagles, Packers, 49ers, Panthers and Vikings.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: Lett's appeal also exposed a loophole in the N.F.L.'s drug policy: a player in its drug program is subject to a maximum of 10 tests a month for a period of two years.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: Lett's appeal reportedly included the argument that the test that turned up positive was invalid because it was his 11th test in November. That suggests that once a player has passed his 10th test in any month, he knows he can take a chance on doing drugs until the next month is near.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: Is that what Lett thought? Only he knows.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: If a player is subject to only 10 tests a month, the N.F.L. testing people should space their tests so that the 10th is near the beginning of the next month. That way, there's no significant length of time when the player thinks he can do drugs because he's already had 10 tests.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: Of the eight N.F.L. drug suspensions this year, Lett's ban is the Cowboys' third. Wide receiver Michael Irvin was banned for the first five games after his guilty plea to felony cocaine possession. Defensive end Shante Carver was banned for the first six games for alcohol abuse.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: Irvin's case was sleazy. The police were called to an Irving, Tex., motel on March 3 to investigate what the manager called ''noise and possible prostitution.'' Irvin was found in a room with cocaine, marijuana, two ''self-employed models'' and a former Cowboy teammate, Alfredo Roberts.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: When the Cowboys' owner, Jerry Jones, was asked not long ago if his Cowboy players had learned a lesson from Irvin's suspension, Jones replied, yes. And maybe some have learned. But Leon Lett didn't.
title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans

text: They looked like Airborne Express deliverymen and they were even driving one of the company's trucks. But as soon as they had delivered their heavy package to a Brooklyn car repair shop, the two men arrested the worker who had signed for it.
title: 'Express Delivery' Parcel Delivers a Speedy Arrest

text: These were no deliverymen, and the package was no ordinary delivery. The men were undercover police officers assigned to an effort against drugs in Brooklyn, and the police said that the package, which they had intercepted, was an air compressor stuffed with 75 pounds of marijuana, worth thousands of dollars.
title: 'Express Delivery' Parcel Delivers a Speedy Arrest

text: The man they arrested was Albert Malcolm, 32, of 1964 Bussing Avenue in the Wakefield section of the Bronx. The police said that the repair shop, on Utica Avenue in East Flatbush, was not a target of the inquiry.
title: 'Express Delivery' Parcel Delivers a Speedy Arrest

text: ''We delivered it to the site, and once he signed for it, we locked him up,'' said Officer Joseph Butta, one of five police officers backing up the two in the truck. ''He was kind of surprised.''
title: 'Express Delivery' Parcel Delivers a Speedy Arrest

text: The police first received a tip on Saturday that a drug delivery was planned, said a senior Brooklyn police official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ''We got information that this thing contained drugs, so we tested and confirmed it and then got a warrant,'' the official said. ''Then we did a controlled delivery.''
title: 'Express Delivery' Parcel Delivers a Speedy Arrest

text: Law enforcement agencies have complained for years about drug dealers' using overnight package delivery services as their unwitting couriers. And while many delivery services have stepped up their security and screening procedures, drugs still occasionally get through.
title: 'Express Delivery' Parcel Delivers a Speedy Arrest

text: A spokesman for Airborne Express, who was unfamiliar with the details of the case, said that his company did all it could to avoid transporting drugs. Sometimes, smugglers find new ways to disguise their drugs. This time it didn't work.
title: 'Express Delivery' Parcel Delivers a Speedy Arrest

text: ''It was packed in a Sears Craftsman air compressor,'' Officer Butta said. ''A lot of it.''
title: 'Express Delivery' Parcel Delivers a Speedy Arrest

text: It's game night for the Mount Zion Christian Academy Mighty Warriors. So all rise.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: First, the pastor of the church, the Rev. Donald Fozard, gives the invocation, milking the clock as if it were the end of the game rather than the beginning. Next, 12-year-old James Dargen strolls to midcourt, where he plays ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' (you may have heard it) on the violin (but never like this). Finally, even before the last notes off the prodigy's sweet strings fade into the Carolina night, the two assistant Mount Zion pastors serving as P.A. announcers bellow into their separate microphones: ''Let's . . . Get . . . Ready . . . To . . . Rummmmble.''
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: Praise the Lord and pass the ammunition. Which at Mount Zion includes:
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: *Max Owens, a 6-foot-5-inch senior wing guard who has signed to play at North Carolina next year. Truth is, he would start and be precisely the deadly outside shooter the Tar Heels need at Chapel Hill this year.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: *George Mazyck, a 6-9, 280-pound senior center who has signed to play at Missouri, which outrecruited Cincinnati, Georgia Tech and others for his behemothian services.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: *Travis Spivey, a 6-2 senior point guard who has backed off his commitment to play football as a defensive back for Miami because he wants to replace Jacque Vaughn as the backcourt leader at Kansas.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: *Corey Hightower, a 6-6 senior forward whose angular quickness and intelligence enable him to start ahead of the 6-7 senior Brian Williams, himself the subject of passionate recruiting entreaties from Florida State to U.C.L.A.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: *Oh yes. And Tracy McGrady, a 6-9 senior every-position player -- unknown last summer, now ''the next Scottie Pippen,'' according to several scouts. McGrady is so surpassingly skilled that he turned down Rick Pitino of Kentucky last month so that he could weigh the likely option of entering the National Basketball Association draft as a lottery pick next summer.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: So how good does that make the Mighty Warriors among the high school basketball elite? Recruiting gurus agree this may be the best prep team ever assembled: as many as 10 of the players on Mount Zion's varsity could play Division I basketball. Mount Zion more than held its own in preseason scrimmages with the crosstown Duke University varsity, which is ranked No. 10 in the Associated Press college poll. Early national prep polls rank Mount Zion from No. 1 to No. 3.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: ''We should go undefeated,'' Mount Zion Coach Joel Hopkins said of his 2-0 team, which in an early showdown last week drilled Carter High School of Dallas, 103-69, as McGrady poured on the numbers: 34 points, 6 rebounds, 5 blocks.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: ''McGrady is the second-best basketball player in the state -- any level,'' said Hopkins. ''Tim Duncan is better than anybody the Charlotte Hornets got, and McGrady is next,'' Hopkins went on, rating McGrady above everyone in North Carolina except Wake Forest's All-America center.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: While Hopkins insists he doesn't specifically recruit -- ''I've hardly seen any of these kids play before they show up here,'' he said -- a network of Amateur Athletic Union coaches, players and church figures, combined with favorable word of mouth, have made Mount Zion an oasis for young men with a background of academic, family and discipline problems.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: Mount Zion is just the latest in the wave of private schools to specialize in offering academic discipline, social skills and basketball, especially basketball, to mostly black, inner-city youth who would have little chance at preparing for college any other way. Oak Hill in Virginia, Prospect Hall in Maryland and the famed DeMatha Catholic High School in suburban Washington have gained respect in academic and athletic circles even while luring away players from other schools.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: This fall Lamar Odom, the 6-9 star at Christ the King High School in Queens, created a stir when he transferred upstate to tiny Redemption Christian Academy in Troy, N.Y. -- ''To change his structure and environment,'' according to the Rev. John Massey, founder of Redemption Christian, where 65 students are enrolled this year.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: Mount Zion is larger, with an enrollment of around 200 in kindergarten through Grade 12. Like Redemption, it is coed (about 60 percent girls) and predominantly black. The basketball program includes road trips to Cincinnati, Norfolk, Va., and Lexington, Ky., as well as prestigious tournaments in Richmond, Rock Hill, S.C., Washington and Las Vegas, Nev.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: A little more than a decade ago, when Fozard started the Mount Zion school as an offshoot of his church, this was precisely his long-range vision. ''To use basketball as an evangelistical tool,'' he said. ''To take the dropouts, the fall-through-the-cracks, the un-churched, to get them in here and whip them into shape.''
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: Fozard is the brother-in-law of John Lucas, the former N.B.A. player and coach. That didn't help when Mount Zion's first team lost its opener, 118-18.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: ''But a few years ago at the barber shop I told Phil Ford the day would dawn when he'd be coming to Mount Zion for his players,'' Fozard said, referring to the assistant coach at the University of North Carolina. ''This is what I wanted. I spoke it. Get national attention. Be the best team in the country. It's God's anointment that we've done so well. Praise the Lord.''
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: Additional praise should go to Hopkins, 28, who played at North Carolina Central College before he was expelled for marijuana use. A family mortuary business was waiting. ''But,'' Hopkins said, ''I felt that would be a bore, sitting around waiting for people to die, even on Christmas and the Fourth of July when I couldn't go to the beach or anything.''
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: Hopkins, a parishioner at Mount Zion, ''was saved by the Lord'' and was, in turn, hired by Fozard to save basketball at the school. The Mount Zion experience is a combination of tough love -- ''McGrady! Shut the door on your way out!'' the coach barked at the future millionaire the other day in his office -- and bewilderingly stringent rules. ''A Christian boot camp,'' said one rival coach.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: Mount Zion players live in the same ''missionary house'' with Hopkins and his young family, start the day at 5 A.M. with a three-mile run, wear uniforms to class (oxford button-down, burgundy tie) and attend church twice a week. They are not allowed to date, swear, listen to rap music, wear jewelry or even talk on the phone to friends.
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: ''They're here to benefit themselves academically, spiritually and athletically; where does a phone come in?'' Hopkins said. ''Everything is, 'Yes Sir,' 'No Ma'am.' ''
title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever

text: With such structure and foundation, Hopkins has placed 17 former Mount Zion players in college basketball. Of the current team, Owens is from Macon, Ga.; Mazyck from Columbia, S.C.; Spivey from Myrtle Beach, S.C.; Hightower from Flint, Mich., and Williams from Richmond. Perhaps the recruitment of the 6-7 forward Travis Robinson from Gastonia, N.C., one of the best junior prospects in the land, is most instructive.

text: Mr. Keating, 72, had served four and a half years of a 12 1/2-year sentence on charges of securities fraud, conspiracy and racketeering after the collapse of the institution he ran, Lincoln Savings and Loan of Irvine, Calif. title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: Once the dirt road passes the big vegetable farms near Landless Corner and becomes the private highway of suicidal chickens and car-chasing cows, the huts take on the personalities of their owners. One thatched roof is so neat that it is fussy, another has a layered look, a third is a mess of slipping straw.
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: It seems an odd place for street children to end up: no streets.
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: That is part of the plan for the children's farm run here by Development Aid From People to People, a private European group.
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: Instead of street crimes, there are pigs to wash, okra plants to hoe and lessons to be learned in everything from farm economics to how to brush your teeth. There is lumber, with which students build the first beds in which they have ever slept.
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: In the six years the place has been running, only a handful of students have decided to return to sleeping on bus terminal floors. How do you keep them down on the farm when they've seen Lusaka? Kindness seems to be the answer. They do not cane boys who talk back, which Zambian teachers at public schools do routinely.
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: The counselors are remarkably unruffled about the habits their charges have when they arrive.
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: ''At first sometimes, they're stealing and smoking,'' said Lise Uld bjerg, shrugging as she locked a door behind her. ''They take the mattresses and blankets and sell to the villages around here. We have a sort of P.T.A. now with the local headmen. They tell the villagers not to buy, and to inform on the students. It takes a few months for them to change.''
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: Gilbert Sichalwe, 20, came to the farm five years ago. ''I had been looking after cars, stealing, smoking different things,'' he said. ''There was no one to control me. I liked it at the time I was in the street, but I realized that this place is good for me.''
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: ''Because in future,'' he explained, ''I will be someone.''
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: That someone, he hopes, will be a pig farmer. As one of the eldest students, he is a master of the ''piggery'' here. He is fond of the hogs, he says, but he has no problem helping make them into pork chops. As he bends to pat one, he has the proud smile of a man thinking, ''1,800 kwacha per kilo.''
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: The piggery is turning into a real profit center for the farm.
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: ''Agriculture is the best tool we can give them,'' said Brandy Blackman, a young Louisiana native who recently dropped out of graduate school to direct the farm. ''When they finish, they'll be able to grow a small plot and support a family.''
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: That is important in Zambia, which is deep into an austerity and privatization program. It may eventually turn the old socialist economy around, but right now it is costing thousands of Zambians their jobs, forcing them back to farming.
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: Neal Mpondo tends guava and orange seedlings in the garden. He is 13, but malnourishment has left him the size of an 8-year-old. ''My mother went home to our village and died,'' he said. ''My father died in Kabwe. I stayed at the bus station in Ndola. The other boys went to Lusaka, but I did not want to, because there I would start to steal something. Then the police picked me up.''
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: Pigs aside, the farm is paid for by old clothes. Development Aid, which originated in Denmark in 1977, and a similar group called Humana collect used clothing. The best furs, leather and funk fashion are sold in trendy shops from Helsinki to Barcelona. The rest is baled and sent here, most of it sold to street hawkers in the city. Some is kept for the farm's shop for local villagers, with the rest given to the children. There are about 150 here, mostly boys.
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: The school affects its teachers, too. ''When I first joined,'' said John Bwalya, 32, who cooks lunch and teaches mathematics and hygiene, ''I thought of simply caning and nothing else. If a child didn't come when you called, or if they said bad words -- in Government schools, you cane. But these children are different. They're used to a life of survival of the fittest. They were always in fights. If you started caning, you would lose them.''
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: They have lost only a few. One boy who pulled a knife on a teacher was sent back to Lusaka to be watched by a social agency and then returned -- only to throw a rock at another and be sent back for good. ''We're not police,'' Ms. Uldbjerg said.
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: But most of the children, who are referred here by welfare workers, change their ways quickly. Danny Njovu, 18, said he was drinking and smoking marijuana when he dropped out of school in Ndola and ended up in ''the probational institute.'' When he came out, his parents had disappeared. For years, he sold popsicles and old clothes on the street and begged for gardening work in the rainy season. Now he is molding cinderblocks for a new classroom and says he wants to be a builder.
title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia

text: The passage of voter initiatives in California and Arizona allowing the medical use of marijuana has caused renewed interest in a little-known Government program at the University of Mississippi that supplies marijuana for medicinal purposes to eight people across the country.
title: Despite Marijuana Furor, 8 Users Get Drug From the Government

text: ''There has definitely been more public attention to medical marijuana,'' Allen St. Pierre, deputy director of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, said on Thursday. ''But the increased attention has been bittersweet because there has been so much misinformation on the subject. We get so many calls when people hear of the program and want to know how they can apply or how it can be legal for eight and not for others.''
title: Despite Marijuana Furor, 8 Users Get Drug From the Government

text: Under a contract with the National Institute on Drug Abuse, the University of Mississippi in Oxford has grown marijuana for 26 years for research. It is the only legal marijuana plot in the country.
title: Despite Marijuana Furor, 8 Users Get Drug From the Government

text: Twenty years ago, the university began supplying a select group of patients with marijuana under a separate program, overseen by the Food and Drug Administration, to provide ''compassionate care'' to relieve symptoms from diseases like multiple sclerosis, epilepsy, cancer, glaucoma and rare genetic diseases. Even though Federal law classifies marijuana as an illegal narcotic with no recognized therapeutic value, the university's garden is supplying the eight patients with up to 300 marijuana cigarettes apiece each month.
title: Despite Marijuana Furor, 8 Users Get Drug From the Government

text: The program was set up in 1976 when Robert Randall, a glaucoma patient, won a court ruling in Washington that said marijuana was a medical necessity for his condition. Five of the original 13 patients have subsequently died.
title: Despite Marijuana Furor, 8 Users Get Drug From the Government

text: The program stopped taking new patients in 1992, when the Department of Health and Human Services began its official policy of disavowing marijuana as a legitimate form of treatment.
title: Despite Marijuana Furor, 8 Users Get Drug From the Government

text: Five of the original 13 patients have subsequently died.
title: Despite Marijuana Furor, 8 Users Get Drug From the Government

text: One patient, Corinne Millet, a 65-year-old woman who has glaucoma, says smoking marijuana has saved her sight. After two operations and ''trying every drop on the market,'' Ms. Millet was told that there was nothing that could prevent her from going blind. Ms. Millet says that prognosis was proved wrong on Oct. 14, 1989, when she was accepted into the Federal program that provides her with five marijuana cigarettes a day, which she says has allowed her to keep her vision.
title: Despite Marijuana Furor, 8 Users Get Drug From the Government

text: Although the new state laws allow doctors to prescribe marijuana in Arizona and to recommend its use in California, Federal law makes it illegal for patients to get it. By Federal definition, marijuana is a controlled substance with a high potential for abuse and no medical value. Proponents of legalizing marijuana for medicinal purposes say that seems illogical when forms of cocaine and morphine can be prescribed despite the risk of abuse.
title: Despite Marijuana Furor, 8 Users Get Drug From the Government

text: The very existence of the compassionate-care program contradicts Federal policy and puts the Food and Drug Administration in an ''awkward position,'' said Don McLearn, a spokesman for the agency. Despite its name, the Compassionate Investigative New Drug program, known as a compassionate I.N.D., is not a research study intended to evaluate the medicinal value of marijuana.
title: Despite Marijuana Furor, 8 Users Get Drug From the Government

text: ''It is not a clinical trial,'' Mr. McLearn said. ''There was never any intent of using reports from the compassionate I.N.D.'s to reach approval for the drug.''
title: Despite Marijuana Furor, 8 Users Get Drug From the Government

text: In fact, the reports submitted regularly by the participants' doctors are used only to evaluate whether to keep them in the program. The reports have no effect on a policy that discounts the medical value of smoking marijuana, Mr. McLearn said.

title: You're Under Arrest

text: But that is for the courts to decide. The fact remains, gentle reader, that you have been busted. A police officer has just put you under arrest and you are about to enter the unnerving behemoth known to cops and robbers alike as ''the system.''
title: You're Under Arrest

text: Rack your brains. You must have learned something from ''Dragnet,'' Detective Who-sowicz on ''N.Y.P.D. Blue,'' tropical memories of ''Hawaii Five-0'': Book 'em, Danno. Think. Oh yes, Miranda rights. You have the right to remain silent. It's part of pop culture. And something about being entitled to a phone call. But what if you get an answering machine?
title: You're Under Arrest

text: Just what does happen to you after the handcuffs go on?
title: You're Under Arrest

text: It is not such an idle question. Statistically speaking, you are more likely to be arrested these days. Although major crimes are down in the city, arrests are up, way up. Under Mayor Giuliani's crackdown on ''quality of life'' crimes, the police have arrested 21 percent more people this year than last year. Mostly for the little things.
title: You're Under Arrest

text: And if you are arrested, you are far more likely to go through the system, to be jailed until you are brought before a judge to be charged at arraignment. By law this process is not supposed to take more than 24 hours. And while the time between arrest and arraignment is shrinking, last month some people were held in cells for more than 60 hours waiting to see a judge for crimes like fare-beating, sleeping on park benches and drinking beer in public. You can spend up to three days behind bars before you are even charged with a crime. Getting a handle on how the criminal-justice system works is not such a bad idea.
title: You're Under Arrest

text: This is what you can expect if you are arrested in Manhattan, the arrest capital of the city.
title: You're Under Arrest

text: It's not like the movies. For one thing, the police don't always say ''You're under arrest.''
title: You're Under Arrest

text: But it should not be hard to tell. ''You're officially arrested as soon as a police officer puts hands or handcuffs on you on the street,'' said Robert J. Louden, who directs the Criminal Justice Center at John Jay College of Criminal Justice.
title: You're Under Arrest

text: And police officers do not always recite the Miranda rights.
title: You're Under Arrest

text: ''They didn't read me anything,'' recalled Cameron Clark, an artist who was arrested shortly after midnight on May 3 as he pasted one of his posters to a building on Hudson Street. And an East Village squatter who was arrested last year at a rally, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, insisted, ''With every arrest I've ever suffered, in California or New York City, I have never hard the Miranda warning from the mouth of a police officer, ever.''
title: You're Under Arrest

text: Whether or not you hear about your right to remain silent depends on whether or not the police want a confession. ''If they want to use your testimony against you, they must run down the Miranda rights with you,'' said Mr. Louden. ''If a cop witnesses a crime, he can arrest you and not ask you anything. Then he doesn't need to read the Miranda rights. But prosecutors and judges want to see people Mirandized.''
title: You're Under Arrest

text: With or without Miranda, what else happens when you're arrested?
title: You're Under Arrest

text: First, you will be ''tossed.'' That's what the police call their first search, when they frisk you and pat you down. They are looking for weapons and contraband, like drugs. Franklin Wiggins remembers. ''They said, 'Put your hands up against the wall,' '' recalled Mr. Wiggins, 40, a film maker who was arrested by two plainclothes officers on a heroin possession charge one Monday evening earlier last month as he walked down 10th Avenue in Hell's Kitchen. ''They went through my pockets, dumped cigarettes, threw pens away.''
title: You're Under Arrest

text: Then you will be cuffed. Charles King, an executive director of Housing Works, the AIDS services organization, said several civil disobedience arrests had convinced him that you will be more comfortable if you cross your hands, one over the other, before being cuffed. ''That way,'' he said, ''they can rest against each other.''
title: You're Under Arrest

text: Stay calm. It is illegal to resist arrest, even if the arrest is uncalled for. It is bad form to aggravate your arresting officers. Be polite. Call them officer, or sir, or ma'am.
title: You're Under Arrest

text: Mr. Clark, 25, ought to know. When he was caught pasting up his poster -- a drawing of a character he created, called Eye + Eye -- he remembers being contrite and offering to remove the poster immediately. ''I said I'd wash it off,'' he said.
